Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Financial Information of the Issuers
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer are newly formed entities incorporated on July 20, 2021, in each case for purposes of facilitating the Transactions and performing certain activities related thereto. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer and, following the completion of the Acquisition, the Target will be a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuers have no revenuegenerating activities of their own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those acquired or incurred in connection with their incorporation and the Transactions. As a result, no historical financial information of the Issuers is included in this Offering Memorandum, except for certain limited “adjusted” financial data presented on a consolidated basis, adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom, including the impact on the cash position, the amount of debt and the interest expense of the Group. The effects of purchase price accounting from the Acquisition have not yet been reflected in the information presented in this Offering Memorandum. The Acquisition may have certain effects on our financial statements and may impact our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows, which we are unable to determine with certainty until after the Completion Date. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating _to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Acquisition—We have made certain assumptions relating to the Acquisition in forecasts that may prove to be materially inaccurate.”_

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Title: Historical Financial Information of the Target Group
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of financial position and consolidated statement of cash flows of the Target Group presented herein are derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union and which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. (the “Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting (the “Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the “Historical Consolidated Financial Statements”). The financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 in this Offering Memorandum is derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Financial Statements”). The audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 were originally approved by us on December 31, 2019. Thereafter, we have restated certain financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, included in the 2019 Financial Statements, by restating the classification of “other receivables” to “trade receivables” for an amount of €619 thousand, “other payables” to “current other liabilities” for an amount of €68,947 thousand, “non-current other liabilities” to “other liabilities” for an amount of €2,004 thousand, “other receivables” to “other assets” for an amount of €32,629 thousand and “tax liabilities” to “liabilities held for sale” for an amount of €1,792 thousand. These restatements do not have any impact on the reported profit for the year 2018 or reported equity and an immaterial impact on the cash flow statement for 2018. As a result, we have not separately restated the financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018. See note 2.3 to the 2019 Financial Statements. ----- In addition, we also present certain financial information of the Target Group for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 (the “LTM Financial Information”). Except as otherwise stated, the LTM Financial Information is derived by adding the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to the audited consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income of the Target Group for the year ended December 31, 2020 and deducting the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. The LTM Financial Information has been presented for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. Except as stated otherwise, the LTM Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting or in accordance with IFRS. We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) effective from January 1, 2019. As a result, leases (as lessee) that would have been classified in previous periods as operating leases are recognized in our consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. Under the new standard, except for short-term or low-value leases, the right to use a leased asset is recognized as an asset with a corresponding financial liability for the present value of outstanding lease payments. Assets with a finite useful life are subject to impairment testing. We have adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment obligations from existing operating leases were discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and recognized as a lease liability and the right-to-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments. As a result of the application of new accounting standards and the associated impact on our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements, prospective investors should exercise particular caution when comparing our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 to our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations.” For a discussion of the_ effects of the adoption of IFRS 16 on our financial condition and results of operations, see “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and note 2.4 to the 2019 Financial Statements._ We have included in this Offering Memorandum for the convenience of the reader, certain metrics excluding the impact of cash leases that have been impacted by IFRS 16 as the adoption of IFRS 16 has had a significant impact on our historical financials which has impacted the comparability of some of our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum and we believe it is of interest to investors to present certain measures excluding such impact to facilitate like-for-like comparability between our historical financial information during the periods under review. After the completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group will not prepare separate consolidated financial statements and we instead intend to report our consolidated financial results at the level of the Parent. Due to this, our future financial statements may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum. Our future financial statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Impacting Comparability—Reporting.”_

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Pro Forma Adjustments Related to the Tele2 and Simpel Acquisitions and T-Infra Demerger
Subsubsection Text: We completed the acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019 and the acquisition of Simpel on December 1, 2020. On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our rented sites to a separate legal entity, T-Infra. T-Infra was transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date. In this Offering Memorandum, we present Pro Forma Net Revenue which is based on Tele2 and Simpel’s revenues for their respective preacquisition periods (adjusted for the estimated impact of IFRS 15 and IFRS 16) which are added to our revenue and adjusted for certain management reclassifications. We also present in this Offering Memorandum, Pro ----- Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying RunRate EBITDA AcL which make certain adjustments to our EBITDA for the periods presented to take into account the reported EBITDA contributions of Tele2 and Simpel for their respective pre-acquisition periods, and eliminating the reported (negative) EBITDA of T-Infra (demerged business) for the relevant periods after making certain intercompany adjustments based on management reclassifications and to exclude special factors such as pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, as detailed in this Offering Memorandum. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL as presented herein are not intended to represent pro forma financial information prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X promulgated under the U.S. Securities Act or other SEC requirements or IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The assumptions underlying Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are presented for informational purposes only and do not purport to represent what our results of operations or financial condition would have been had the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel and the de-merger of T-infra actually occurred on the dates indicated, and they do not purport to project the results of operations or financial condition for any future period or as of any future date.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum contains certain financial measures and ratios (the “Non-IFRS

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Measures”), including Pro Forma Net Revenue, EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin, Underlying EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL Margin, Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow, Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion, Capital Expenditure, Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL Margin that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. Non-IFRS measures presented in this Offering Memorandum (and which are subject to the qualifications described below) include the following. For further information, see “Summary—Summary _Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial Information” and “Summary—Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Capital Expenditure Data.”_ - “Pro Forma Net Revenue” which represents our net revenue for the year/period, to include the pro forma effect of the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel, in each case from January 1, 2018 and certain TMNL management reclassifications. - We present Pro Forma Net Revenue because we believe that it facilitates like-for-like comparability between our historical financial information during the periods under review. - “EBITDA” which we define as net profit/(loss) for the relevant period, before income taxes, gain from other financial activities, net finance costs and depreciation, amortization and impairment losses. - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA” which we define as our EBITDA adjusted for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, the demerger of T-Infra and certain TMNL management reclassifications, as well as to exclude special factors such as pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring ----- costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, consisting primarily of advisory costs/support, network integration costs and severance costs. - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude the estimated impact of IFRS 16, thereby including operating lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with cash EBITDA. - “Underlying EBITDA AcL” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, adjusted to exclude (i) certain items, which management believes are one-off and/or non-recurring items and (ii) removal costs related to the stock appreciation right (“SAR”) scheme introduced by TMNL in 2017. We present EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL and Underlying EBITDA AcL because we believe that these measures provide useful information to our management and investors with respect to our overall operating performance by facilitating comparisons of operating performance on a consistent basis by removing the impact of items not directly resulting from core operations. We present these Non-IFRS Measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance. - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage. - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage. - “Underlying EBITDA AcL Margin” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage. - “Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow” which we define as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL less Capital Expenditure. - “Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL less Capital Expenditure. We present Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow and Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow because we believe that similar free cash flow measures are frequently used by securities analysts, investors and other interested parties in evaluating similar issuers. Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow and Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow should not be considered as measures of cash flow from operations under IFRS or as an indicator of liquidity. - “Cash Conversion” which we define as Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow divided by Underlying EBITDA AcL. - “Capital Expenditure” which we calculate as the sum of mobile capital expenditure, fixed capital expenditure, IT capital expenditure and other capital expenditure. - “Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL” which we define as Underlying EBITDA AcL adjusted for (i) the full year effect of achieved synergies and (ii) the full year impact of planned unrealized synergies. We believe Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL provides useful information to our management and investors with respect to our overall operating performance. We present Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL because we believe that it and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance. ----- - “Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL Margin” which we define as Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL divided by Pro Forma Net Revenue, expressed as a percentage. The Non-IFRS measures and other information presented in this Offering Memorandum have been prepared for information purposes only and have not been prepared in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP or any other internationally accepted accounting principles or audited or reviewed in accordance with any applicable auditing standards. These non-IFRS measures and other information are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered as alternative or substitute measures to evaluate our performance. You should not consider the foregoing items as alternatives or substitutes to comparable IFRS measures. Moreover, these measures and related ratios: - have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation; - are not measures of our financial performance or liquidity under IFRS; - should not be considered as alternatives to net cash flow from operating activities or any other measure of our liquidity derived in accordance with IFRS; - should not be considered as alternatives or substitutes to profit/(loss) after tax or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS; - may not be indicative of our results of operations; and - do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available for cash requirements. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only to supplement the evaluation of our performance. We present the Non-IFRS measures and other information (i) as they are used by our management to monitor and report to the board on financial position and (ii) to present similar measures that are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of financial position, financial performance and liquidity. We present the Non-IFRS Measures because we believe that they are of interest to the investors and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. We believe these Non-IFRS measures and other information enhance the investor’s understanding of our indebtedness and our ability to fund our ongoing operations, make capital expenditures and meet and service our obligations, including our obligations under the Notes. The Non-IFRS measures and other information are based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable in the circumstances. However, these assumptions and estimates are inherently uncertain, subject to a wide variety of significant business, economic and other risks and may differ materially from our actual financial condition and results of operations. The Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our or any of our subsidiaries’ operating results as reported under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. You should exercise caution in comparing these measures as reported by us to such measures of other companies. The Non-IFRS Measures may also be defined differently than the corresponding terms governing our indebtedness, including the Senior Secured Notes Indenture (as described under “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes”), the Senior Notes Indenture (as described under “Description of the Senior Notes”) and the_ Senior Facilities Agreement (as described under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”). The NonIFRS Measures and ratios are not measurements of our or any of our subsidiaries’ performance or liquidity under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. In addition, the presentation of these NonIFRS Measures is not intended to, and does not comply with, the reporting requirements of the SEC and will ----- not be subject to review by the SEC. Therefore, investors should not place undue reliance on the Non-IFRS Measures. The Historical Consolidated Financial Statements mentioned above do not indicate results that may be expected for any future period. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial _Information—This Offering Memorandum includes certain non-IFRS financial measures calculated using management estimates or projections and they should not be relied upon in isolation when making an investment decision.”_ In making an investment decision, you must rely upon your own examination of the terms of this Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult your own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP and how those differences could affect the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. For a description of the Non-IFRS Measures referenced in this Offering Memorandum, see “Summary—Summary Financial _Information and Other Data—Non-IFRS Measures.”_

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: We also present in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited financial information of the Group adjusted to give effect to the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom as if they had occurred on September 30, 2021 for the consolidated statement of financial position data and on October 1, 2020 for our consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income data, including the impact on our cash position, amount of debt and interest expense (the “Adjusted Financial Information”). The Adjusted Financial Information is not intended to represent pro forma financial information prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X promulgated under the U.S. Securities Act or other SEC requirements or IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. The Adjusted Financial Information is based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The assumptions underlying the Adjusted Financial Information have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. The Adjusted Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting. The Adjusted Financial Information is presented for informational purposes only and does not purport to represent what our results of operations or financial condition would have been had the Transactions actually occurred on the date indicated, and they do not purport to project the results of operations or financial condition for any future period or as of any future date. The Adjusted Financial Information should be read in conjunction with the information contained in “Summary—Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Adjusted Financial Information,” “Capitalization,” “Selected Historical Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations” as well as the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements_ and accompanying notes thereto appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum also includes information relating to certain non-financial key performance indicators (“KPIs”) of our operations, including, among others, B2C Mobile Postpaid Subscribers, B2C Fixed Subscribers, B2B Mobile Subscribers, B2C Mobile Postpaid average revenue per user (“ARPU”), B2C Fixed ARPU and B2B Mobile ARPU. For a full list of our key performance indicators, see “Summary— _Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Key Performance Indicators” None of these terms are_ measures of financial performance under IFRS, nor have these measures been audited or reviewed by an auditor, consultant or expert. All of these measures are derived from the Target Group’s internal operating systems. As defined by us, these terms may not be directly comparable to corresponding or similar terms used by competitors or other companies. Our KPIs included in this Offering Memorandum are defined below: ----- B2C Mobile Postpaid ARPU ...._** represents the sum of postpaid mobile ARPU in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands. B2C Fixed ARPU ....................._** represents the sum of fixed ARPU in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile Thuis and Tele2 brands. B2B Mobile ARPU ..................._** represents the ARPU in our B2B segments.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial information presented in billions, millions or thousands and percentages, have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data in this Offering Memorandum may vary from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. In this Offering Memorandum, percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other information set forth in “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations” are calculated using the rounded numerical data included in this Offering_ Memorandum and not the numerical data in the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements or the relevant entity’s internal accounting system. With respect to financial information set out in this Offering Memorandum, a dash (“—”) signifies that the relevant figure is not applicable for such period, zero or rounded to zero. -----

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, references to “IFRS” herein are to International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union.

Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid) and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The _2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut)._ As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers, representing an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our combined mobile service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled €391 million, and our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million. Mobile service revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming, and our fixed line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as fixed line wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was €292 million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €637.4 million. TMNL traces its origins back to 2002, when Deutsche Telekom entered the Dutch market through the acquisition of Ben, which it subsequently rebranded as T-Mobile in 2003. In 2007, we acquired Orange Netherlands, making us the third largest mobile operator in The Netherlands after Koninklijke KPN N.V. (“KPN”) and VodafoneZiggo Group Holding B.V. (“VFZ”). In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which was subsequently renamed to TMNL Thuis. This transaction marked our entry into the fixed market, adding approximately 150,000 fixed line customers. Through the TMNL Thuis acquisition, we also gained access to a dark fiber footprint on KPN’s fiber network (KPN ODF). In January 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2, strengthening our position in the Dutch market, across all segments. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, an online-only SIM-only MVNO on our network, focusing in particular on the low budget segment of the market. The Simpel acquisition further strengthened our position, making us the leader both in terms of B2C mobile postpaid SIM cards and service revenues. We continue to operate the Simpel brand after its acquisition in 2020. In April 2021, we announced a strategic partnership with Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP that plans to roll-out fiber services to over one million homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on this network which focuses on dense, urban areas in which we currently have a large mobile market share. The Open Dutch Fiber partnership is an example of our asset-light model and lean operational setup, which we believe enables us to streamline our business and optimize our indirect cost base ratio. We provide our B2C customers with a multi-brand portfolio of mobile services, including voice, messaging and broadband aiming to cover all segments of the market from premium to low-budget and operating on our own networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide fixed broadband, TV and fixed voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. In addition, and in line with market trends, we offer B2C customers packages that bundle mobile and fixed telecommunications services at attractive prices, known as FMC packages. Our B2B business segment is dedicated to meeting the ----- connectivity needs of companies of all types and sizes as we offer a broad range of telecommunications solutions, cloud-based and unified communications solutions. The chart below sets forth key events in our growth and transformation to the largest mobile telecommunications provider in The Netherlands’ B2C market and an established mobile-led FMC challenger. We have invested heavily in our offerings and we believe we have successfully repositioned our business through innovation and change, as evidenced by our new offerings and services and by our being the first provider to offer nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band. Going forward, we believe we are uniquely positioned to capitalize on further growth opportunities, enabling us to continue on our historical trajectory and set new industry standards. The chart below highlights some of our key successes between 2015 and 2020. _Source: Telecompaper, competitor reports, Company information. Notes: (1) Magenta FTTH footprint consists of FTTH from KPN wholesale, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest fiber. (2) As of the second quarter of 2021. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group and consists of (i) customer recommendation, (ii) customer likelihood to continue services, (iii) competitive advantage and (iv) performance. (3) As per Telecompaper, fourth quarter of 2015. (4) Base for calculation includes T-Mobile premium brand and Tele2 subscriptions across both B2C (3.4 million subscribers) and SOHO/VSE B2B (0.4 million subscribers)._

Subsubsection Title: Attractive telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: We operate in The Netherlands, which has a sizeable and attractive telecommunications market which consists of three main telecommunications providers. The Netherlands is the 6[th ]largest economy in Europe and has a robust macroeconomic environment, with 2% real GDP growth expected for 2021, moderate population and household growth, and a large demand for high-quality communication services (Source: Telecompaper). We compete in both the mobile and the fixed markets with KPN and VFZ. We are the premier company in the B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as ----- compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the same market. The MVNO market is small accounting for approximately 4% market share of postpaid SIMs, with the largest MVNO, Youfone, having an approximately 3% market share based on number of SIM subscribers. In this context, we believe the risk of irrational behaviors by existing competitors is low and that existing MNOs are likely to compete primarily on the quality of their services. Following our acquisition of Tele2, the market players were further consolidated from four to three and a process of revenue and ARPU stabilization started, similar to what has been seen in other markets such as Austria, Germany or Ireland. The Netherlands has one of the lowest ARPU levels in Europe. We also believe that the risk of a new MNO entering the market is low. We believe that this is due to the following factors: (i) the highly converged nature of the market, making it less attractive for new entrants, as they must be able to offer both mobile and fixed offers to be competitive therein and (ii) the lack of any viable spectrum auction that could allow the entrance of a new player, since the upcoming 5G spectrum auction in The Netherlands is planned to offer only a specific band of spectrum and we do not need to renew our existing spectrum licenses until 2030, making the auction more suitable for existing MNOs and unsuitable for new entrants. The most recent possibility for a new entrant to obtain a marketable spectrum allocation would have been the 2020 multi-band spectrum auction. However, only the three main players in the telecommunications market, namely KPN, VFZ and us, participated in the auction. Additionally, we believe that the competitive risk posed by MVNOs is low because MVNOs have limited ability to compete on unlimited subscriptions in light of each MVNO’s lack of owned network and their limited ability to cover FMC packages, as well as such unlimited plans’ impact on costs. Indeed, the number of MVNOs has decreased by half from approximately 60 to approximately 30 in The Netherlands over the last six years. Furthermore, we anticipate that the B2C mobile market will continue to grow as data traffic continues to increase. Indeed, our B2C mobile pro forma service revenues grew by 3.1% in 2020 (after a 4.1% decrease in 2019) despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Key trends include: (i) Growth in postpaid SIMs subscriptions, which is driven both by prepaid to postpaid subscription migration and by population growth, as well as trends of increasing proportions of multi-SIM subscriptions; and (ii) Growth in mobile ARPU as driven by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services, value-added services as well as overall inflation and the telecommunications market’s shift towards larger data bundles. We believe that B2C ARPU will grow in the future due to these factors, even though mobile ARPUs had decreased in The Netherlands in past years because of intense price competition and mobile discounting as part of FMC offers, mainly triggered by KPN and VFZ. The following table sets out historical trends in B2C mobile services ARPU across our brands and our two major competitors, KPN and VFZ, and demonstrates that while ARPU among our competitors has generally decreased in recent years, ARPU among our brands has generally increased or stabilized. ----- _Source: Company information and publicly available information adjusted based on management estimates._ The B2B market has seen similar developments. In particular, ARPU in the SOHO/VSE segment follows consumer market trends, driven as in the B2C market by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services and value-added services, and we believe those drivers will continue to push ARPU growth. In the B2B market generally, we believe that growth in subscribers will be driven by growth in SOHO/VSE businesses, an increased adoption of mobile services in the B2B market and an increasing adoption of converged telecommunications solutions. Additionally, the Dutch fixed telecommunications market has benefitted from infrastructure upgrades in recent years that have contributed to a growing market, in spite of declining telephony and peaking TV, primarily due to a higher demand for broadband services at higher speeds, which is our core product offering within the fixed segment. Historically, the fixed internet market in The Netherlands was dominated by KPN and VFZ, which have a combined market share of approximately 80%. We have positioned ourselves as a challenger in this market, focusing on providing fast broadband services and offering competitive and sustainable pricing. In the future, we believe that growth in the fixed market will be driven by (i) an increase in subscribers associated with household growth and (ii) premium customers’ willingness to pay for ultrafast fiber and better quality, which allows for more-for-more strategies and results in increasing demand for higher fiberbased data bundles. FTTH coverage is expanding in The Netherlands and the B2C and B2B markets are expected to benefit from such expansion. We expect to benefit from this trend through what we call our ‘Magenta’ footprint, which includes several Optical Distribution Framework-type of agreements and partnerships with, among others, Open Dutch Fiber, KPN’s affiliate Reggefiber Operator B.V. and Primevest Capital Partners, where we expect to ----- eventually have access to over three million households at sustainable commercial terms. The remaining households can be reached by Wholesale Broadband Access (“WBA”)-type of access on KPN copper (until its planned phase-out over the next three years) and/or fiber network. Additional infrastructure players of significant size include Delta Fiber, Glaspoort (a joint venture between KPN and APG Groep N.V.) and Eurofiber.

Subsubsection Title: World-class network and strong commercial execution
Subsubsection Text: We lead our competitors across a number of key attributes, including our world-class mobile network with the largest spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands, our leading brand portfolio and our strong commercial execution. In December 2020, Umlaut ranked us the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and in February 2021, they recognized us as the top network in the world (Sources: PresseBox, Five in _a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again; PresseBox, T- Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut). According to the ACM, our mobile network carries_ approximately 50% of mobile data traffic in The Netherlands. We believe that our leading network position results from our efficiently leveraging three key pillars: (i) technology, such as single radio access network (“RAN”) with future-proof site configurations that are regularly upgraded in anticipation of customer demand; (ii) sites, as we operate an optimal site grid with the highest site density in urban areas and 4,982 base stations in total, providing coverage to more than 99% of the population of The Netherlands; (iii) the largest mobile spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands with interference-free low bands, resulting in high cost efficiency and an indoor capacity advantage. As of December 31, 2020, we held an aggregate of 250 MHz of spectrum, in comparison with 215 MHz for VFZ and 195 MHz for KPN. None of the licenses in our portfolio need to be renewed before 2030. We have distinguished ourselves by our distinctive brand portfolio. In line with other MNOs in The Netherlands, we have been following value-based and more-for-more strategies that target different market segments with separate brands. Each of our four brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated profiles, as summarized in the following chart.
