Subsubsection Title: Well-positioned to benefit from market tailwinds for growth in market share, B2C revenue, customer satisfaction and ARPU
Subsubsection Text: Our status as a leading B2C mobile operator is confirmed by our market share as measured by our volume of subscribers and by our revenue. As of December 31, 2020, we have 42% of the B2C mobile postpaid market share by volume, which corresponds to 5.1 million SIMs. We have managed to reach our leading volume market share of 42% over the past three years, supported in part by the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, while the absolute number of subscribers grew at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2018 and 2020. At the same time, our market share by revenue increased from 33% to 40% over the same period. Our B2C mobile revenue growth in the past three years was mainly driven by stable ARPUs at brand levels and a growing subscriber base, driven by marketing strategies for our brands, our strong positioning in unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2, and an increase in demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel. We have also maintained growth in customer satisfaction, which has helped us retain customers. In the B2C mobile market, TMNL outpaced its competitors in The Netherlands by delivering the fastest-increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group which combines customer recommendation, customer likelihood to continue services, competitive advantage and performance. Our TRI*M score increased by over 50% over 12 years. We believe that an increase in customer satisfaction was one of the key factors driving the reduction in our B2C mobile churn to approximately 11% in 2020. We believe that our position as a leading B2C mobile operator with growing customer satisfaction metrics situates us well to take advantage of trends towards converged fixed and mobile offerings and more ----- for-more strategies, as it allows us a larger base of customers to cross-sell into FMC packages and to upsell into more premium offers. See “—World-class network and strong commercial execution” and “Industry—Dutch _Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market—Focus on fixed broadband market.” Already in the first three quarters_ of 2021, our ARPU has grown across all four of our brands, corresponding to increases of between €0.8 and €1.1 in the third quarter of 2021 in comparison with the first quarter of 2021. We expect to experience moderate growth in the future by building on our success in growing subscriber base and potential further ARPU growth.

Subsubsection Title: High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model
Subsubsection Text: We have a successful track record of M&A, synergy realization and cost optimization. This track record, combined with a lean, asset-light fixed business model has given us operating leverage and operational efficiency. In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s B2C fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which we shortly thereafter rebranded T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone’s divestiture of Vodafone Thuis was ordered by the European Commission as a remedy to provide competition clearance for VFZ, the joint venture between Vodafone and Ziggo. This acquisition marked the beginning of our present fixed internet business and added about 150,000 fixed-line customers. In January 2019, we completed our acquisition of Tele2. This acquisition has strengthened our position in the Dutch telecommunications market and allowed us to compete more effectively with KPN and VFZ by giving us enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources and significant synergy potential. We are executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have closed Tele2’s standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings. Based on our estimates, we anticipate realizing Tele2 cost-saving synergies with a total run-rate synergy potential of €130 million by 2024, of which we have already realized €115 million of synergies run-rate as of September 30, 2021. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, by then the largest MVNO in The Netherlands. By means of this transaction, we acquired one million additional B2C mobile postpaid customers who were already using our network under Simpel’s prior wholesale agreement with us. The acquisition of Simpel provide further synergy and cost savings potential to be realized in the total amount of approximately €9 million by 2024. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel entail for example related to reduced interconnect costs, migration of Tele2’s business support system (“BSS”) to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad debt collections (representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon integration with TMNL), direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and the cancellation of leased telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile cross-selling, optimization of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related costs as well as legal audit and tax fees. For risks related to our growth through acquisitions, see “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Acquisitions and other strategic transactions present many risks, including the risk that we may not be able to integrate newly acquired operations into our business, which may prevent us from realizing the strategic and financial goals contemplated at the time of any such transaction and thus adversely affect our business.”_ We believe that these strategic acquisitions, coupled with our rapid and successful organic growth initiatives, position us well to capture further market share and grow margins across the business segments in which we operate. Further, our lean and digital business model also allows us to benefit from strong operating leverage. Aside from the lean operating cost base described above, we have also repositioned ourselves to become a digital telecommunications company with an asset-light fixed model. On September 1, 2018, we demerged our tower business into Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra). Subsequently, on January 1, 2019, one day prior to the closing of the Tele2 acquisition, we distributed Cignal Infrastructure as a dividend in kind to Deutsche Telekom, with TMNL continuing to have full access to the contributed infrastructure through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP, which is a joint venture of Cellnex and DTCP. Currently, we benefit from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price Index. Additionally, we continue to hold our own market-leading mobile spectrum portfolio. ----- In our fixed segment we also have an asset-light model. Our partners, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, are conducting the roll-out of our FTTH network, and we do not have any direct fixed access network ownership. We expect to have access to the over one million FTTH homes that Open Dutch Fiber is scheduled to roll out to by 2025 in densely-populated areas with strong TMNL mobile customer presence. Under the Primvest partnership, we expect that we will have FTTH access to approximately 130,000 homes passed. By the terms of this partnership, we benefit from an initial period of exclusivity and line prices with base rates of not more than €15 per month, indexed to inflation and subject to certain adjustments. In both of these partnerships, we have agreed to certain utilization commitments. In addition, we have access to approximately two million homes passed on KPN’s Open Distribution Framework footprint which is completed by WBA for a nationwide fixed network footprint. Such a lean business model has allowed us to achieve total capital expenditure savings of over €700 million, estimated as savings as a result of us not having to allocate and devote capital expenditure on building a fiber network and mobile towers for five years.

Subsubsection Title: Strong cash flow profile with demonstrated resilience and strong cash generation
Subsubsection Text: We have historically demonstrated a track record of growth, profitability improvement and strong cash flow generation. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have been able to maintain growth and increase profitability, as evidenced by a 29.7% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin in 2020 in comparison to 26.7% in 2019. We believe this demonstrates the resilience of our business and of our company overall. In addition, we generated a 56% Cash Conversion in 2020 in comparison with an average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies. We delivered revenue growth in a challenging market environment between 2018 and 2020 at a 2% CAGR. Such growth was mainly driven by a growing subscriber base and stabilizing ARPU levels in the mobile B2C segment, as well as by strong growth in our B2C fixed business. Historically, our B2C mobile segment has been the major contributor to revenue at a 4% CAGR between 2018 and 2020, having accounted for 47% of total revenue in 2020. Our B2C mobile business delivered significant SIM net adds, particularly in the Simpel and Ben brands, and relatively stable ARPUs among those of our brands that offered the increasingly-popular unlimited data bundles. Positive developments offset a decrease in roaming revenue as a result of COVID-19– induced travelling restrictions. Our B2C fixed segment was our fastest-growing segment, growing at a CAGR of 11% over the past three years. We believe that this strong growth was driven by a successful FMC challenger strategy which resulted in strong growth in subscriber base that amounted to an additional 133,000 customers in the past three years. We also delivered strong performance in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, both in terms of margin expansion and growth. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin increased from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 and to 31.1% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL exhibited a strong CAGR of 16.1% between 2018 and 2020 due to an improved gross margin, declining indirect costs in absolute terms from cost saving programs and headcount reduction, and realization of Tele2 synergies. Because we delivered strong revenue and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL expansion through challenging market conditions, we believe that we are in a position of strength and greater scale to deliver incremental top line and profitability expansion as market conditions improve. We also benefit from a strong cash generation profile driven by a solid top-line performance that is combined with prudent cost management and moderate capital expenditure needs. Our Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow increased by 53% in 2020 compared to 2019, and is expected to continue on a growth trajectory going forward as we maintain our capital expenditure-light strategy. Our Cash Conversion was 56% in 2020 and it further increased to 58.9% during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, which is above the average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies. The below chart shows our resilience and strong cash flow profile by presenting certain business metrics for the periods under review, on a pro forma basis for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, the demerger of T-Infra and the application of IFRS 16, as applicable, in each case from January 1, 2018. For further information, see “Summary—Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial Information.” ----- _Source: Company information. Notes: (1) Pro forma service revenues per segment where B2C mobile only incudes postpaid subscriptions and B2B mobile excludes revenues from IT partners and Gamma Communications Nederland (formerly named Dean One), a reseller of our B2B services. (2) Booked capital expenditures excluding spectrum._

Subsubsection Title: Committed and experienced management team
Subsubsection Text: Our experienced management team is led by our CEO, Søren Abildgaard, and our CFO, Gero Niemeyer, each of whom has over 22 years of industry experience. Our management team is seasoned in running, acquiring and staffing telecommunications businesses and in navigating consumer markets both in The Netherlands and abroad, and they leverage the expertise they acquired over decades of combined experience at top-tier telecommunications and consultancy companies such as Telia, Orange, Magenta Telekom, KPN, Deloitte and Booz Allen Hamilton. More importantly, the management team has a strong track record of delivering growth from both organic initiatives and strategic acquisitions, and has won and maintained strong stakeholder support while maintaining a strong debt capital structure. This industry-leading management team is supported by a deep bench of divisional managers, who in turn are supported by a substantial workforce of 1,870 full-time equivalents as of September 30, 2021. Our employees, 48% of whom are customer-facing, are highly diverse, being represented by 45 distinct nationalities. Our management team has reached multiple milestones. Under our management’s leadership, revenue between 2018 and 2020 increased by a CAGR of 2% due to increasing B2C revenues, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin expanded from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 as driven by an improved cost structure and synergies from the Tele2 acquisition. Furthermore, the team has successfully repositioned our company as a full FMC challenger in addition to having executed the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions.

range of offerings at the low end _Source: Company Information._ Our strong commercial execution is supported by our multiple sales channels and highly optimized distribution network. We complement our in-store retail sales channel with an indirect sales channel that deploys more than 500 extra partner stores that we regard as vital to boost physical sales. On top of our brickand-mortar network, webshops for T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel serve as efficient and growing online ----- channels that are instrumental for the sales of the whole brand portfolio. Our direct and indirect online channels accounted for more than 60% of our B2C sales in 2020, which we regard as proof of our established and effective digital presence. Furthermore, customer service for Ben and T-Mobile has been voted the best in the Dutch telecommunications industry in 2021 as determined by a customer survey (Source: MarketResponse _customer survey). The quality of our customer service both in our physical locations and through our online_ presence has resulted both in continuous improvement of customer satisfaction and generation of FMC leads. The following chart summarizes key indicators of our status as the leading telecommunications operator in The Netherlands. _Source: Umlaut, Agentschap Telecom, Company information. Notes: (1) According to Umlaut. (2) Spectrum portfolios as of latest 5G auction in July 2020. (3) Average includes mobile operator network test from 2019 in Hungary and Slovakia, 2020 in Austria, Czech Republic, Finland, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Spain and Sweden, 2021 in Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Malta, Portugal and Romania. (4) Based on number of transactions, both gross adds and renewals._

Subsubsection Title: Leverage our leading position in B2C mobile and benefit from market tailwinds on 5G monetization, unlimited offerings, portfolio optimization and increased value-added services
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading B2C mobile operator with a SIM market share of 42% in the B2C mobile postpaid market, corresponding to 5.1 million SIMs as of December 31, 2020. B2C revenue growth resulted from stabilizing ARPUs in 2019 and 2020 as well as a growing subscriber base, further supported by growth in ----- unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2 as well as an increasing demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel. We have also seen continued growth in our customer satisfaction. For B2C mobile, we have delivered the fastest increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade, having outpaced our competitors in The Netherlands. Our leading market position provides a strong platform for growth both in terms of volume and value across all brands and segments. In particular, we plan to grow ARPU through (i) 5G monetization, (ii) unlimited growth, (iii) portfolio optimizations, (iv) value-added services and (v) FMC growth. _Drive 5G monetization_ We were the first operator to reach nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band in 2020, and we believe that we are well positioned to monetize our 5G investments. We offer 5G connectivity per default to our premium offerings, such as T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan,’ or as an add-on to our value offerings, such as a €2 p.c.m. add-on for our Tele2 customers. In the future, we plan to extend our 5G offering and continue our more-for-more portfolio approach on the back of 5G. _Grow unlimited offerings_ We believe that we hold a leading position in unlimited offerings based on our number of subscribers and on our having been the first to have introduced an unlimited plan for mobile in The Netherlands. Our premium offers in the mobile segment are unlimited plans, which we sell for €35 p.c.m. and €25 p.c.m., including value added tax (“VAT”), through the T-Mobile and Tele2 brands respectively. T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan’ also includes 5G connectivity by default. Having introduced these offerings in 2017, our unlimited subscriber base grew from 578,000 subscribers in December 2018 to more than a million subscribers in June 2021. In May 2021, we also introduced an ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ plan including access to Netflix and Videoland, a Dutch streaming service. We intend to continue to grow our unlimited offerings in the future as we believe that unlimited plans are a key value driver in our premium portfolio by increasing customer loyalty and customer satisfaction, and ultimately result in above-average monthly recurring charges (“MRC”). _Portfolio optimizations_ Our multi-brand portfolio is a key value driver that allows us to effectively compete in all market segments. All our brands have a distinctive positioning, minimizing the risk of intra-brand competition. With approximately 100,000 intra-brand migrations in 2020, creating an average incremental MRC of €1, we have proven the ability to upsell to customers within our portfolio, accruing value. _Value-added services_ We believe that by offering value-added services (“VAS”), we distinguish ourselves from our competitors while increasing ARPU, customer loyalty and customer satisfaction. Our new ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ package, described above, is one such example. In addition, T-Mobile offers security options and add-ons from the music streaming service Deezer. On Tele2, we recently introduced ‘Unlimited for a day’ and ‘Unlimited weekend’ plans which add VAS to a Tele2 portfolio that already includes, among other things, a 5G priced add-on. _FMC growth_ Compared to KPN and VFZ, who have mobile FMC penetrations of 65% and 71% as of December 31, 2020, we believe that our FMC penetration of 8% as of December 31, 2020 provides us with ample opportunity for growth. While KPN and VFZ leverage their large fixed bases, we intend to focus on crossselling our fixed offerings into our leading consumer mobile base. Since FMC customers are more loyal, more satisfied and have higher monthly bill sizes compared to one-product customers, we expect FMC growth to be attractive, both, in terms of volume and value. -----

Subsubsection Title: Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus
Subsubsection Text: We are a successful challenger in the B2C fixed market with approximately 9% market share by subscribers in 2020. In the past three years, as our business has grown its subscriber base and revenue at a CAGR of approximately 11%, marking the fastest growth among our competitors, our market share has grown from 7% in 2018 to 9% in 2020 and our share of total subscriber gross adds has grown from 17% in 2018 to 20% in 2020. We believe that we have been able to deliver this rapid, market-leading growth by leveraging our challenger strategy and B2C fixed ARPUs below those of our competition, as our fixed ARPU was approximately €33 for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, compared to the market average of approximately €50. Our price leadership is evidenced by our FMC offer which combines 1 Gbit internet speeds and a T-Mobile Unlimited subscription for a price of €50 p.m. (€25 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile subscription), compared to €90 p.m. at KPN (€65 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile) and €93 p.m. at VFZ (€65.5 p.m. internet + €27.5 p.m. mobile). These consumer bundle prices are excluding promotions. We believe this lower fixed-segment ARPU and challenger strategy represents a strong lever to continue attracting valueseeking customers. As illustrated in the chart below, we are able to offer fixed and mobile services at a significantly lower price than our competitors. We have an FTTH footprint that covers approximately 1.6 million homes passed on KPN’s and Primevest’s networks. FTTH is also achieved through the Magenta footprint. We expect a further increase of approximately 500,000 homes passed by the end of 2021 and the Magenta footprint is expected to significantly increase homes passed by 2025. Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest partnerships are also key pillars of this strategy. We have secured exclusive agreements with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in addition to benefitting from non-exclusive ODF wholesale access to the KPN network, complemented by nationwide wholesale access via KPN bitstream. For more about our partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, see “—Our _Competitive Strengths—High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model.” We believe that our_ partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in particular will allow us to grow our fixed subscriber base and drive margin expansion while maintaining healthy cash profile through our capital expenditure-light strategy. In the future, we plan to increase our revenue share through share gains at competitive ARPUs. First, we plan to tap our mobile subscriber base, which is the largest in The Netherlands, to cross-sell our fixed offerings to our mobile customers. In our T-Mobile brand, FMC penetration rose from 4% in 2018 to 20% in 2020, whereas overall for our company, FMC penetration increased from 2% in 2018 to 8% in 2020. However, our FMC penetration remains well below the FMC penetration of our competitors. We believe our penetration will grow in the future both as a result of a focused sales approach and because we expect more SIMs to become FMC-eligible in 2021-2022. Planned quality improvements will also help grow and maintain our fixed base through increased customer satisfaction and loyalty. Second, we will rely on highly-competitive ARPU levels to further drive market share gains. Going forward, we are considering shifting towards a value-based proposition by focusing on high-end fiber speeds and value-added services. -----

Subsubsection Title: Exploit untapped B2B value pools and expand in fixed
Subsubsection Text: We have established a presence in the B2B market across all segments, namely SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE, both with our mobile and our fixed offerings which represent 71% and 29%, respectively, of our B2B revenue in 2020. Our presence extends across all B2B customer segments with our largest exposure in the SOHO/VSE and LE/CE segments at 36% of B2B mobile service revenues each, followed by the SMB segment with a 25% revenue share (Source: Company information). We have increased our revenue market share in the mobile B2B market from 17% in 2018 to 20% in 2020. For the past three years, we have the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator as measured by SIM net adds, having earned a 43% SIM net adds share in 2020 in comparison with 31% for the closest competitor. We believe this strategy highlights our success in attracting B2B mobile customers and managing churn well, and we believe it will fuel our growth in the coming years. In the fixed B2B market, we had a modest revenue market share of 4% in 2020, affording us an opportunity to grow our presence in the segment in 2021 and beyond. Among our key priorities, we aim to transform the former Tele2 large enterprise legacy business and expand into SOHO/VSE with fixed offerings. Recognizing the above growth path in B2B mobile and the opportunity in B2B fixed, we have defined a strategy to develop our potential in each of our SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE B2B segments. Our entrepreneurial approach is built on four key growth drivers, namely (i) FMC offerings in the SOHO/VSE segment, (ii) an SMB portfolio that combines FMC offerings (a “converged” portfolio) with cloud-based service enhancements, (iii) a differentiating partner approach and (iv) fixed transformation in the LE/CE segment. _FMC offerings in the attractive SOHO/VSE segment_ The SOHO/VSE segment is a highly attractive market for our services, both because of its higher margins and because we believe we are well-positioned to succeed in this space as a result of its similarities with the B2C segment where we are a leader in mobile. This segment has rarely been tapped by either T-Mobile or Tele2 before and it is growing in line with the B2C market. See “—Our Competitive Strengths—Attractive _telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands.” Given our strength in mobile offerings in particular,_ we intend to target the SOHO/VSE segment by relying on FMC offerings. For example, in September 2021, we launched a VSE internet offering and related FMC bundling proposition in order to provide the best value for money, thus opening an additional market segment for us and a potential source of incremental revenue. _FMC and cloud-enhanced SMB portfolio along with differentiating partnering approach_ We operate in the SMB segment under the T-Mobile and selectively under the Tele2 brand for larger SMB customers. Our SMB offering comprises a product portfolio focused on FMC and cloud-enhanced solutions. In the SOHO/VSE segment, we strive for an increase of our Unlimited attach rate as a key value driver. In addition, we believe that our SMB FMC seats will increase, driven by, among other things, a Microsoft Teams integration that forms a unified communications solution which we were the first to launch in the Dutch market. We have a large mobile customer base and, as in the consumer market, we intend to upsell fixed and unified communications services to our mobile base. In addition to our core connectivity services, we sell a broad range of communications and cloud-based solutions tailored to the customers’ needs through our extensive partner portfolio. See also “—Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus” above. _Fixed transformation in LE/CE_ In the LE/CE segment, we are conducting a transformation of our fixed services in order to realize the full potential of our extended portfolio. We are in the process of a transition from Tele2 legacy fixed infrastructure to future-proof transactional stacks in order to accommodate changing customer demands that request faster and more reliable connections and thus are switching to future-proof fiber-based technologies which includes a shift from copper to fiber, from VPN to SDWAN and a phase-out of ISDN. We also intend to supplement our stable fixed wholesale business with international carriers and Internet Service Providers by wholeselling active services in ODF areas. -----

Subsubsection Title: Optimize our indirect cost base ratio
Subsubsection Text: We have an asset-light fixed model and have been focused on creating a lean operational setup since 2016 when we completed a reorganization under the name ‘Lean Telco’ with a headcount reduction of certain full-time equivalents and a savings target of €30 million. We further streamlined our business with a “3F – Fit For Future” initiative in 2018-2019, having achieved our further cost savings target of €100 million during the two year period 2018-2019. The focus in the coming years will be on optimization of our indirect cost base (“IDC”) ratio through: - _Focusing on smart growth by transforming remaining legacy architecture, digitizing processes towards self-service, improving fixed product quality and transforming the OSS while focusing on high-margin segments, thereby increasing our scale; - _Countering inflation with efficiencies by investing in marketing automation, robotic process automation and first-time right focus to deliver efficiency gains as they increase productivity; and - _Continuing to optimize costs by investing in systems and process improvements.

Subsubsection Title: Build on our ESG commitments
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several initiatives in order to improve our impact on the environment and society. We intend to build on our past ESG successes with a four-pillar ESG program. Our first pillar is sustainability. In 2020, we already used 100% green electricity and produced 60,000 kWh of renewable energy by using our own solar panels. In 2021, we introduced eco-plastic, E-SIMs and lighter packaging. Additionally, we have targeted a reduction to carbon neutral emission level by 2026. Furthermore, we will reduce new plastic packaging to zero by 2026. We continue to be involved in our community in other ways, such as our establishment of two partnerships to accelerate “Innovation for Society” projects in 2020. For 2021 and 2022, we aim to set up three impactful “Innovation for Society” partnerships to invest in e-health, education and smart cities. Going forward, we intend to continue setting up three partnerships a year. We also focus on digital inclusion, as our goal is to enable more people to be part of the digital society. In 2020, more than 2,500 people gained access to the digital society with our social SIM program and we reached more than 15,000 people through our debt prevention program. Our target is to reach more than 25,000 disadvantaged individuals every year. Lastly, our management aims to foster an environment in which everyone feels included. We have set up a dedicated work stream in the diversity and inclusion program focused on activities and awareness within the company, sharpened our policy on social return and set up a “Back to work” fund. For 2021 and 2022, our focus is on diversity and inclusion, such as through setting up gender-neutral communication and starting the dialogue on safety and belonging. Our goal is to be a 100% inclusive organization by 2025. ----- _Notes: (1) Sustainable Development Goals of United Nations, of which there are 17 in total_

We have detailed commercial plans to support our further growth, both in terms of volume and of value, for all brands and segments. In particular, we have identified a number of key drivers leading to growth in our business which we believe will preserve our leadership position in the future, namely (i) leverage our leading position in the B2C mobile market, (ii) capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus, (iii) exploitation of untapped B2B value pools and expansion in fixed and (iv) optimization of our indirect cost base ratio, with (v) a commitment to ESG initiatives.

Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: On September 6, 2021, funds advised by Apax and Warburg Pincus, which together control the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, announced their intention to acquire the Target from its current shareholders, Deutsche Telekom, the holder of 75.0% of the share capital of TMNL and Tele2 Sweden (together with Deutsche Telekom, the “Existing Shareholders”), the holder of 25.0% of the share capital of TMNL. In this regard, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into a sale and purchase agreement dated September 6, 2021 with the Existing Shareholders and the Target (the “Acquisition Agreement”), pursuant to which, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer agreed to acquire the entire issued share capital of the Target. Under the Acquisition Agreement, the aggregate consideration payable by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer at Completion Date, consists of €3,713.5 million plus €700,000 per calendar day from November 1, 2021 until the earlier of (i) the Completion Date or (ii) the date falling 15 business days after the date on which the last completion condition under the Acquisition Agreement has been satisfied or waived, to compensate the Existing Shareholders for additional cash generation in the Target Group during this time period. The purchase price will be adjusted for a leakage amount, which consists of €24.0 million as re-branding costs plus the sum of any specified item resulting in leakage of value, for example, any distribution by the Target Group to any of the Existing Shareholders or certain affiliates parties and any payments made or amounts payable under the SAR schemes instituted by the Target, in each case, during the period from July 1, 2021 until the date of transfer of the shares of the Target to Senior Secured Issuer (together, the “Leakage”). In addition, the Acquisition Agreement also specifies the manner in which the acquisition consideration payable by the Senior Secured Issuer is to be split between the Existing Shareholders. Under the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including appropriate clearance from the antitrust and other regulatory authorities and the satisfaction of relevant procedures with the Target’s works council. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, a number of these closing conditions have been satisfied, and among key conditions, clearance from the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy under the Dutch Telecommunication Act. Depending on the timing of the satisfaction of the remaining closing conditions, we currently expect to complete the Acquisition by January 2022. Under the Acquisition Agreement, (i) in the event that the Completion Date does not take place by March 6, 2022, each of Deutsche Telekom and Tele2 Sweden (as Existing Shareholders and sellers under the Acquisition Agreement) will have the right to terminate the Acquisition Agreement and (ii) in the event that the Completion Date does not take place by July 6, 2022, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (as the purchaser) will have the right to terminate the Acquisition Agreement. The total consideration for the Acquisition due on the Completion Date, is expected to be financed on such date using a portion of: - the Shareholder Contribution of an estimated amount of €1,090.0 million; - the TLB drawn under the Senior Facilities Agreement; and - the offering of the Notes. ----- Prior to the Completion Date, the Issuers will not have any control over the Target Group. In addition, prior to the completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group will not be subject to the covenants described in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and the “Description of the Senior Notes.”

Subsubsection Title: Sources and Uses
Subsubsection Text: We expect to receive gross proceeds of €1,350.0 million from the offering of the Notes, assuming an issuance at par. The proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with borrowings under the TLB and the Shareholder Contribution from the Sponsors, will be used to (a) make payments under the Acquisition Agreement (including the acquisition consideration and funds for refinancing the Existing Target Group Facilities) and (b) pay certain costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection the Transactions, including the offering of the Notes. The following table illustrates the estimated sources and uses of proceeds in connection with the Acquisition and the other Transactions. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the exact Completion Date, actual amount of cash at the Target on Completion Date, any Leakages as described under “—The Acquisition,” and the difference between the estimated and actual fees and expenses.

The Transactions consist of the following (collectively, the “Transactions”): - the issuance by the Issuers of the Notes offered hereby and the use of proceeds therefrom; - the execution, delivery and performance of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the use of proceeds from any borrowing thereunder; - an equity contribution for an estimated amount of €1,090.0 million from the Sponsors to finance the acquisition of the Target on or about the Completion Date (the “Shareholder Contribution”); - the completion of the Acquisition; - the refinancing and cancellation of the Existing Target Group Facilities; - the payment of costs, fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions, including the costs, fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the offering of Notes; and - any other transactions in connection with any of the above or incidental thereto. For a description of the anticipated indebtedness of the Group following the Transactions, see “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” Concurrently with the closing of the offering of the Notes on the Issue Date, the Issuers will deposit the gross proceeds of the offering into the Escrow Accounts, to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. On or about the Issue Date, the Issuers will assign as security its beneficial interest in the Escrow Accounts and Escrowed Properties to the Trustee. The release of the funds credited to the Deposit Accounts and the consummation of the Acquisition will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. In the event that, (i) the Completion Date does not take place on or prior to the Longstop Date, (ii) in the good faith judgment of the Issuers, the Acquisition will not be consummated on or prior to the Longstop Date, (iii) the Acquisition Agreement is terminated at any time on or prior to the Longstop Date, or (iv) certain other events occur, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such Notes, plus accrued but unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date to (but not including) the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein) (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date). See “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Deposit of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Deposit of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”_ ----- In the event of a special mandatory redemption, WP/AP Telecom Holdings II B.V., the holding company of the Senior Notes Issuer, will commit to fund the Issuers in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Accounts fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balance and costs, accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date pursuant to an equity commitment delivered to the Issuers by WP/AP Telecom Holdings II B.V. (the “Equity Commitment”). The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ sole right to enforcement under the Equity Commitment. See “Risk Factors—Risk Factors relating to the Acquisition—The _Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, on or prior to the Longstop Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.”_

(1) Represents the gross proceeds of the Notes expected to be issued pursuant to the Offering on the Issue Date, assuming an issuance at par. (2) Represents the borrowing under the TLB provided for under the Senior Facilities Agreement. In connection with the Transactions, the Parent has entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement, which provides for a TLB of €2,400 million and revolving facilities consisting of the €500 million RCF1 and the €200 million RCF2. On or about the Completion Date, the TLB is expected to be drawn in full, and along with the proceeds from the Notes and the Shareholder Contribution, utilized as set forth above. RCF1 and RCF2 are expected to remain undrawn as of the Completion Date. See also “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_ (3) Represents approximately €1,090.0 million in aggregate amount of estimated common equity directly or indirectly to be contributed to the Parent in connection with the Acquisition by the Sponsors. (4) Represents the sum of the following amounts: - €3,713.5 million, which is the amount payable to the sellers as consideration under the Acquisition Agreement. The Acquisition consideration, which is payable on the Completion Date, is subject to adjustments in respect of any Leakage, as further described under “Summary—The Transactions—The Acquisition.” The amount also excludes any consideration that is payable in respect of the Acquisition at a daily rate of €700,000 from November 1, 2021 until the Completion Date to compensate the Sellers for additional cash generation in the Target Group during this period. - €980.3 million, which is calculated as the aggregate principal amount of the Existing Target Group Facilities which is to be repaid on or about the Completion Date, net of anticipated use of cash and cash equivalents with the Target Group on the Completion Date for such repayment. The amounts in respect of the Existing Target Group Facilities shown above, do not include accrued but unpaid interest and any breakage cost in relation to these facilities. See also “Capitalization.” (5) Represents certain estimated costs, fees and expenses associated with the Transactions, including underwriting and financing fees, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction costs and professional fees. The actual amount of the costs, fees and expenses may differ from the estimated amount depending on several factors, including differences between our estimates of costs, fees and expenses and the actual costs, fees and expenses as of the completion of this offering and the Acquisition.

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer, WP/AP Telecom Holdings IV B.V., was incorporated as a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) under the laws of The ----- Netherlands on July 20, 2021 in contemplation of the Transactions. The registered office of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Strawinskylaan 3051, 1077 ZX Amsterdam, The Netherlands. The Senior Notes Issuer, WP/AP Telecom Holdings III B.V., was incorporated as a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) under the laws of The Netherlands on July 20, 2021 in contemplation of the Transactions. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer. The registered office of the Senior Notes Issuer is Strawinskylaan 3051, 1077 ZX Amsterdam, The Netherlands.

Subsubsection Title: Apax
Subsubsection Text: Apax is a leading global private equity advisory firm. Over its 50-year history, Apax has raised and advised funds with aggregate commitments of over $60 billion. Apax invests in companies across four global sectors of Healthcare, Technology, Services and Internet/Consumer. These funds provide long-term equity financing to build and strengthen world-class companies through leveraging its deep sector and sub-sector experience, operating capabilities, and global platform. Some of Apax’s investments in the telecommunications and allied sectors include, Inmarsat, Orange Switzerland, TDC, Wind Telecom, Mobifon, TIM Hellas, Kabel Deutschland, Bezeq, Versatel.

Subsubsection Title: Warburg Pincus
Subsubsection Text: Warburg Pincus is a leading global growth investor and is an experienced partner to management teams seeking to build durable companies with sustainable value. Founded in 1966, it has invested more than $97 billion in over 960 companies across 40 countries, as of September 30, 2021. In particular, Warburg Pincus has, over the years, invested over $3.3 billion of equity in the communication and media sector as of September 30, 2021 and possesses direct knowledge of the telecommunications industry’s end markets and customers through its investments in other telecommunications companies. Some of Warburg Pincus’ investments in the telecommunications and allied sectors include Inmarsat, Community Fibre, Ziggo, Airtel, United Internet, IONOS by 1&1, Converge, INEA, inexio, Bharti and Amercia Net. -----

The following chart shows a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure on the Completion Date after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, including the use of proceeds thereof. See “—The Transactions,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes,” “Description of the Senior Notes,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements,” “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” Unless otherwise indicated, entities shown in the chart are wholly owned. (1) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, funds managed or advised by Apax and Warburg Pincus, each own 50% of the beneficial ownership and voting rights of WP/AP Telecom Holdings I B.V. and jointly control this entity. WP/AP Telecom Holdings I B.V. is an indirect holding company of the Parent and holds its entire beneficial ownership and voting rights. Funds managed or advised by Apax and Warburg Pincus by way of the Shareholder Contribution, are expected to provide an estimated aggregate amount of €1,090 million to the Target. In addition, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, it is expected that senior management of the Target Group will reinvest in WP/AP Telecom Holdings I B.V. in connection with the Acquisition. The exact nature of the management incentive plan for the Target’s reinvesting management is still being determined. (2) The entities in the “Restricted Group” are subject to the covenants in the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Indentures. (3) Comprises €550,000,000 aggregate principal amount of    % Senior Notes due 2029. The Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all other existing and future senior debt of the Senior Notes Issuer. We intend to use the gross proceeds of the Offering, together with the borrowings under the TLB and the Shareholder Contribution, (a) to make payments under the Acquisition Agreement (including the acquisition consideration and funds for refinancing the Existing Target Group Facilities) and (b) pay certain costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection the Transactions, including the offering of the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds.” Concurrently with the closing of the offering of the Senior Notes on the Issue Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the offering of the Senior Notes into the SN Escrow Account, which is segregated and controlled by the Senior Notes Issuer to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will assign as security its beneficial interest in the SN Escrow Account and the SN Escrowed Property to the Senior Notes Trustee. See “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to the Acquisition—The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions _and risks and, if it is not consummated, on or prior to the Longstop Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.”_ The Senior Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer secured on a limited basis as set forth under “—The Offering— _Collateral,” rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Notes Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated_ ----- in right of payment to the Senior Notes, including the Senior Notes Issuer’s obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Facilities Agreement, rank senior in right of payment to all of the Senior Notes Issuer’s future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes, be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that are secured by liens ranking ahead of the liens securing the Senior Notes or secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Notes, including the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Facilities Agreement, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness or obligation and be structurally subordinated to any future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Notes Issuer (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Senior Notes. (4) Comprises €800,000,000 aggregate principal amount of    % Senior Secured Notes due 2028. The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all other existing and future senior debt of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. We intend to use the gross proceeds of the Offering, together with the borrowings under the TLB and the Shareholder Contribution, to (a) make payments under the Acquisition Agreement (including the acquisition consideration and funds for refinancing the Existing Target Group Facilities) and (b) pay certain costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection the Transactions, including the offering of the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds.” Concurrently with the closing of the offering of the Senior Secured Notes on the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the offering of the Senior Secured Notes into the SSN Escrow Account, which is segregated and controlled by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will assign as security its beneficial interest in the SSN Escrow Account and the SSN Escrowed Property to the Senior Secured Notes Trustee. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Acquisition—The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not _consummated, on or prior to the Longstop Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.”_ The Senior Secured Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations in respect of the Senior Facilities Agreement, rank senior in right of payment to all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations in respect of the Senior Notes, be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that is secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such obligation or indebtedness, and be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Notes Issuer (including obligations to trade creditors), other than the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes. (5) On September 16, 2021, the Senior Notes Issuer entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement (as amended and restated on October 18, 2021 and on November 25, 2021), which provides for the TLB of €2.40 billion to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as original borrower and the RCF comprising of RCF1 of €500 million and RCF2 of €200 million to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as original borrower. For a description of the Senior Facilities Agreement, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior _Facilities Agreement.” As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the RCF, consisting of RCF1 and RCF2 was undrawn and we_ expect they will remain undrawn as of the Issue Date. (6) On the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Parent Guarantor. In addition, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Completion Date and in any event within the date that is 150 days after the Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis, by the Target Guarantors. See “—The Offering—Guarantees.” On the Issue Date, subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles and the applicable perfection requirements, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured on an equal and ratable first-priority basis by an English law escrow account pledge over the SSN Escrow Account in respect of the Senior Secured Notes. On or around the Completion Date, this security will be released and the Senior Secured Notes will be, secured on a first-priority basis by the Initial Collateral (as defined herein), and, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Completion Date and in any event within 150 days after the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Target Collateral (as defined herein). See “—The Offering—Collateral.” On the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis, by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. In addition, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Completion Date and in any event within the date that is 150 days after the Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis, by the Target Guarantors. See “—The Offering—Guarantees.” On the Issue Date, subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles and the applicable perfection requirements, the Senior Notes will be secured on an equal and ratable first-priority basis by an English law escrow account pledge over the SN Escrow Account in respect of the Senior Notes. On or around the Completion Date, this security will be released and the Senior Notes will be, secured on a first-priority basis by the Shared Collateral (as defined herein). See “—The Offering—Collateral.” The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to the limitations described under “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on Notes Guarantees and _Security,” “—The Offering—Guarantees,” “—The Offering—Collateral” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes—The Notes are secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral that has been granted or will be granted as security for the Notes and the Guarantees, and such security may not be sufficient to satisfy the obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.” By virtue of such limitations, the Guarantors’ obligations_ under the Notes Guarantees or the amounts secured by the Collateral will be significantly less than the total amounts payable with respect to the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes, as the case may be, or could be declared null or rescinded in certain circumstances. (7) Upon the release of the Senior Notes proceeds from the relevant Escrow Account, the Senior Notes Issuer will on-lend the gross proceeds of the Senior Notes to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, pursuant to a Senior Notes Issuer Proceeds Loan. Similarly, upon the release of the Senior Secured Notes proceeds from the relevant Escrow Account, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-lend to the Target and/or other members of the Target Group a portion of (i) the gross proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes and (ii) the proceeds from Senior Notes Issuer Proceeds Loan, which together, among others, are expected to be utilized to refinance and cancel ----- the Existing Target Group Indebtedness and associated fees and expenses, pursuant to a Senior Secured Notes Issuer Proceeds Loan. See “Use of Proceeds.” (8) For the year ended December 31, 2020, on an unconsolidated basis and without giving effect to intercompany eliminations and other adjustments in relation to consolidation, the Target Guarantors (expected to be the Target and T-Mobile Netherlands) represented (i) 92.1% of the Target Group’s net revenue and (ii) 94.3% of the Target Group’s EBITDA. For the nine months ended September 30, 2021, on an unconsolidated basis and without giving effect to intercompany eliminations and other adjustments in relation to consolidation, the Target Guarantors represented (i) 90.3% of the Target Group’s net revenue, and (ii) 103.0% of the Target’s Group EBITDA, which is higher than the consolidated EBITDA of the Target Group for nine months ended September 30, 2021, primarily due to negative EBITDA of some of non-Target Guarantor entities for this period. As of December 31, 2020 and September 30, 2021, after giving effect to intercompany eliminations attributable to share capital but not to other adjustments in relation to consolidation, the Target Guarantors represented 117.0% and 130.0%, respectively, of the Target Group’s total assets, which are higher than the consolidated total assets of the Target Group for the relevant periods due to the negative value of total assets at some of the nonTarget Guarantor entities as a result of operational intercompany position of these entities with the Target Guarantors, whereby, prior to consolidation, their liabilities exceed their assets. (9) Not all of the subsidiaries of the Group will guarantee the Notes. As of September 30, 2021, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, the subsidiaries that are not expected to guarantee the Notes would have no third party financial debt outstanding. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the _liabilities of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.”_ -----

Collateral in respect of the Senior Secured Notes .................................. On the Issue Date, subject to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, any limitations set out in the Security Documents, the applicable perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens, the Senior Secured Notes will be, secured on an equal and ratable first-priority basis by an English law escrow account pledge over the SSN Escrow Account. On or around the Completion Date, the bank account pledge over the SSN Escrow Account will be released and replaced by: - a Dutch law share pledge over the shares in the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; - a Dutch law bank account pledge over any material operating bank accounts of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; and - a Dutch law pledge over any material structural loan receivables owed to the Parent by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (such items collectively, the “Initial Collateral”). In addition, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Completion Date and in any event within 150 days from the Completion Date, subject to the Intercreditor Agreement and to the Agreed Security Principles, the applicable perfection requirements and Permitted Collateral Liens, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will be secured on an equal and ratable first-priority basis by the following security agreements: - a Dutch law share pledge over the shares in the Target (subject to the Security Agent and each other finance party taking all action that is required to ensure that such security can be granted by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in that time period); - in the case of each Target Guarantor incorporated in The Netherlands, (a) security over any shares held by it in another Guarantor; (b) any material operating bank accounts held by such Target Guarantor and (c) security over any material structural intercompany loans made by it to another Guarantor; and - in the case of any Target Guarantor that is incorporated in a jurisdiction that is not The Netherlands but is designated a “Security Jurisdiction” for the purposes of the Senior Facilities Agreement (a “Security Jurisdiction”), security over any shares held by it in another Guarantor (the “Post**Closing Target Collateral” and together with the Initial Collateral and any additional assets that may from time to time be subject to security in favor of the Senior Secured Notes pursuant to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the “Collateral”). ----- Collateral in respect of the Senior Notes................................................ Limitations in respect of the Collateral ......................................... The Collateral will also secure the senior secured guarantee given by the Issuers and the Guarantors’ obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, certain hedging obligations and certain other future indebtedness permitted to be incurred and secured. On the Issue Date, subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles, the applicable perfection requirements and Permitted Collateral Liens, the Senior Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by an English law escrow account pledge over the SN Escrow Account. On or around the Completion Date, the bank account pledge over the SN Escrow Account will be released and replaced by: - a Dutch law share pledge over the shares in the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; and - a Dutch law pledge over any material structural loan receivables owed to the Parent by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (such items collectively, together with any additional assets that may from time to time be subject to security in favor of the Senior Notes pursuant to the terms of the Senior Notes Indenture, the “Shared

All Shared Collateral shall be subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles, the applicable perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens. The Shared Collateral will also secure the liabilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes, and potentially other future Indebtedness, on a firstranking basis, ahead of any claims of the Senior Notes. Pursuant to the distribution waterfall provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement, upon an enforcement of the Shared Collateral, the proceeds thereof will be distributed to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes, the creditors under the Senior Facilities Agreement and other senior secured creditors ahead of the holders of the Senior Notes. Moreover, the Senior Notes Indenture will allow us to incur additional secured debt that pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement may rank senior to the Senior Notes but junior to our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Risks Relating to the Senior Notes—Pursuant to the distribution waterfall provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Shared Collateral will secure the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement on a first priority basis, and will secure the Senior Notes and the Senior Notes Guarantees on a junior priority basis and, as such, the rights of the holders of the Senior Notes to recover on such Shared Collateral will be limited.”_ The security over the Collateral, including the Shared Collateral, will be limited as necessary to recognize certain limitations arising under or imposed by local law and defenses generally available to providers of collateral (including those that relate to fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, financial assistance, corporate purpose or benefit, capital maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses ----- affecting the rights of creditors generally) or other considerations under applicable law. In addition, the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. Subject to the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Security.” See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes—Each Guarantee is subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability.”_ Intercreditor Agreement ...............** The Notes, the related Notes Guarantees, the Collateral and the Shared Collateral will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor _Agreement.”_ Use of Proceeds ..............................** The proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with borrowings under the TLB and the Shareholder Contribution from the Sponsors, will be used to (a) make payments under the Acquisition Agreement (including the acquisition consideration and funds for refinancing the Existing Target Group Facilities) and (b) pay certain costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection the Transactions, including the offering of the Notes.

A change of control triggering event, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net senior secured leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. A change of control triggering event, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event.

Subsection Title: Deposit of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes ...................... Concurrently with the closing of the Offering on the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes into the SSN Escrow Account, to hold such amount pending the completion of the Acquisition. On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will assign as security its beneficial interest in the SSN Escrow Account and SSN Escrowed ----- Property to the Trustee. The release of the funds credited to the SSN Escrow Account and the completion of the Acquisition will be subject to the will be subject to the good-faith determination by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer of the satisfaction of certain conditions, and such release will occur as soon as reasonably practicable following such determination (the date of such determination of the conditions, the “Release Date”). In the event that, (i) the completion date of the Acquisition (the “Completion Date”) does not take place on or prior to July 10, 2022 (the “Longstop Date”), (ii) in the good faith judgment of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Acquisition will not be consummated on or prior to the Longstop Date, (iii) the Acquisition Agreement is terminated at any time on or prior to the Longstop Date, or (iv) certain other events occur, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will redeem the Senior Secured Notes at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such Senior Secured Notes, plus accrued but unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date to (but not including) the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date). See “Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Deposit of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Acquisition— The Acquisition is subject to significant uncertainties and risks and, if it is not completed on or prior to the Longstop Date, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes at 100% of the initial issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.”_ On or prior to the closing of the Offering on the Issue Date, certain affiliates of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will enter into a commitment to fund the accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, Escrow Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow account balance and cost, owing to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption Price exceeds the amount of funds in the SSN Escrow Account. On or about the Release Date, the deposited funds may be released to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and utilized as described in “Use of _Proceeds” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Deposit of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and the SSN Escrow_ Charges will be released. If either Issuer or any Guarantor is required by law to withhold or deduct for such taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction with respect to a payment to the holders of Notes, such Issuer or Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amounts received by the holders of Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Withholding Taxes.” Certain Covenants .........................** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Notes Indenture will limit, among others, the ability of the Parent and its subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase its capital stock; - make certain restricted payments; - make certain investments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of its subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the Parent; - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain asset sales; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes, as applicable; and - guarantee certain indebtedness. Each of these covenants will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants.”_ Certain of the covenants and events of default will be suspended if and for as long as, and the security interests in respect of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and in respect of the Shared Collateral securing the Senior Notes will be released if, we achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status” and “Description of the Senior Notes—_ ----- _Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_ Transfer Restrictions.....................** The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transfer and may only be offered or sold in the United States in compliance with Rule 144A and outside the United States to non-U.S. Persons in reliance on Regulation S or in transactions that are exempt from or are not subject to the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions” and “Plan of Distribution.” No Prior Market for the Notes .....** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be maintained. Listing and Trading .......................** Application will be made to list the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange and to admit the Notes to trading on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted, or that such listing will be maintained.

Additional Senior Secured Notes .... Subject to compliance with the covenants, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be permitted to issue additional Senior Secured Notes (“Additional Senior Secured Notes”), without notice to or the consent of holders of Senior Secured Notes, which shall have terms substantially identical to the Senior Secured Notes except in respect of specified terms. Such Additional Senior Secured Notes will be treated, along with all other Senior Secured Notes, as a single class for the purposes of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture with respect to waivers, amendments and all other matters which are not specifically distinguished for such series. For all purposes other than United States federal income tax purposes, Additional Senior Secured Notes shall be deemed to form one series with any Senior Secured Notes previously issued if they have terms substantially identical in all material respects to such other Senior Secured Notes. Additional Senior Secured Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may at the option of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Senior Secured Notes belonging to the same series previously issued without being fungible with such series of initial Senior Secured Notes for United States federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined in “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States _Federal Income Tax Considerations”) considering the purchase of_ Senior Secured Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S as part of this offering of Senior Secured Notes or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular United States federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such Senior Secured Notes, including with respect to the potential issuance of Additional Senior Secured Notes that are not fungible with the applicable series of initial Senior ----- Secured Notes for United States federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being separately identified. In the event Additional Senior Secured Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Senior Secured Notes belonging to the same series previously issued, without being fungible with such series of initial Senior Secured Notes for United States federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Senior Secured Notes that form part of that series, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests (as defined herein) in the Regulation S Global Senior Secured Notes (as defined herein) on or prior to the date of issuance of such Additional Senior Secured Notes, will not be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a 144A Global Senior Secured Note (as defined herein) (if any) representing Senior Secured Notes of that same series. Such a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Senior Secured Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes—Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with existing Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for United States federal income tax purposes,” “Book- Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Additional Notes.”_ Senior Notes .................................... Subject to compliance with the covenants, the Senior Notes Issuer will be permitted to issue additional Senior Notes (“Additional Senior

Subsection Title: Notes”), without notice to or the consent of holders of Senior Notes,
Subsubsection Text: which shall have terms substantially identical to the Senior Notes except in respect of specified terms. Such Additional Senior Notes will be treated, along with all other Senior Notes, as a single class for the purposes of the Senior Notes Indenture with respect to waivers, amendments and all other matters which are not specifically distinguished for such series. For all purposes other than United States federal income tax purposes, Additional Senior Notes shall be deemed to form one series with any Senior Notes previously issued if they have terms substantially identical in all material respects to such other Senior Notes. Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may at the option of the Senior Notes Issuer be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Senior Notes belonging to the same series previously issued without being fungible with such series of initial Senior Notes for United States federal income tax purposes.
