Subsection Title: Summary Financial Information and Other Data
Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth our summary financial information and other data on a consolidated basis as of the dates and for the periods indicated. The results of operations for prior fiscal years may not be necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for any future period. This summary financial information and other data should be read in conjunction with the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements (as defined below) and accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and discussed in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Selected Historical Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”

Subsubsection Title: Financial Information of the Issuers
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer are newly formed entities incorporated on July 20, 2021, in each case for purposes of facilitating the Transactions and performing certain activities related thereto. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer and, following the completion of the Acquisition, the Target will be a wholly owned direct subsidiary of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuers have no revenuegenerating activities of their own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those acquired or incurred in connection with their incorporation and the Transactions. As a result, no historical financial information of the Issuers is included in this summary, except for certain limited “adjusted” financial data presented on a consolidated basis, adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom, including the impact on the cash position, the amount of debt and the interest expense of the Group. The effects of purchase price accounting from the Acquisition have not yet been reflected in the information presented, however, the Acquisition may have certain effects on our financial statements and may impact our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows, which we are unable to determine with certainty until after the Completion Date. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and _Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Acquisition—We have made certain assumptions relating to the Acquisition in forecasts that may prove to be materially inaccurate.”_

Subsubsection Title: Historical Financial Information of the Target Group
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of financial position and consolidated statement of cash flows of the Target Group presented herein are derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union and which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. (the “Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting (the “Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the “Historical Consolidated Financial Statements”). The financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 in this Offering Memorandum is derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Financial Statements”). The audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 were originally approved by us on December 31, 2019. Thereafter, we have restated certain financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, included in the 2019 Financial Statements, by restating the classification of “other receivables” to “trade receivables” for an amount of €619 thousand, “other payables” to “current other liabilities” for an amount of €68,947 thousand, “non-current other liabilities” to “other liabilities” for an amount of €2,004 thousand, “other receivables” to “other assets” for an amount of €32,629 thousand and “tax liabilities” to “liabilities held for sale” for an amount of €1,792 thousand. These restatements do not have any impact on the reported profit for the year 2018 or reported equity and an immaterial impact on the cash flow statement for 2018. As a result, we ----- have not separately restated the financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018. See note 2.3 to the 2019 Financial Statements. In addition, we also present certain financial information of the Target Group for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 (the “LTM Financial Information”). Except as otherwise stated, the LTM Financial Information is derived by adding the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to the audited consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income of the Target Group for the year ended December 31, 2020 and deducting the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. The LTM Financial Information has been presented for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. Except as stated otherwise, the LTM Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting or in accordance with IFRS. We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) effective from January 1, 2019. As a result, leases (as lessee) that would have been classified in previous periods as operating leases are recognized in our consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. Under the new standard, except for short-term or low-value leases, the right to use a leased asset is recognized as an asset with a corresponding financial liability for the present value of outstanding lease payments. Assets with a finite useful life are subject to impairment testing. We have adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment obligations from existing operating leases were discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and recognized as a lease liability and the right-to-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments. As a result of the application of new accounting standards and the associated impact on our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements, prospective investors should exercise particular caution when comparing our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 to our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations.” For a discussion of the_ effects of the adoption of IFRS 16 on our financial condition and results of operations, see “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and note 2.4 to the 2019 Financial Statements._ After the completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group will not prepare separate consolidated financial statements and we instead intend to report our consolidated financial results at the level of the Parent. Due to this, our future financial statements may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum. Our future financial statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Impacting Comparability—Reporting.”_

Subsection Title: Pro Forma Adjustments Related to the Tele2 and Simpel Acquisitions and T-Infra Demerger
Subsubsection Text: We completed the acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019 and the acquisition of Simpel on December 1, 2020. On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our rented sites to a separate legal entity, T-Infra. T-Infra was transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date. In this Offering Memorandum, we present Pro Forma Net Revenue which is based on Tele2 and Simpel’s revenues for their respective preacquisition periods (adjusted for the estimated impact of IFRS 15 and IFRS 16) which are added to our revenue and adjusted for certain management reclassifications. We also present in this Offering Memorandum, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying RunRate EBITDA AcL which make certain adjustments to our EBITDA for the periods presented to take into account the reported EBITDA contributions of Tele2 and Simpel for their respective pre-acquisition periods, and eliminating the reported (negative) EBITDA of T-Infra (demerged business) for the relevant periods after ----- making certain intercompany adjustments based on management reclassifications and to exclude special factors such as pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, as detailed in this Offering Memorandum. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL as presented herein are not intended to represent pro forma financial information prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X promulgated under the U.S. Securities Act or other SEC requirements or IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The assumptions underlying Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting. Pro Forma Net Revenue, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL are presented for informational purposes only and do not purport to represent what our results of operations or financial condition would have been had the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel and the de-merger of T-infra actually occurred on the dates indicated, and they do not purport to project the results of operations or financial condition for any future period or as of any future date.
This Offering Memorandum contains certain financial measures and ratios (the “Non-IFRS

Subsection Title: Measures”), including Pro Forma Net Revenue, EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin, Underlying EBITDA AcL, Underlying EBITDA AcL Margin, Pro Forma Operating Free Cash Flow, Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion, Capital Expenditure, Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL and Underlying Run-Rate EBITDA AcL Margin that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. We present the Non-IFRS Measures because we believe that they are of interest to the investors and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our or any of our subsidiaries’ operating results as reported under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards. The Non-IFRS Measures may also be defined differently than the corresponding terms governing our indebtedness, including the Senior Secured Notes Indenture (as described under “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes”), the Senior Notes Indenture (as described under “Description of the Senior Notes”) and the_ Senior Facilities Agreement (as described under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements”). The NonIFRS Measures and ratios are not measurements of our or any of our subsidiaries’ performance or liquidity under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. In addition, the presentation of these NonIFRS Measures is not intended to, and does not comply with, the reporting requirements of the SEC and will not be subject to review by the SEC. Therefore, investors should not place undue reliance on the Non-IFRS Measures. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only to supplement the evaluation of our performance. The Historical Consolidated Financial Statements mentioned above do not indicate results that may be expected for any future period. In making an investment decision, you must rely upon your own examination of the terms of this Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—This Offering ----- _Memorandum includes certain non-IFRS financial measures calculated using management estimates or projections and they should not be relied upon in isolation when making an investment decision.”_ We have included in this section for the convenience of the reader, certain metrics excluding the impact of cash leases that have been impacted by IFRS 16 as the adoption of IFRS 16 has had a significant impact on our historical financials which has impacted the comparability of some of our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum and we believe it is of interest to investors to present certain measures excluding such impact to facilitate like-for-like comparability between our historical financial information during the periods under review.

We also present in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited financial information of the Group adjusted to give effect to the Transactions and the use of proceeds therefrom as if they had occurred on September 30, 2021 for the consolidated statement of financial position data and on October 1, 2020 for our consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income data, including the impact on our cash position, amount of debt and interest expense (the “Adjusted Financial Information”). The Adjusted Financial Information is not intended to represent pro forma financial information prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X promulgated under the U.S. Securities Act or other SEC requirements or IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. The Adjusted Financial Information is based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The assumptions underlying the Adjusted Financial Information have not been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. The Adjusted Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting. The Adjusted Financial Information is presented for informational purposes only and does not purport to represent what our results of operations or financial condition would have been had the Transactions actually occurred on the date indicated, and they do not purport to project the results of operations or financial condition for any future period or as of any future date. The summary financial information presented below should be read in conjunction with the information contained in “Presentation of Financial Information,” “Capitalization,” “Selected Historical _Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” as well as the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying notes thereto_ appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsubsection Text: _(In thousands of subscribers)_ B2C Mobile Postpaid Subscribers[(1)] . 4,646 4,931 5,074 5,053 5,159 B2C Fixed Subscribers[(2)] ................. 549 619 682 661 721 B2B Mobile Subscribers[(3)] .............. 1,075 1,234 1,353 1,345 1,402 _(€ per month)_ B2C Mobile Postpaid ARPU[(4)] ........ 16.2 15.7 15.5 15.5 15.6 B2C Fixed ARPU[(5)] ........................ 33.4 33.5 33.5 33.8 33.4 B2B Mobile ARPU[(6)] ...................... 17.2 15.1 13.7 14.1 13.0 ----- (1) Represents the sum of postpaid mobile subscribers in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, as at the end of the relevant period. (2) Represents the sum of fixed subscribers in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile Thuis and Tele2 brands, as at the end of the relevant period. (3) Represents the number of subscribers in our B2B segment, as at the end of the relevant period. (4) Represents the sum of postpaid mobile ARPU in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands. We calculate B2C Mobile Postpaid ARPU by dividing the relevant B2C mobile postpaid revenue in a period by the average by number of subscribers over that period (calculated as the average of the number of subscribers at the beginning of the period and the number of subscribers at the end of the period), and further divided by the number of months in the relevant period. B2C mobile postpaid revenue in a period is calculated on a pro forma basis for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisition. (5) Represents the sum of fixed ARPU in our B2C segment for each of our T-Mobile Thuis and Tele2 brands. We calculate B2C Fixed ARPU by dividing the relevant B2C fixed line revenue in a period by the average by number of subscribers over that period (calculated as the average of the number of subscribers at the beginning of the period and the number of subscribers at the end of the period), and further divided by the number of months in the relevant period. B2C fixed line revenue in a period is calculated on a pro forma basis for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisition. (6) Represents the sum of mobile ARPU in our B2B segment. We calculate B2B Mobile ARPU by dividing the relevant B2B mobile revenue in a period by the average by number of subscribers over that period (calculated as the average of the number of subscribers at the beginning of the period and the number of subscribers at the end of the period), and further divided by the number of months in the relevant period. B2B mobile revenue in a period is calculated on a pro forma basis for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisition. During the year ended December 31, 2020, management estimates the ARPU for SOHO/VSE to be €23.7, €16.6 for SMB and €6.1 for LE/CE.

Certain financial information below has been presented on a historical pro forma basis to include the pro forma effect of the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel, the demerger of T-Infra and the application of IFRS 16, in each case from January 1, 2018, including retrospective application of the T-Infra Master Lease Agreement (“MLA”) and certain TMNL management reclassifications, as applicable. We present such historical pro forma information because we believe that it facilitates like-for-like comparability between our historical financial information during the periods under review. The LTM Financial Information presented in this section is calculated based on monthly management accounts and monthly performance, reflecting pro forma adjustments for the Tele2 and Simple acquisitions, the T-Infra demerger and the application of IFRS 16, on a monthly or quarterly basis, as applicable. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” for further details.

(a) Represents the standalone pre-acquisition revenue of Tele2, which we acquired in January 2019, adjusted for the application of IFRS 15 and IFRS 16 based on management estimates for purposes of accounting harmonization. (b) Represents the standalone pre-acquisition revenue of Simpel, which we acquired in December 2020, adjusted for the application of IFRS 15 and IFRS 16 based on management estimates for purposes of accounting harmonization. (c) Represents several management reclassifications, mainly related to (i) interconnected revenues that are reclassified from TMNL to Simpel, (ii) the elimination of Simpel wholesale fees and (iii) the elimination of Tele2 wholesale fees. (2) We define EBITDA as net profit/(loss) for the relevant period before income taxes, gain from other financial activities, net finance costs and depreciation, amortization and impairment losses. We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as our EBITDA adjusted for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, the demerger of T-Infra and certain TMNL management reclassifications, as well as to exclude special factors such as pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, consisting primarily of advisory costs/support, network integration costs and severance costs. We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude the estimated impact of IFRS 16, thereby including operating lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with cash EBITDA. We define Underlying EBITDA AcL as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, adjusted to exclude (i) certain items, which management believes are one-off and/or non-recurring items and (ii) removal costs related to the stock appreciation right (“SAR”) scheme introduced by TMNL in 2017. EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL and Underlying EBITDA AcL are supplemental measures of our performance that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. We believe EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL and Underlying EBITDA AcL provide useful information to our management and investors with respect to our overall operating performance by facilitating comparisons of operating performance on a consistent basis by removing the impact of items not directly resulting from core operations. We present these Non-IFRS Measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance. These Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for an analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. See also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Measures” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—This Offering Memorandum includes certain non_IFRS financial measures calculated using management estimates or projections and they should not be relied upon in isolation when _making an investment decision.”_ The following table shows a reconciliation of EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL and Underlying EBITDA AcL to our net profit/(loss) for the relevant period:

(b) For the year ended December 31, 2018, the Simpel EBITDA adjustment consisted of (i) pre-acquisition EBITDA of Simpel of €12.6 million, (ii) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €(1.9) million and (iii) an intercompany adjustment for the reclassification of interconnect activities in respect of certain users that were, pre-acquisition, users on both TMNL and Simpel networks and are post-acquisition consolidated in TMNL’s financial statements, in the amount of €(2.1) million. For the year ended December 31, 2019, the Simpel EBITDA adjustment consisted of (i) pre-acquisition EBITDA of Simpel of €22.6 million, (ii) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €1.5 million and (iii) an intercompany adjustment for the reclassification of interconnect activities in respect of certain users that were, pre-acquisition, users on both TMNL and Simpel networks and are post-acquisition consolidated in TMNL’s financial statements, in the amount of €(5.5) million. For the year ended December 31, 2020, the Simpel EBITDA adjustment consisted of (i) pre-acquisition EBITDA of Simpel of €24.8 million, (ii) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €1.1 million and (iii) an intercompany adjustment for the reclassification of interconnect activities in respect of certain users that were, pre-acquisition, users on both TMNL and Simpel networks and are post-acquisition consolidated in TMNL’s financial statements, in the amount of €(1.1) million. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, the Simpel EBITDA adjustment consisted of (i) pre-acquisition EBITDA of Simpel of €3.2 million, (ii) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €0.2 million and (iii) an intercompany adjustment for the reclassification of interconnect activities in respect of certain users that were, preacquisition, users on both TMNL and Simpel networks and are post-acquisition consolidated in TMNL’s financial statements, in the amount of €(0.1) million. (c) On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our rented sites to T-Infra. TInfra was transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date. For the year ended December 31, 2018, the T-Infra EBITDA adjustment consisted of (i) eliminating the reported (negative) EBITDA of T-Infra (demerged business) of €17.9 million, (ii) inclusion of lease costs with other operating expenses of €(51.9) million in connection with the continuing MLA and (iii) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €51.9 million. (d) For the year ended December 31, 2018, the TMNL management reclassifications consisted of (i) pro forma application of the estimated impact of IFRS 16 in the amount of €36.1 million, (ii) pre-acquisition period interconnect revenues that were reclassified from TMNL to Simpel in the amount of €2.1 million, (iii) consolidation entry between TMNL and Simpel relating to wholesale fees in the amount of €(6.0) million and (iv) consolidation entry between TMNL and Tele2 in the amount of €(0.8) million. For the year ended December 31, 2019, the TMNL management reclassifications consisted of (i) pre-acquisition period interconnect revenues that were reclassified from TMNL to Simpel in the amount of €5.5 million and (ii) consolidation entry between TMNL and Simpel relating to wholesale fees in the amount of €1.1 million. For the year ended December 31, 2020, the TMNL management reclassifications mainly consisted of (i) pre-acquisition period interconnect revenues that were reclassified from TMNL to Simpel in the amount of €1.1 million, (ii) management’s estimates for alignment of IFRS 16 assumptions for the T-Infra MLA contract in the amount of €0.3 million and (iii) an incremental ----- amount of €(14.9) million in order to adjust for the difference between preliminary statutory adjustments and final statutory adjustments. The difference in preliminary and final statutory adjustments is attributable to accounting differences in the treatment of the bad debt provision, mass claim provision, SAR provision, lease incentive provisions and IFRS 16 positions as a result of final year-end closing procedures and audit adjustments. Management has assessed the differences on a case-bycase basis and concluded that while relevant for statutory financial statements, these are non-representative for the recurring trend of pro forma adjusted EBITDA or Underlying EBITDA for which these fluctuations represent one-off events or differences in a given period and should be phased or time corrected to another (earlier) period. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, the TMNL management reclassifications mainly consisted of (i) preacquisition period interconnect revenues that were reclassified from TMNL to Simpel in the amount of €0.1 million, (ii) management’s estimates for alignment of IFRS 16 assumptions for the T-Infra MLA contract in the amount of €0.1 million and (iii) an incremental amount of €30.0 million in order to adjust for the difference between preliminary statutory adjustments and final statutory adjustments. The difference in preliminary and final statutory adjustments is attributable to accounting differences in the treatment of the bad debt provision, mass claim provision, SAR provision, lease incentive provisions and IFRS 15 and IFRS 16 positions as a result of final year-end closing procedures and audit adjustments. Management has assessed the differences on a case-by-case basis and concluded that while relevant for statutory financial statements, these are nonrepresentative for the recurring trend of pro forma adjusted EBITDA or Underlying EBITDA for which these fluctuations represent one-off events or differences in a given period and should be phased or time corrected to another (earlier) period. (e) Represents adjustments for certain one-off costs primarily related to pre- and post-acquisition integration and restructuring costs related to the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions and consisting primarily of advisory costs/support, network integration costs and severance costs. (f) Reflects an adjustment to exclude the estimated impact of IFRS 16, thereby including operating lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with cash EBITDA. (g) Represents certain items, which management believes are one-off and/or non-recurring items, primarily related to: (i) €7.7 million of temporary effects in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic, €0.7 million of early termination fees for shops, one-off fine of €1.4 million imposed by the Dutch ACM, €1.8 million of advisory fees related to the sale of Simpel incurred during the pre-acquisition period, €(0.4) million of release of a previous accrual in Simpel’s pre-acquisition accounts, €0.5 million of reversal of an out of period accrual release attributable to a discount to a wholesale partner in 2020, €0.7 million of accrual policy change regarding catch-up carrier costs, €0.3 million of correct phasing of B2B activation costs in connection with IFRS 15, €0.7 million of correct phasing of installation cost accruals, €(0.3) million of double-booked bad debt costs during the migration of Tele2 customers from the Tele2 systems to the TMNL systems, €(0.7) million of reversal of release of a previous over-accrual provision in connection with Eurofiber, €0.8 million of one-off correction for administrative costs related to recognition of VAT on electronic payments for prepaid credits, €(1.1) million of release of over-accruals for cost of goods sold and supplier invoices in the fixed segment, €(14.9) million of release of a COVID-related bad debt provision in the third quarter of 2021 which led to a positive one-off COVID-19 impact on Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. These one-off or non-recurring items have been calculated based on management estimates, which we believe are reasonable. The COVID-19-related effects of €7.7 million during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 primarily comprised of temporary effects on revenues and contribution margin, mainly driven by customer behavior such as reduced mobility, reduced roaming charges due to COVID-19 related travel restrictions and reduced out-of-bundle usage by customers. Furthermore, we also experienced temporarily high costs due to high utilization of call centers with our shops being closed, and additional costs for home delivery of handsets, which negatively impacted profitability. See also “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Non-IFRS Measures” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—This Offering Memorandum includes certain non-IFRS financial measures calculated using management estimates or projections and they should not be relied upon in isolation when making an investment decision.”_ (h) Represents the costs associated with the SAR incentive scheme. In 2017, TMNL introduced the SAR scheme to offer eligible employees the option to participate in an increase in the enterprise value. The full amount of expenses related to the SAR scheme has been adjusted to provide details on the EBITDA generation of TMNL and enhance comparability with equity based/non-cash incentive schemes. Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business is uncertain and its effect on the Dutch economy and our customers’ behavior constitutes a threat to our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, governments of many countries, including The Netherlands, have taken preventative measures to try to contain its spread. These measures have included mandatory closure of businesses, social distancing requirements and travel restrictions, which have severely diminished the level of economic activity around the world and in The Netherlands and have caused significant volatility in financial markets and triggered a period of global economic slowdown, the extent and duration of which are currently uncertain. In The Netherlands, according to CBS, Dutch gross domestic product (“GDP”) declined by 1.7% during the first quarter of 2020 and by 8.5% in the second quarter of 2020, each relative to the previous quarter. Growth in The Netherlands has oscillated since the second quarter of 2020, reaching 7.8% in the third quarter of 2020, then declining by 0.1% and 0.8% in the fourth quarter of 2020 and the first quarter of 2021, respectively, and increasing by and 3.1% in the second quarter of 2021, each in comparison to the previous quarter. The COVID-19 pandemic and the multiple waves of infections that have been recorded have severely impacted the economies of the European Union, including The Netherlands. In particular, the World Bank registered a contraction for the Euro area’s real GDP of 6.4% in 2020 and forecasts deeper continuing impacts on those economies dependent on international tourism as well as those dependent on international trade, as supply bottlenecks persist (Source: World Bank). In The Netherlands, employment and working hours were negatively impacted, with the unemployment rate increasing by approximately 1.5% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2020 and total working hours decreasing. After the lockdown in mid-March, hours worked per week fell by 18%, or 6 hours per week by May of 2020 (Source: Institute of Labor Economics, Drivers of _Working Hours and Household Income Dynamics during the COVID-19 Pandemic: The Case of The Netherlands). COVID-19 caseload waves and concomitant containment measures were associated with_ exceptional declines in consumer spending in two waves in 2020, reaching 17% and 12% declines in consumer spending year-over-year in April and December of 2020, respectively (Source: CBS). The European Commission expects the Dutch economy to rebound in the second and third quarters of 2021, leading to real GDP growth of 3.3% year-over-year for both 2021 and 2022 (Source: European Commission, Summer 2021 _Economic forecast for Netherlands), but there can be no assurance that these recovery rates will be achieved._ Economic slowdown due to further waves of COVID-19 may result in additional or more drastic preventive measures being imposed, which in turn may result in further declines in consumer disposable income and spending as well as consumer confidence. These economic effects may in turn cause increases in customer payment defaults and bad debt in respect of both our business and retail customers, and they may also cause our business customers to delay or forego decisions to use our services, all of which may adversely impact our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects. In response to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, we closed all our retail shops on March 16, 2020. We reopened some of our shops on a shop-in-a-box concept a few days later, and by June 2020 we had reopened ----- all our shops. However, under renewed Dutch government containment measures, we closed all our shops again on December 15, 2020 and gradually restarted services in shops as of February 2021, with the shops fully open as of April 28, 2021. Such measures have had an impact in the general financial condition of the companies and workforce in The Netherlands. They have also had an impact on our business in particular as retail footprint is an important sales channel for us, especially for the T-Mobile brand. Such closures may have affected, and may in the future affect if they are re-imposed, important metrics such as gross adds in mobile and fixed services, or may otherwise adversely affect our business, operating results, financial conditions and prospects. On November 12, 2021, the Dutch government announced a new set of COVID-19 containment measures by which, as of November 13, 2021, bars, restaurants, clothing shops and other non-essential shops and services are required to be closed from during certain hours, gatherings at home are limited, and sporting events will be held without spectators, among other measures. In response to continued high infection rates in the Netherlands, on November 26, 2021, the Dutch government announced that these measures would tighten as of November 28, 2021, for an additional three weeks at least, with non-essential shops to close between 5 PM and 5 AM daily and supermarkets to close at 8 PM daily. In addition, the Dutch government has prescribed guidelines to maintain social distancing in shops and outlets and other mitigating measures in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19, which may impact our ability to carry out our business and operations at normal capacity. Terminal equipment sales, renewal and new contracts could decrease due to the additional measures announced on November 12 and November 26, 2021, or due to any further temporary COVID-19-related closures or restricted hours of our retail shops or due to decrease in customer demand as a result of such measures and closures. These and similar measures may also delay the completion of our capital or infrastructure construction projects and other operations and maintenance activities, which could result in a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. See “—The _continuity of our services strongly depends on the proper functioning of our IT and network infrastructure and any failure of this infrastructure could have a material adverse effect on our business.”_ While we believe our operations are currently in compliance with applicable guidance, if customers perceive our implementation of these measures to be inadequate or ineffective, we may experience lower than expected activity at the retail stores or suffer damage to our reputation, which could have a significant adverse effect on our business. In addition, our customers’ ability or desire to visit our physical premises may remain weak for a significant length of time. This would affect sales of hardware such as handsets, tablets and other accessories and other in-store purchases such as top-ups, and would also impede our ability to capture new customers. Furthermore, the self-isolation measures imposed by the Dutch government in order to combat COVID-19 have led to changing patterns of internet and mobile services usage. For example, mobile calling and fixed data traffic tended to increase during lockdowns and decrease once lockdown restrictions ended. If the Dutch government were to impose new or different containment measures, consumer patterns of interest and mobile services usage may change in ways we cannot predict and which could negatively affect our revenues and results of operations. Lastly, the severe national and international travel restrictions implemented in order to contain the COVID-19 pandemic spread have also contributed to diminishing the level of economic activity in The Netherlands, including tourism and leisure (significant contributors to the Dutch economy), which could negatively impact our retail sales, including revenue from roaming services that have decreased as a consequence of travel restrictions, as well as consumer confidence, investment by business and the Dutch economy more broadly, which could in turn adversely affect our sales to both residential and business customers across channels. Additionally, further variants of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, may mutate in ways that increase transmissibility, evade the human immune system, or bypass the protection provided by vaccines, and thereby cause governments to order travel bans and re-impose lockdowns as these variants appear. As a result of the start of the global spread of the Omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 in the week of November 22, 2021, governments around the world began to re-impose travel bans to southern African countries that were seen as sources of the new variant, as cases of the new variant were detected that week in the UK and Belgium, among other countries. Since the severity of the disease Omicron causes and the extent to which it is more transmissible than previous widespread SARS-CoV-2 variants are presently unknown, we cannot predict the course of future lockdowns, travel bans, and other measures that may be imposed by Dutch or other governments to contain its spread or the spread of other SARS-CoV-2 which may appear in the future, all of which may have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and prospects. ----- Further, we cannot predict if and when customer spending and domestic travel will return to preCOVID-19 levels, and any of these factors may adversely affect our ability to conduct our business on the same terms as we did prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. In the last five years we have grown rapidly to become one of the largest telecommunications services providers in The Netherlands and we continue to pursue a growth strategy to improve our business, financial condition and results of operations. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including labor supply dislocation which has increased job vacancies in The Netherlands (Source: CBS) and which may increase our labor costs, decreased customer confidence and decreased consumer spending, could result in our failure to achieve our historical growth rates. The full impact of the pandemic on our business remains uncertain and will ultimately depend on a number of factors that cannot be accurately predicted at this time, including, but not limited to, the duration (including the extent of any resurgence in the future) and severity of the COVID-19 pandemic, the timing of and manner in which containment efforts are reduced or lifted, the timing and ability of vaccination boosters, the effects and impact of variants on the vaccinated population, the duration and magnitude of its impact on unemployment rates and consumer discretionary spending, the length of time it takes for demand and pricing to return to pre-COVID-19 levels and for normal economic and operating conditions to resume, which are all beyond our knowledge and control. Moreover, there are no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance. For these reasons, we cannot reasonably estimate the ultimate impact of COVID-19 on our business with any certainty nor can we provide any assurance that COVID-19 will not have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. To the extent COVID-19 adversely affects our business, financial condition and results of operations, it may also have the effect of heightening other risks described in this “Risk Factors” section, including those relating to our significant levels of debt, our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to fund our debt obligations, and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the agreements that govern our indebtedness.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The spread of the COVID-19 pandemic has caused severe disruptions in the Dutch and the global economy and could potentially create widespread business continuity issues of unknown magnitude and duration, which may impact our liquidity and access to capital.
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused, and is likely to continue to cause, severe economic, market and other disruptions worldwide. We cannot assure you that conditions in the bank lending, capital and other financial markets will not continue to deteriorate as a result of the pandemic, or that our access to capital and other sources of funding will not become constrained, which could adversely affect the availability and terms of future borrowings, renewals or refinancing. We may be required to raise additional capital in the future and our access and cost of financing will depend on, among others, global economic conditions, conditions in the global financing markets, the availability of sufficient amounts, our prospects and our credit ratings. In addition, the terms of future debt agreements could include more restrictive covenants or require incremental collateral, which may restrict our business operations or make such debt unavailable due to our covenant restrictions then in effect. There is no guarantee that debt financings will be available in the future to fund our obligations, or that they will be available on terms consistent with our expectations. We depend upon our operations to generate strong cash flows to support our operating activities, supply capital to finance our operations and growth, make capital expenditure and manage our debt levels. The continuing economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, and the resulting restrictions and preventive measures, could adversely affect our ability to generate sufficient cash flows from operations and could adversely affect our ability to make payments of future interest and other payments with respect to our indebtedness and other obligations, including payments on the Notes and to fund capital expenditures, which could negatively impact the quality of our service, our competitiveness and customer satisfaction, which could in turn have a negative impact on our revenue, operating profit and cash flows. In addition, since we have fixed costs which we cannot significantly or rapidly decrease when demand for our products or services decreases, such as personnel costs and costs related to our infrastructure, any resulting decline in our revenue, particularly in the event of a future resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic, may have a material adverse effect on our net cash flows, margins and profits. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face significant competition in each of the business segments in which we operate and competitive pressures and shifting customer preferences could have a material adverse impact on our business.
Subsubsection Text: The Dutch telecommunications market is dynamic and competitive pressure may undercut our business, materially negatively affecting our business, revenue and prospects. We operate in highly competitive markets and we face significant competition in our industry which has resulted in ARPU that historically has been, until recently, generally declining in the important B2C mobile segment across our industry. In The Netherlands, the three main providers in the telecommunications sector are TMNL, KPN and VFZ. VFZ and KPN currently lead the fixed internet market. We are the largest mobile telecommunications operator in The Netherlands, as measured by number of SIMs and by revenue in the B2C mobile segment. For our mobile and our fixed services, our competitors include, but are not limited to, KPN and VFZ. In addition, our mobile services face competition from OTT services providers and MVNOs while our fixed services also compete with alternative providers such as Delta, Online.nl and in B2B, Eurofiber, as well as fixed virtual network operators. For our wholesale services, our key competitors include, but are not limited to, wholesale providers of voice, data and fiber services. We may also face increased competition in any of these business segments as a result of new market entrants, or legacy operators may seek to leverage their market position to compete with us in new territories or service areas. For instance, KPN or VFZ may aggressively compete with us in our mobile business in response to our attempts to gain market share in fixed internet services. Competition from such companies, as well as from new entrants and new technologies, could create downward pressure on prices across all the business lines, which could result in a decrease in ARPU, a loss of customers or revenue generation units and a decrease in revenue and profitability. In addition, technological developments are increasing cross-competition in certain markets, such as that between mobile and fixed-line telephony. In some instances, our competitors may have easier access to financing, more comprehensive product ranges, lower financial leverage, greater financial, technical, marketing and personnel resources, larger subscriber bases, wider geographical coverage for their networks, greater brand name recognition and experience or longer established relationships with regulatory authorities, suppliers and customers. Some of our competitors may have fewer regulatory burdens with which they are required to comply because, among other reasons, they use different technologies to provide their services or are not subject to obligations applicable to operators with significant market power. Traditional telecommunications operators may develop an expansion policy with their main or secondtier brands based on large price discounts that generally affect all operators in the market. Certain of our main competitors in The Netherlands may have greater financial capacity than us. This could be used to undercut competing businesses, including us, or to invest in infrastructure or other assets that would enable our traditional competitors to become more competitive in the market. In order to increase our postpaid subscriber base, we must either migrate our existing prepaid mobile customers to a postpaid plan, attract our competitors’ existing subscribers or attract new customers who did not have a mobile telecommunications subscription before. We may face a declining rate at which we can continue to migrate our existing prepaid customers to postpaid plans as the prepaid base decreases consistently over time, or we may not be successful in attracting new subscriptions, or attempting to attract our competitors’ existing subscribers may intensify the competitive pressures that we are subject to. We cannot guarantee that our historical positive net adds numbers and leading customer satisfaction ratings (as confirmed by our increasing TRI*M scores over the last decade, where TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group) will continue in the future. In addition, as a consequence of the COVID-19 pandemic, since the first half of 2020, the level of competition has increased as many of our competitors have launched new promotions and offers in an attempt to tackle worsening economic conditions and declining consumer spending, such as KPN’s Unlimited mobile promotion and fixed line portfolio changes from KPN and VFZ. Such initiatives may adversely affect ARPU, including as a result of any potential customer retention campaigns that we may undertake in response to such strong market competitive intensity. Our competitors could gain competitive advantages over us through leveraging their more extensive fixed internet networks or through joint ventures and alliances among franchises or financial investors, wireless or private cable operators, satellite providers, local exchange carriers and other telecommunications service ----- providers in The Netherlands that could give them increased access to financing, resources, efficiencies of scale or the ability to provide multiple services in direct competition with us. Public-private joint ventures may also increase competition. Any of these advantages that our competitors may hold or come to hold could make it difficult for us to compete, for instance by making our FMC bundles less attractive relative to our competitors’ and thereby siphoning away customers from our mobile base, negatively impacting our business, revenue, and prospects. In our capacity as wholesale seller of mobile services, we have an arrangement with MVNOs who rely on our network to provide services for their own customers. An MVNO arrangement generally provides less revenue and lower margins than our other services, and as a result, a potential increase in market share of MVNOs may reduce our margins and revenue if we fail to increase our own market share in the mobile market. In addition, aggressive pricing from MVNOs on our network or on other networks and pressure from MVNOs on our network for contract terms that are more favorable to them could also increase the competitive pressure and cause our results of operations to decline. If we are unable to compete effectively with MVNOs, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially and adversely affected. The success of our business model is based on our service quality and the products currently offered in the market as well as on continual renewal and updating of our product and service range in accordance with the requirements and changes that arise in a highly competitive market. Our business and results of operations may be adversely affected if we become uncompetitive as a result of failing to keep pace with changing technology and consumer preferences. Any delay or absence in introducing a product or service range that is at least similar to what is being offered by our main competitors could lead us to lose our competitive position in the market and, consequently, to a decrease of our current market share, which would have a negative impact on our revenue, operating profit and cash flows. In addition, maintaining and developing our infrastructure and the range and quality of our services to remain competitive in the market requires significant capital expenditure on an ongoing basis, which could negatively impact our profitability in future periods. For instance, to remain competitive we will occasionally need to bid for spectrum allocations at government auctions, such as at the planned 3.5 GHz 5G spectrum auction that the Dutch government is planning for 2022. See “—Our business is capital intensive and our capital _expenditures may not generate a positive return.” Our inability, for any reason, to fund our capital expenditure_ in the future could negatively impact the quality of our service, our competitiveness and customer satisfaction, which could have a negative impact on our revenue, operating profit and cash flows. New providers of mobile data and telephony services may enter the market and may benefit from more effective or lower cost technologies that give them a competitive advantage over us in these markets. In particular, we are facing increasing competition from non-traditional mobile voice and data services based on new mobile VoIP, in particular OTT services, such as Facebook Messenger, FaceTime, Google Talk, Skype, Snapchat, Viber and WhatsApp. These OTT services are often free of charge, accessible via smartphones and allow their users to have access to potentially unlimited messaging and voice services over the internet, thus bypassing more expensive traditional voice and messaging services (SMS/MMS) provided by MNOs like us, who are only able to charge the internet data usage for such services. With the growing share of smartphone users in the Dutch mobile subscriber base, there are an increasing number of customers using OTT services. All MNOs are currently competing with OTT services providers who leverage existing infrastructure and are often not required to implement capital-intensive business models associated with traditional mobile network operators like us. OTT service providers have in recent years become more sophisticated, and technological developments have led to a significant improvement in the quality of service, particularly in speech quality. In addition, players with strong brand capability and financial strength, such as Apple Inc. (“Apple”), Google Inc. (“Google”), Meta Platforms, Inc. (“Facebook”) and Microsoft Corporation, have turned their attention to the provision of OTT services. In the long-term, if non-traditional mobile voice and data services or similar services continue to increase in popularity and if we, or more generally all the MNOs, are not able to address this competition, this could cause declines in subscriber base and profitability across all of our products and services, among other material adverse effects. In addition, we may face increasing competition from a large-scale rollout of public Wi-Fi networks by local governments and utilities, transportation service providers, new and existing Wi-Fi telecommunications operators and others, which particularly benefits OTT services. Enhanced fixed service infrastructure access and mobile services provided by competing operators may be more appealing ----- to customers, and new technologies may enable our competitors to offer not only new or technologically superior services, but to also offer existing standard services at lower prices. For example, in areas with slow mobile internet service but broadband coverage, the availability of OTT services may negatively impact the demand for mobile services subscriptions. The telecommunications services industry has undergone significant technological development over time and these changes continue to affect our business. Such changes have had, and will continue to have, a profound impact on consumer expectations and behavior. Our products and services are also subject to increasing competition from alternative new technologies or improvements in existing technologies. We may not be able to fund the capital expenditures necessary to keep pace with technological developments. See “—If we fail to successfully adopt new technologies or services, or to respond to _technological developments, our business may be adversely affected and we may not be able to recover the cost of investments that we have made.”_ Any inability or unwillingness to respond effectively to such competitive pressures could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to make payments on the Notes and on the trading price of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is concentrated in The Netherlands, and may be adversely affected by negative economic, legal or political developments in The Netherlands.
Subsubsection Text: Our business operates entirely in The Netherlands and all of our revenue is generated in The Netherlands. Accordingly, our results may be adversely impacted by negative economic, legal or political developments in The Netherlands, or by our failure to anticipate the needs and preferences of Dutch consumers in terms of our marketing, service portfolio and strategic investments. Any adverse developments, or even uncertainties, in this regard may adversely affect our business, financial position, cash flows and results of operations. A deterioration in economic conditions in The Netherlands as a result, for example, of changes in government policy, a further deterioration in global economic conditions as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic (see also “—The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our _business is uncertain and its effect on the Dutch economy and our customers’ behavior constitutes a threat to our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects” and “—The spread of the COVID-19 pandemic has caused severe disruptions in the Dutch and the global economy and could potentially create widespread business continuity issues of unknown magnitude and duration, which may impact our liquidity and access to capital” above) or a regional or global recession, could reduce or limit the growth of consumers’_ disposable income. All these factors could have a negative impact on our sales of new services and hardware and lead some of our customers to default on their telephone, broadband and/or television bills, thus negatively impacting our revenue. There is also a risk that financing conditions will tighten for both private and public sectors in Europe, or in The Netherlands in particular, as a result of renewed uncertainty surrounding the sustainability of public finances in certain European countries, recession or other macroeconomic developments, which could increase our cost of financing or limit our access to financing in the future, which could limit our ability to pursue new acquisitions, improve and expand our infrastructure or otherwise implement our business plan. In addition to the COVID-19 pandemic, there are several potential sources of economic uncertainty which could adversely affect the Dutch economy in particular. For example, the Dutch economy has experienced volatility in recent years, including due to fundamental political changes to the European Union and trade uncertainties as a result of the UK’s decision to leave the European Union. Additionally, Dutch market risk arises as a result of changes in interest rates, exchange rates, inflation, increasing gas and energy costs and others.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions and other strategic transactions present many risks, including the risk that we may not be able to integrate newly acquired operations into our business, which may prevent us from realizing the strategic and financial goals contemplated at the time of any such transaction and thus adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our business has grown, in part, through a number of selective acquisitions and joint ventures that have enabled us to take advantage of existing networks, service offerings and management expertise. In the period from 2016 to 2020 in particular, we acquired three complementary businesses. In ----- December 2016, we acquired from VFZ the fixed-line business unit in The Netherlands, then known as Vodafone Thuis and since rebranded as T-Mobile Thuis, which has enabled us to offer FMC B2C packages that combine internet, television and fixed telephone. In January 2019, we acquired Tele2 from Tele2 Sweden, which added over one million B2C SIMs and over 300,000 B2C and B2B fixed subscribers to our business. In December 2020, by acquiring Complex Bidco B.V., we acquired Simpel, which added a budget brand with over one million B2C SIMs. In April 2021, we entered into an agreement to serve as the anchor tenant of a new fiber network that is projected to extend to over one million homes passed in The Netherlands by Roots OpCo B.V. (“Open Dutch Fiber”), a joint venture between KKR and DTCP. In May 2019, we entered into an agreement with Primevest Capital Partners and Koninklijke VolkerWessels B.V (“VolkerWessels”) by which we will serve as an anchor tenant on an FTTH, a high-speed internet network that Primevest Capital Partners and Volker Wessels will build. Following the pilot of this partnership in The Hague’s Segbroek area, the consortium will build fiber networks in The Hague’s Loosduinen area as well as Eindhoven and Rotterdam. This network is expected to extend to over 130,000 homes passed by mid-2022. We may undertake further acquisitions, joint ventures or other synergistic transactions in the future, in addition to pursuing organic growth through increased customer numbers and increased penetration of our services and products among our existing customer base. Any acquisition, disposal or other strategic transaction we may undertake in the future could result in us incurring additional debt or contingent liabilities, in addition to post-completion liabilities, increased interest expenses and/or amortization expenses related to goodwill and other intangible assets. In particular, any target that we acquire may have liabilities that we failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing our due diligence investigations. We may learn of additional information about the target companies that adversely affects us, such as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws and regulations. For example, we could become liable for overdue payables to suppliers and employees that are not known to us at the time of the acquisition, or we could become subject to tax or pension liabilities in respect of historical periods that we are not currently aware of or the amount of which we underestimated. In conducting our due diligence, we rely on resources available to us, including public information and information provided by the sellers and third-party advisers. In addition, our due diligence usually provides for materiality thresholds, a limited scope and a restricted perimeter. There can be no assurance that the due diligence we undertake reveals or highlights all relevant facts necessary or helpful in evaluating future acquisitions. Furthermore, there can be no assurance as to the adequacy or accuracy of information provided during the due diligence exercise. The due diligence process is inherently subjective. If the due diligence investigation failed to identify material information regarding the business we plan to acquire, we may later be forced to write down or write off certain assets, significantly modify the business plan or incur impairment or other charges. Similarly, the materialization of certain risks, which may or may not have been identified during due diligence, may lead to a loss of property, loss of value and, potentially, subsequent contractual and statutory liability to various parties. Any of these events, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes. Furthermore, the acquisitions of certain companies may constitute a change of control under agreements entered into by such companies, and may entitle these third parties to terminate their agreements with us or, in some cases, request adjustments and financing arrangements of the terms of the agreements. We cannot exclude the possibility that some of these third parties may exercise their termination, adjustment or other rights, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position following any such acquisition. In addition, some of the third parties may use their termination or adjustment rights to renegotiate the terms of the agreements to our detriment and may benefit from stronger bargaining power, as a result of which the acquired company may only be able to secure replacement contracts on less favorable terms or at all. In addition, it cannot be guaranteed that we will have sufficient resources to fund any acquisitions in the future, which would limit our growth potential, or we may use available cash on hand to finance any such acquisitions, which may impact our ability to make capital expenditures or payments on the Notes. We may experience difficulties in integrating the businesses we acquire into our business, incur higher than expected costs or fail to realize all of the anticipated benefits or synergies of such acquisitions, or fail to retain key customers, employees and management personnel of the relevant targets. For example, we may fail to achieve the anticipated operational synergies under our acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel or our separation from ----- Deutsche Telekom, or the costs we incur in trying to realize these synergies and other benefits described herein may be substantially higher than our current estimates and may outweigh any benefit. Further, the anticipated total run-rate synergy potential of €139 million by 2024 which we have identified in respect of Tele2 and Simpel, may not be achievable within the anticipated timelines or at all and there may be significant costs associated with achieving such synergies. Such transactions may also disrupt our relationships with current and new employees, customers and suppliers. Further, the attention of our managers may be distracted from existing operations by such acquisition processes and the integration of the acquired businesses, especially for material acquisitions. Such acquisitions may also raise regulatory compliance issues. We may face difficulty integrating a newly-acquired company into our data protection compliance framework, and we may become liable for regulatory compliance issues with respect to the acquired company relating to events that took place before our acquisition of it. For example, in September 2019, we were fined by the ACM for alleged violations of our website information obligations that in part related to Tele2’s website offerings in a period both before and after we completed our acquisition of Tele2. For further information, see “—Risks Relating to Legislative and _Regulatory Matters—We face risks arising from the outcome of various criminal, civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.” Thus, if we consummate any further acquisitions or fail to integrate previous_ acquisitions, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in completing business acquisitions or integrating previously acquired companies. In addition, our debt burden may increase if we borrow funds to finance any future transactions, which could have a negative impact on our cash flows and our ability to finance our overall operations. Acquisitions or disposals of additional telecommunications companies may require the approval of governmental authorities (either domestically or at the EU level), which can block, impose conditions on, or delay the process which could result in a failure to proceed with announced transactions on a timely basis or at all, thus hampering our opportunities for growth. In the event conditions are imposed and we fail to meet them in a timely manner, the relevant governmental authority may impose fines and, if in connection with a merger transaction, may require restorative measures, such as mandatory disposition of assets or divestiture of operations, which could have an adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Although we analyze and conduct due diligence on acquisition targets, our assessments are subject to a number of assumptions concerning profitability, growth, interest rates and company valuations and our inquiries may fail to uncover relevant information. There can be no assurance that our assessments or due diligence of and assumptions regarding acquisition targets will prove to be correct, and actual developments may differ significantly from our expectations, especially in light of the severe economic uncertainty and unpredictability caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Moreover, our plans to acquire additional businesses in the future are subject to the availability of suitable opportunities. Our competitors may also follow similar acquisition strategies and may have greater financial resources available for investments or may be willing to accept less favorable terms than we can accept, which may prevent us from acquiring businesses that we target to the benefit of our competitors. For further information regarding our acquisitions and joint ventures, see “Summary—Overview,” “Business—Material Contracts” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Acquisitions and Demerger and Other Arrangements.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is capital intensive and our capital expenditures may not generate a positive return.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is capital intensive and requires significant levels of investment. Like other companies in the fixed line, mobile and internet services sector, we must continually invest in order to develop, expand and maintain our network infrastructure. Although we maintain what we believe is a sufficient budget for capital expenditures, our business demands significant capital expenditures to improve, expand and maintain our networks and improve the scope and quality of our service, including expenditures relating to equipment and labor. We incur significant capital expenses for the deployment of new technologies, for the purchase of frequencies and the deployment of network infrastructure for our mobile operations and for our fixed line operations. In particular, obtaining access to 3.5 GHz 5G spectrum through the Dutch government auction planned for 2022 (subject to possible delays) would likely require significant capital expenditure on our part, as measured against industry benchmarks. For further discussion of the planned 2022 5G spectrum auction, see ----- “—Our existing services’ future network capacity growth may be constrained by the frequency spectrum _available to us.” With respect to fixed internet services, although we do not own our own network and are not_ responsible for investment in the passive infrastructure of the networks that we use, namely KPN’s copper, fiber WBA or optical distribution framework (“ODF”) access networks, along with the Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest fiber networks, provision of fixed internet services to our customers will require investments in customer premises equipment such as modems, routers and TV equipment. Although we do not presently anticipate a need to build our own fixed network, in order to effectively compete against our competitors in The Netherlands, it remains possible that in the future we may also need to build our own such network, for example, a fiber optic network. Such unanticipated future needs could involve significant expenditures. We may also need to make investments to provide business continuity and to meet requirements for information security and disaster recovery, all of which could require significant capital expenditures which could be further increased by applicable regulations requiring increased levels of the technical protection of telecommunications networks. In addition, costs associated with the licenses and spectrums that we need to operate our existing networks and technologies and those that we may acquire or develop in the future, as well as costs and rental expenses related to their deployment, could be significant. The amount and timing of our future capital requirements may differ materially from our current estimates due to various factors, many of which are beyond our control. See also “—Our existing services’ future network capacity growth may be constrained by the _frequency spectrum available to us.”_ Furthermore, new technologies and the use of multiple applications increasing customers’ bandwidth requirements could lead to saturation of the networks and require telecommunications operators to make additional investments to increase the capacity of their infrastructures. It cannot be guaranteed that we will continue to have sufficient resources to maintain the quality of our network and our other products and services, or to expand our network coverage, which are key elements for our strategy and growth over the long-term. Unforeseen investment expenses, an inability to generate sufficient cash flows and/or finance our capital expenditure needs at an acceptable cost or an inability to make profitable investments could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to make payments on the Notes and on the trading price of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not generate sufficient cash flow to fund our capital expenditures and ongoing operations and to service our debt obligations.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to service our debt and to finance our capital expenditure needs and operations in progress will depend on our ability to generate cash flows. We cannot provide any assurance that our business will generate sufficient cash flow from operations or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debt obligations when due, sustain our operations or meet our other capital requirements.
