In addition, the Indentures allow us to issue additional notes in the future, which could adversely impact the liquidity of the Notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Additional Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Additional Notes.”

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: The interests of the holders of the Notes and additional notes issued under the Indentures from time to time may be inconsistent.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes will be issued pursuant to the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, and the Senior Notes will be issued pursuant to the Senior Notes Indenture. Subject to certain restrictions, further series of additional notes may be issued under the Indentures which may have different terms in respect of currency, interest rate and certain other matters. Accordingly, holders of such additional notes may have interests that differ from the holders of other series of notes issued under the Indentures, including the Notes. However, holders of such additional notes will generally vote as a single class with holders of other series of notes issued under the relevant Indenture, including the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes (as the case may be), with respect to amendments, waivers or other modifications of the relevant Indenture. Accordingly, to the extent any amendment, waiver or modification is approved by the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes (as the case may be) then outstanding under the relevant Indenture (subject to the limited exceptions), all holders of Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes (as the case may be) under the relevant Indenture will be bound by such amendment, waiver or modification.

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and the applicable securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction. See ----- “Transfer Restrictions.” It is the obligation of holders of the Notes to ensure that their offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws.

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuers and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are organized outside the United States, and the business of such entities organized outside the United States is conducted outside the United States. The majority of the directors and executive officers of the Issuers and the Guarantors organized outside the United States are non-residents of the United States. Although the Issuers and the Guarantors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws or under the Indentures, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on those directors and executive officers of the Issuers and the Guarantors outside the United States. In addition, because the majority of the assets of the Issuers and Guarantors and the assets of their directors and executive officers are located outside of the United States, your ability to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S. courts will be limited. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuers and the Guarantors may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: The Indentures will not be qualified under the TIA.
Subsubsection Text: The Indentures with respect to the Notes offered hereby are not required to be, nor will they be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include or be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of the Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the Trustees or conflicting interests of the Trustees. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes.”

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. An investment in the Notes denominated in a currency other than the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among others, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to other relevant currencies because of economic, political or other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against other relevant currencies could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments. In addition, an investment in the Notes by U.S. investors may have significant tax consequences. See “Certain Tax Considerations— _Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations.”_

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Title: Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with existing Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for United States federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the applicable series of Notes previously issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes Indenture, as applicable, without being fungible with such series of Notes for United States federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined in “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal _Income Tax Considerations.”) considering the purchase of Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes sold pursuant_ to Regulation S as part of this offering of Senior Secured Notes and Senior Notes or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular United States federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such series of Notes, including with respect to the potential issuance of Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes that are not fungible with the applicable series of initial Notes issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes Indenture, as applicable, for United States federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being separately identified. In the event Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification ----- number as Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, belonging to the same series previously issued, without being fungible with such series of initial Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for United States federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests in the relevant Regulation S Global Notes (as defined herein) that form part of that series, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests in such Regulation S Global Notes on or prior to the date of issuance of such Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes, as applicable, will not be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a 144A Global Note (as defined herein) (if any) representing Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, of that same series. Such a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the relevant Regulation S Global Notes. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers,” “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Additional Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Additional Notes.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Issuers/Guarantors”) (the “(Deemed) Payments”) pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021
Subsubsection Text: (Wet bronbelasting 2021) in case the relevant Dutch Issuer/Guarantor is related (gelieerd) (within the meaning set out below) to the entity entitled to such (Deemed) Payments (voordeelgerechtigde) and: - such related recipient entity (i) is (deemed) resident in a low tax jurisdiction (laagbelastende _jurisdictie) or (ii) has a permanent establishment in such low tax jurisdiction to which the interest_ (or guarantee payment) is allocated (worden toegerekend); - the related recipient entity is not (deemed) resident in a low tax jurisdiction, in case (a) such entity is entitled to the (Deemed) Payments with the main purpose or one of the main purposes of avoiding withholding tax in the hands of another person or entity, and (b) there is an artificial arrangement or transaction, or a series of artificial arrangements or transactions. An arrangement or transaction, or series of arrangements or transactions, shall be regarded as artificial to the extent that it is not put into place for valid commercial reasons, which reflect economic reality; and/or - the related entity is from a Dutch tax perspective regarded the recipient of the (Deemed) Payments, whereas such related recipient entity is not regarded as the recipient (gerechtigde) thereof pursuant to the laws of the country in which such entity is (deemed) resident or pursuant to the laws of which such entity is established (opgericht). No additional amounts shall be payable with respect to any Note in relation to the withholding or deduction for or on account of any tax imposed or to be withheld in the Netherlands pursuant to The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Withholding Taxes.” _Related entities_ Generally, a holder of notes is considered to be related to a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor for these purposes if (i) it has a qualifying interest in a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor, (ii) a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor has a qualifying interest in such party, or (iii) a third party has a qualifying interest in both a Dutch Issuer/Guarantor and such party. For these purposes, a party is equated with any collaborating group of parties of which it forms part. A qualifying interest is an interest that allows the holder to have a decisive influence over the other party’s decisions, in such a way that it is able to determine the activities of the other party. A party is in any case considered to have a qualifying interest in another party if it (directly or indirectly) owns more than 50% of the voting rights in such other party. _Low tax jurisdictions_ A jurisdiction qualifies as a low tax jurisdiction for purposes of The Netherlands Withholding Tax Act 2021 if it is listed in an annually updated ministerial decree published by the Dutch government which includes jurisdictions (i) with a profit tax applying a statutory rate of less than 9% (updated annually based on an assessment as of October 1 of the preceding year) or (ii) included on the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions in the preceding year.

In addition, our past financial performance may not be a reliable indicator of future performance and historical trends should not be used to anticipate results or trends in future periods. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward- Looking Statements.”_

Subsubsection Title: Historical Financial Information of the Target Group
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of financial position and consolidated statement of cash flows of the Target Group presented herein are derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union and which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. (the “Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) and (ii) the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, including the accompanying notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting (the “Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the “Historical Consolidated Financial Statements”). The financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 in this Offering Memorandum is derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Financial Statements”). The audited consolidated financial statements of the Target Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 were originally approved by us on December 31, 2019. Thereafter, we have restated certain financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018, included in the 2019 Financial Statements, by restating the classification of “other receivables” to “trade receivables” for an amount of €619 thousand, “other payables” to “current other liabilities” for an amount of €68,947 thousand, “non-current other liabilities” to “other liabilities” for an amount of €2,004 thousand, “other receivables” to “other assets” for an amount of €32,629 thousand and “tax liabilities” to “liabilities held for sale” for an amount of €1,792 thousand. These restatements do not have any impact on the reported profit for the year 2018 or reported equity and an immaterial impact on the cash flow statement for 2018. As a result, we have not separately restated the financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018. See note 2.3 to the 2019 Financial Statements. In addition, we also present certain financial information of the Target Group for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 (the “LTM Financial Information”). Except as otherwise stated, the LTM Financial Information is derived by adding the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 to the audited consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income of the Target Group for the year ended December 31, 2020 and deducting the unaudited condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income of the Target Group for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. The LTM Financial Information has been presented for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. Except as stated otherwise, the LTM Financial Information is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting or in accordance with IFRS. We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) effective from January 1, 2019. As a result, leases (as lessee) that would have been classified in previous periods as operating leases are recognized in our consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2019. Under the new standard, except for short-term or low-value leases, the right to use a leased asset is recognized as an asset with a corresponding financial liability for the present value of outstanding lease payments. Assets with a finite useful life are subject to impairment testing. We have adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment ----- obligations from existing operating leases were discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and recognized as a lease liability and the right-to-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments. As a result of the application of new accounting standards and the associated impact on our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements, prospective investors should exercise particular caution when comparing our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 to our financial condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and Financial Information—The preparation of our financial statements involves judgments, estimates and assumptions, and changes in financial accounting standards may cause unexpected revenue fluctuations and affect our reported results of operations.” For a discussion of the_ effects of the adoption of IFRS 16 on our financial condition and results of operations, see “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Adoption of IFRS 16” and note 2.4 to the 2019 Financial Statements._ The selected historical consolidated financial information is qualified in its entirety by reference to, and should be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Information,” “Summary Financial _Information and Other Data,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying notes included elsewhere_ in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid) and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The _2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut)._ As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers, representing an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our combined mobile service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled €391 million, and our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million. Mobile service revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming, and our fixed line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as fixed line wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was €292 million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €637.4 million.

Subsubsection Text: Our activities primarily comprise the provision of mobile and fixed line communications services including internet, television and fixed telephony for the consumer and business market in The Netherlands. In this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” we present, among others, a revenue disaggregation by customer type. We differentiate between the following types of customers: - _B2C: this segment offers fixed and mobile services (including handset sales) to consumers. - _B2B: this segment offers fixed and mobile services (including handset sales) to entrepreneurs and enterprises. - _Other: this segment consists of other revenues such as wholesale revenues and costs related to the Target Group’s headquarters. Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Mobile and Fixed Subscriber Base
Subsubsection Text: Mobile subscribers consist of subscribers for voice services (including incoming and outgoing calls), SMS and MMS services, and mobile broadband services (smartphones, wireless internet access through a laptop, tablet, wireless router or dongle). Fixed subscribers consist of subscribers for FTTH or xDSL broadband services through one of our fixed line services, TV or telephony packages, as well as other business and Wholesale Services such as “fiber to the office” services. The evolution of our mobile and fixed subscriber bases is, and in the periods under review was, driven by market dynamics (including regulatory environment, competition-driven price evolution, demographics, technological innovation and changing customer behavior), our ability to capture new subscribers and retain existing subscribers, our acquisitions, and macroeconomic conditions. See “—Macroeconomic Developments and the Impact of COVID-19 in The Netherlands” and “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our business is concentrated in The Netherlands, and may be adversely affected by negative economic, legal or political developments in The Netherlands.” A larger_ subscriber base generally results in higher revenue, as the number of our revenue-generating customers increases. In addition, as a substantial portion of our costs are fixed, a larger subscriber base produces certain relative cost savings, as efficiencies of scale in our network reduce the costs per customer of delivering our services and providing customer support. With the acquisition of Tele2 in January 2019 and Simpel in December 2020, we have substantially increased our subscriber base by covering all consumer segments of the B2C postpaid market, particularly by offering the full range of premium to low budget products, which we believe strengthened our position as the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs. We divide our mobile subscriber base primarily into postpaid and prepaid B2C mobile and postpaid B2B mobile. In particular, we expect the Dutch B2C mobile postpaid market, which is a key segment of growth for us, to expand due to growth in postpaid SIMs, driven by prepaid to postpaid migration, increasing use of second SIMs, population growth and an increased prevalence of younger generations using mobiles phones at an early age. Similarly, we expect our B2B mobile market to grow across the three main segments: SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE. Postpaid SIMs are counted in our subscriber base as long as they have an active contract and prepaid SIMs are counted in our subscriber base as long as a SIM card is connected to our network which has had at least one chargeable event or incoming traffic event (excluding any traffic initiated by us) within the last six months. The calculation includes subscribers through wholesale resellers, as we enter into direct contractual arrangements with customers of resellers, but excludes subscribers through MVNOs, as MVNOs own their respective subscriber bases. Each connection by a subscriber represents at least one line; however, this may vary depending on circumstances, and one subscriber may have several lines (for instance, a broadband line, together with two postpaid lines). We expect our fixed subscriber base to grow due to a household growth, further FTTH penetration in The Netherlands and better quality. In this regard, in April 2021, we announced a strategic partnership with Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP, to roll-out fiber services to over one million homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on the network, which focuses on dense, urban areas in which we currently have a large mobile market share. Subsubsection Text: Tele2 ................................................................ 1,147 1,227 1,219 1,222 1,215 Ben ................................................................... 558 616 667 658 687 Simpel .............................................................. 844 976 1,039 1,030 1,100 B2C Fixed Subscribers ..........................................._ 549 619 682 661 721 T-Mobile Thuis ................................................ 241 331 444 410 522 Tele2 ................................................................ 309 287 238 252 199 B2B Mobile Subscribers ........................................._ 1,075 1,234 1,353 1,345 1,402 In recent years, the use of the internet, television and mobile services has increased in The Netherlands. We have benefited from this increase and our growth and profitability depend, in part, on the continued demand for these services in the coming years. Approximately 94% of Dutch households have fixed broadband and 128% of the Dutch population have mobile broadband in 2020 (Source: Digital Economy and Society Index _(DESI) 2020, European Commission), we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from growth in both the_ mobile and fixed broadband sectors, driven by increasing subscription rates. The Netherlands has the lowest mobile-only access rate at less than 0.04% of European households, which correlates with the fact that it has the highest take-up rate of fixed broadband in the European Union. We believe that due to our vast product offering we are able to respond to fixed broadband and to mobile-only customers. With a mobile coverage per population of over 99% for 4G and of approximately 92% for 5G, we are able to provide our clients with strong coverage based on an extensive network footprint and the highest density site grids in urban areas. See also “Industry, Competition and Market Overview.”

Subsubsection Title: Multi-brand Strategy to Address Different Customer Segments with Tailored Value Propositions
Subsubsection Text: Our multi-brand strategy has allowed us to grow across all customer segments in The Netherlands by offering different value propositions across key consumer distribution channels. We operate under the TMobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands and each of our brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated profiles. We position our T-Mobile brand as a premium brand, our Tele2 brand as a value brand and Ben and Simpel as budget brands. We are the market leader across the entire spectrum with a 42% market share in the B2C mobile based on our number of postpaid SIM subscribers. We combine strong remote direct sales through our branded websites and mobile platforms with both our own and third-party call centers, complemented by a large physical retail network of exclusive stores and distributors. In 2020, our direct and indirect online channels accounted for more than 60% of our B2C sales. We leverage these channels to offer our customers a range of service options tailored to their needs through both bundled and flexible unbundled packages, offering predictable pricing, a strong portfolio of digital channels and customer experience. Our customer services for Ben and T-Mobile have been voted number one and number two, respectively, in the Dutch telecommunications industry (Source: MarketResponse). In 2020, Umlaut ranked us as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and in 2021, they also ranked us first in their global ranking of all network providers. From 2018 to 2020, we have increased our market share in the mobile services market from 23.8% to 42.0%, respectively, consistently capturing a large majority of market net adds supported by our acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel. Our success in the mobile services market has been driven by our focused commercial strategy and customer led-approach, allowing us to significantly outperform the Dutch mobile market generally. Similarly, our market share in the B2C fixed broadband market by subscriber grew from 4.7% in 2018 to 5.7% in 2020, facilitated by our expanding and improving network footprint. This substantial increase in net adds, combined with the attractive underlying fundamentals of the Dutch telecommunications market, has resulted in an overall increase of our mobile subscriber base at a CAGR of 4.5% from 2018 to 2020 and an increase in our fixed residential broadband subscriber base at a CAGR of 11.5% over the same period.

Subsubsection Title: Bundled Offerings, Cross-selling and Migration of Postpaid Subscribers to FMC and Multiple Lines
Subsubsection Text: The competitive landscape in The Netherlands is generally characterized by tiered offerings that include lower priced entry-level products and a focus on bundled offerings, including special promotions and discounts for customers who subscribe for bundled services and, more recently and as a future trend to take into consideration, offerings for access to services under 5G networks. Our main competitors offer integrated products over their fixed line and/or cable networks, including fixed-mobile services bundles comprising mobile, fixed voice and broadband internet products, as well as 4P bundles that combine these three products with television services. Bundled services are expected to remain important and customers that have such services are less likely to switch to a different operator for all or part of the bundled services. We have used and will continue to use bundled offerings and value added services to attract new customers, and to migrate existing customers to additional services, by cross-selling broadband to our existing mobile subscriber base and upselling higher value packages. During the periods under review we have focused our efforts on cross-selling FMC services and second and third lines to postpaid subscribers, providing discounts to postpaid mobile and fixed subscribers if they sign up for a bundled offering including FMC services and multiple mobile lines. -----

Subsubsection Title: Material New Subsidiaries, Joint Ventures, Acquisitions and Other Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: _Demerger of T-Infra_ On September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our rented sites into a separate legal entity, namely Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021 known as T-Mobile Infra B.V.). Cignal Infrastructure was thereafter transferred to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date, with TMNL continuing to have full access to the contributed infrastructure through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP a joint venture of Cellnex and DTCP, and subsequently it was transferred to Cellnex Netherlands B.V. Currently, we benefit from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price Index. _Acquisition of Tele2 and Simpel_ In January 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2. The acquisition has strengthened our position in the Dutch telecommunications market, particularly in the premium mobile segment, allowing us to compete more effectively with our competitors in the Dutch market, due to enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources and significant synergy potential. Pursuant to this acquisition, we acquired approximately 1.2 million subscribers, as of January 2, 2019. On December 1, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, the largest MVNO in The Netherlands. This has helped to further consolidate our leading position in the mobile market and expand into a low budget segment of the Dutch mobile market. Pursuant to this acquisition, we acquired approximately 1.0 million subscribers, who at the time of the acquisition already used our network pursuant to a network access arrangement that Simpel had previously entered into with us. We are executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have closed Tele2’s standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings. Based on our estimates, we anticipate realizing total cost-saving synergies in connection with Tele2 and Simpel with a total run-rate synergy potential of €139 million by 2024, having already realized €116 million of synergies run-rate as of September 30, 2021. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel include reduced interconnect costs, migration of Tele2’s BSS to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad debt collections (representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon integration with TMNL), direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and the cancellation of leased telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile cross-selling, optimization of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related costs as well as legal audit and tax fees.

Subsubsection Title: Capital Expenditure and Network Upgrades
Subsubsection Text: Our historical capital expenditure is mainly driven by the acquisition of licenses of frequency spectra, which occur every eight to ten years and are a necessary capital expenditure for our mobile network. These frequencies are auctioned by the Dutch government and are generally valid for 15 to 20 years, after which the licenses are put up for auction again. The first 5G frequencies were auctioned in mid-2020 and we were able to acquire bands on the 700 MHz and 1,400 MHz frequencies for the first time as well as re-acquire our previouslyowned 2,100 MHz spectrum. As of December 31, 2020, we had the largest mobile spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands, ranging from low frequency (700 MHz) to high frequency (2,600 MHz), with no reinvestment required until 2030. We intend to participate in the new 3.5 GHz spectrum auction, which is currently expected in the second half of 2022. Our business capital expenditure primarily consists of Mobile Capital Expenditure (which represents capital expenditure relating to expansion and/or improvement of our mobile network infrastructure and is calculated as the sum of capital expenditure relating to (i) modernization of RAN to ensure full 5G capabilities ----- and the roll-out of low frequency 5G-ready bands and (ii) other expansion or improvement of our mobile network, such as in relation to quality improvement and network evolution projects and capital expenditure to increase capacity), Fixed Capital Expenditure (which represents capital expenditure necessary to maintain and expand our fixed infrastructure, and is primarily related to (i) capacity extension and upgrades of our fixed infrastructure, (ii) investments in active equipment in new roll-out areas, (iii) customer-premise equipment for new customers and (iv) quality improvements and phase out of legacy networks). IT Capital Expenditure (which represents capital expenditure relating to the ongoing IT transformation and our cloud-first strategy) and Other Capital Expenditure (which represents certain other heads of capital expenditures incurred by us, such as in relation to the acquisition and post-acquisition integration related capital expenditure as well as certain other miscellaneous heads of capital expenditure such as in relation building facilities and retail outlets). During the last three financial years, we have spent in the aggregate €337.4 million as Mobile Capital Expenditure (€79.7 million in 2018, €143.0 million in 2019, €114.7 million in 2020). We spent in the aggregate €166.4 million as Fixed Capital Expenditure (€22.3 million in 2018, €64.5 million in 2019, €79.6 million in 2020). In addition, we spent in the aggregate €124.9 million as IT Capital Expenditure (€41.6 million in 2018, €44.6 million in 2019 and €38.7 million in 2020) and in the aggregate €78.1 million as Other Capital Expenditure (€2.7 million in 2018, €38.8 million in 2019 and €36.6 million in 2020). See also “—Liquidity and Capital Resources— _Capital Expenditure” and “Summary—Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Capital Expenditure Data.”_ In particular, in addition to other factors such as the impact of adoption of IFRS 16, our business capital expenditure has resulted in an increase in our fixed assets. Our total property, plant and equipment (“PPE”) and intangible assets as of December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and as of September 30, 2021, based on acquisition costs, is summarized in the following table:

Subsubsection Text: B2C Mobile Postpaid.............................................._ 16.2 15.7 15.5 15.6 T-Mobile .......................................................... 19.5 19.2 19.1 19.3 Tele2 ................................................................ 17.0 17.4 17.5 17.9 Ben ................................................................... 10.3 10.5 10.4 10.6 Simpel .............................................................. 9.4 8.9 8.6 8.9 B2C Fixed ..............................................................._ 33.4 33.5 33.5 33.4 T-Mobile Thuis ................................................ 38.0 37.1 35.9 35.2 Tele2 ................................................................ 30.3 30.0 30.0 29.7 B2B Mobile ............................................................._ 17.2 15.1 13.7 13.0 In recent periods, our B2C mobile ARPU, including both B2C mobile postpaid segment ARPU and B2C fixed segment ARPU, have remained relatively steady. In particular, though our B2C mobile postpaid segment ARPU decreased from €16.2 in 2018 to €15.5 in 2020, it has remained relatively steady in more recent periods, at €15.7 in 2019, €15.5 in 2020 and €15.6 in the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Factors such as 5G monetization, growth of unlimited offerings, low-end rationalization initiatives, growth of valueadded services and FMC growth, are expected to keep our B2C mobile ARPU steady in the short term and also potentially support its growth over time. Our B2C fixed segment ARPU has remained stable (€33.4 in 2018, €33.5 in 2020 and €33.4 during the 12 months ended September 30, 2021, in each case on a historical pro forma basis for the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel). We intend to grow our B2C fixed segment ARPU, in particular in respect of our T-Mobile Thuis brand, by implementing a strategic shift to premium value fixed portfolio over ----- time. Similarly, though our B2B mobile segment ARPU decreased from €17.2 in 2018 to €13.7 in 2020 (on a historical pro forma basis for the acquisitions of Tele2 and Simpel), our B2B mobile segment ARPU has experienced similar stabilizing trend in more recent periods and we expect it to grow over time. The decline of ARPU in the segment can mostly be attributed to faster growth in the LE/CE segment compared to growth in smaller sized segments. Within the B2B mobile segment, ARPU in the SOHO/VSE market segment has grown recently, driven by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services and value-added services, and we believe these drivers will continue to have a positive impact on ARPU growth in our B2B segment generally. In addition, historically, the B2B mobile and in particular the SOHO/VSE segments were negatively impacted by ARPU declines driven by significant one-off effects, such as the impact of IFRS-15 and decline in roaming usage due to travel restrictions following the COVID-19 pandemic. Going forward, we do not expect these factors to negatively impact ARPUs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Macroeconomic Developments and the Impact of COVID-19 in The Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: As we operate entirely in The Netherlands, our business and results of operations are influenced by macroeconomic developments in the Dutch economy. To the extent they relate to and influence rates of consumer confidence and spending in The Netherlands, rates of Dutch unemployment, GDP growth and other macroeconomic metrics can impact the amount of money that Dutch consumers spend on our products and services and thus impact our sales and results of operations. GDP growth and other economic metrics may also correlate with rates of business investment in The Netherlands, and can thus impact our sales to business customers. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Dutch GDP increased by 1.96% in 2019, continuing its process of gradual deceleration from the average GDP growth rate of 2.4% from 2016-2018, but still significantly higher than the average GDP growth rate of 1.1% during the period from 2013-2015. Additionally, the inflation rate was on average 2.6% in 2019, well above from 1.1% in 2016-2018 and from 1.4% in 20132015. Since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, governments of many countries, including The Netherlands, have taken preventative measures to try to contain its spread. These measures have included mandatory closure of businesses, social distancing requirements and travel restrictions, which have severely diminished the level of economic activity around the world and in The Netherlands, caused significant volatility ----- in financial markets and triggered a period of global economic slowdown, the extent and duration of which remain uncertain. The COVID-19 pandemic and the multiple waves of infections that have been recorded have severely impacted the economies of the European Union, including The Netherlands. In particular, the World Bank registered a contraction for the European Union’s real GDP of 5.9% in 2020 and forecasts deeper continuing impacts on those economies dependent on international tourism as well as those dependent on international trade, as supply bottlenecks persist (Source: World Bank, Global Economic Prospects January _2021; June 2021). In The Netherlands, employment and working hours were negatively impacted, with the_ unemployment rate increasing by 1.9% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2020 and total working hours bottoming out at an aggregate loss of 7.7 average weekly hours in May of 2020 (Source: Institute of Labor _Economics, Drivers of Working Hours and Household Income Dynamics during the COVID-19 Pandemic: The Case of The Netherlands). COVID-19 caseload waves and concomitant containment measures were associated_ with exceptional declines in consumer spending in two waves in 2020, reaching 17% and 12% declines in consumer spending year-over-year in April and December of 2020, respectively (Source: Statistics _Netherlands). Eurostat has registered a contraction of the Dutch economy of 3.7% in 2020 (source: Eurostat)._ However, due to a steady vaccination drive and the resulting stimulation in economic activity, consumption and public confidence, the OECD has projected a steady rebound of the Dutch economy in 2021, with a projected GDP growth of 3.5% in 2021. For 2022, the OECD has currently forecast a growth of 3.0%. The annual average unemployment rate is expected to be 4.12% in 2021 and 4.66% in 2022. (Source: OECD). In response to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, on March 16, 2020 we temporarily closed all of our retail shops, and thereafter, beginning March 21, 2020 and in compliance with regulations and guidance issued by the Dutch government, we gradually reopened some of our retail shops in a ‘box-in shop’ format, whereby our retail shops were installed with Plexiglas walls enabling our employees and consumers to safely interact with each other. In June 2020, we reopened the entirety of our retail shops while implementing social distancing measures. On December 15, 2020, the Dutch government ordered the closure of all non-essential commercial and retail businesses in The Netherlands and, in compliance with this directive, we closed all of our retail shops for sale while remaining open for service as it qualified as essential services. In April 2021, we progressively reopened our retail stores while requiring certain social distancing and other safety measures to be observed. In addition, the self-isolation measures imposed by the Dutch government in order to combat COVID19 have resulted in a considerable increase in internet traffic, as customers increasingly relied on VoIP and OTT services while gatherings are prohibited and residents are advised to stay at home. The COVID-19 pandemic positively impacted our B2B segment, as people worked remotely, leading to an increase in calls, data usage, video-conferencing and other services requested by business customers. However, COVID-19 pandemic had a negative impact on our roaming revenues due to travel restrictions imposed on our customers by many countries and territories around the world meant that mobile roaming remained limited during this period. Our networks continue to be stable and we believe are able to cope well with the additional volume caused by increased numbers of people working from home.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions and Demerger and other Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: We have made two material acquisitions during the periods under review. The assets and operations acquired in such transactions are not fully reflected across all periods that are included in our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements. We also undertook a material demerger of infrastructure assets during this period. The impact of these acquisitions as well as the demerger should be taken into account when comparing the Historical Consolidated Financial Statements across the periods included therein. These acquisitions and the demerger consist of the following, in chronological order: - on September 1, 2018, we completed the demerger of part of our passive equipment and part of our rented sites to a separate legal entity, Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra). Subsequently, Cignal Infrastructure was transferred to Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. on January 1, 2019, and ceased to form part of our consolidated financial results from that date; ----- - on January, 2, 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2’s Dutch operations, and it has been consolidated into our financial results from that date; - on December 1, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, and it has been consolidated into our financial results from that date. Following the Acquisition, our business operations will be separated from Deutsche Telekom and run as a stand-alone business. In this regard, and at the time of completion of the Acquisition, we expect to enter into certain transitional services agreements, including with Tele2. As a result of the separation, we do not expect our cost base to change materially. In addition, going forward our business would not avail of financing from the Deutsche Telekom, and we expect to fulfil our liquidity requirements mainly from net cash generated from operating activities, the Notes, drawings under the Senior Facilities Agreement (including the RCF) and the factoring arrangements entered into by us from time to time. Pursuant to our separation from Deutsche Telekom, we expect to be able to streamline our reporting and management information systems and expect to achieve certain related efficiencies. See also “Business— Separation from Deutsche Telekom” and “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Separation from Deutsche Telekom.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Seasonality
Subsubsection Text: We regularly experience a slight seasonality in postpaid mobile revenue during two quarters, as described below, while seasonality is fairly low for our other services: - _First Quarter. Revenue in the first quarter is generally less compared to the following quarters in the financial year due to the fact that this quarter has one to two less days than the second and the fourth quarter. This only affects customers in pay-per-use voice tariffs. - _Third Quarter. Some revenue uplift is linked to the growth of out of bundle usage by postpaid mobile lines, due to customers leaving their regular residence and place of work where they have access to broadband and Wi-Fi, whereas they tend to have more limited access to Wi-Fi on vacation, increasing their data usage. This mostly affects customers having tariffs with a low data allowance and prepaid mobile lines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Adoption of IFRS 16
Subsubsection Text: The mandatory first-time application of the new the IFRS 16 (Leases) accounting standard, effective from January 1, 2019, had a material impact on our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Since expenses and cash outflows for leases are substantial elements of our earnings performance and solvency, we have taken into account the effects of IFRS 16 (Leases) when determining our financial performance indicators. On September 1, 2018, we demerged Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra), consisting primarily of passive infrastructure and site lease agreements, and subsequently transferred the entity as a dividend in kind to Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. on January 1, 2019. After the demerger, we entered into a lease agreement with Cignal Infrastructure regarding the demerged passive infrastructure and sites. As of January 1, 2019, the passive equipment previously carried at cost and the right of use assets related to the greenfield and rooftop spaces, each of which were previously accounted as indirect costs, are now accounted as leases under IFRS 16. In order to ensure maximum comparability with our previous performance indicators, we measure our operational performance on the basis of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, which is calculated as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude the impact of IFRS 16, thereby including operating lease expenses in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA in order to arrive at a closer alignment with cash EBITDA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Reporting
Subsubsection Text: We present the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements in this Offering Memorandum. After completion of the Acquisition, the Target Group may not prepare separate consolidated financial statements and we instead may report our consolidated financial results at the level of the Parent. Due to this, our future financial statements may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum. Our future financial statements could be materially different once the ----- adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Target Group’s consolidated financial statements included in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsubsection Title: Net revenue
Subsubsection Text: Net revenue relates to all revenues from the ordinary business activities of the Target Group, including revenue from rendering of mobile telecommunication services, revenue from the sales of goods and merchandise and revenue from the rendering of fixed line services. Revenues are recorded net of value-added tax and other taxes collected from customers. Value-added tax and other taxes collected are remitted to governmental authorities.

Subsubsection Text: Other operating income relates to income from intercompany charges and miscellaneous other operating income such as charge back to shareholders for employees on the Target Group’s payroll and gain in fair value of assets.

Subsubsection Text: Own capitalized costs represents capitalization of workforce cost relating to roll out and capacity expansions in our mobile and fixed network and the development of platforms for cellular sites.

Subsubsection Text: Goods and services purchased relates to expenses for raw materials and supplies, merchandise and for services purchased, such as cost of handset devices, fixed access services, roaming costs for mobile subscribers, marketing and sales costs and commission, and costs relating to energy and logistics.

Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses include legal, consulting and audit fees, claims, expenses recorded due to recognition of provisions, proceeds from sale of receivables to debt collection agencies and miscellaneous other operating expenses.

Subsubsection Title: Income taxes
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes include both our current and deferred income tax. Current tax assets or liabilities are measured at the amount expected to be paid to or recovered from the taxation authorities, using the tax rates and tax laws that have been enacted or substantially enacted at the reporting date. Current or deferred corporate income tax is recognized in our condensed consolidated interim statement of profit or loss and comprehensive income unless it arises from a transaction or economic event that has been recognized in the same year or in a different year against equity or from a business combination.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Net revenue_ Net revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €1,536.5 million, an increase of €89.7 million, or 6.2%, compared to €1,446.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Simpel, which was completed on December 1, 2020. Accordingly, revenue from Simpel was consolidated with our results for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 (contributing €88.0 million), whereas our results for the nine months ended September 30, 2020 did not consolidate any revenue from Simpel. In addition, the increase in net revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020, was, among other things, due to the increase in the subscriber base of our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile operations and our B2C fixed operations. Net revenue for our B2C segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €1,213.2 million, an increase of €136.3 million, or 12.7%, compared to €1,076.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Simpel resulting in a larger customer base, an increase in ARPU for the B2C segment during the nine months ended September 30, 2021, and the increase in subscriber base in relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile operations and our B2C fixed operations. Net revenue for our B2B segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €268.1 million, a decrease of €4.2 million, or 1.6%, compared to €263.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to growth in subscriber base in our B2B segment during these periods, partially offset by a decrease in the ARPU for the B2B segment during the nine months ended September 30, 2021 (€13.0 per month, calculated on an historical basis) as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020 (€13.7 per month, calculated on an historical basis), driven by an increase in the mix of LE/CE customer segment, which has historically generated a relatively lower ARPU. Net revenue for our other segment for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €55.1 million, a decrease of €50.8 million, or 48.0%, compared to €106.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Simpel. Prior to completion of this acquisition and during the nine months ended September 30, 2020, Simpel was the largest MVNO in The Netherlands and we shared our network with Simpel against payment of network access fees, which were recorded as other income. Upon completion of the acquisition of Simpel, such network access arrangements were terminated and no network access fees from Simpel were recorded during the nine months ended September 30, 2021. _Other operating income_ Other operating income for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €0.4 million, a decrease of €2.6 million, or 86.7% compared to €3.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to the fact that indemnification assets relating to “all-in subscriptions” contract claims was recognized during the nine months September 30, 2020 (€1.7 million). These claims relate to our prior and discontinued offer of ‘free handsets’ to consumers along with mobile subscriptions, referred to as ‘all-in subscriptions.’ In 2014 and 2016, the Supreme Court of The Netherlands ruled that such offerings were not compliant with statutory provisions on installment purchases, credit transactions and credit agreements. In this regard, multiple claims vehicles and foundations have solicited individuals to initiate mass claims against telecommunications providers who offered such all-in subscriptions, and as a result, we have recognized provisions in our financial statements for potential payout of these claims. Individual consumers were able to file their potential claim until September 1, 2019, and pursuant to an agreement reached by us in October 2020 with a joint venture organization, we have finalized processing claims from this organization as of date while others are still pending. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to ----- _Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We face risks arising from the outcome of various criminal, civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.” Own capitalized costs_ Own capitalized costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €15.7 million, an increase of €2.2 million, or 16.3%, compared to €13.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to capitalization of increased workforce costs relating to internalization of certain technology management functions, which were previous carried out by an external vendor. _Goods and services purchased_ Goods and services purchased for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €851.1 million, an increase of €68.3 million, or 8.7%, compared to €782.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to an increase in the costs of handset devices, which was primarily driven by an increase in the sales of handset devices and increase in the costs relating to fixed access services, which was primarily driven by an increase in our fixed subscriber base. _Personnel costs_ Personnel costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €126.1 million, an increase of €2.6 million, or 2.1%, compared to €123.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to an increase in provisions for future payments under the share appreciation rights scheme instituted by us. _Net impairment losses on financial assets_ Net impairment losses on financial assets for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €16.2 million, an increase of €6.1 million, or 60.4%, compared to €10.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to release of bad debt provisions during the year ended December 31, 2020, resulting from the clearance and reassessment of bad debt provision for accounts receivable balances of Tele2, upon migration of Tele2 systems to our systems and methodology. _Other operating expenses_ Other operating expenses for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €16.2 million, a decrease of €5.7 million, or 26.0%, compared to €21.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to lower legal and advisory expenses (€1.2) million and multiple individually smaller items within miscellaneous expenses during the nine months ended September 30, 2020. _EBITDA_ EBITDA for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €543.0 million, an increase of €18.0 million, or 3.4%, compared to €525.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to the increase in net revenues, driven by the acquisition of Simpel and an increase in our subscriber base, and partially offset by an increase in goods and services purchased, driven by an increase in the costs of handset devices and increases in costs relating to fixed access services. _Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses_ Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were €362.4 million, an increase of €9.8 million, or 2.8% compared to €352.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, primarily due to an increase in amortization and impairment of intangible assets (€3.1 million), and depreciation and impairment of PPE (€29.2 million), mainly driven by higher capital expenditure resulting in higher depreciation and impairment, partially offset by lower depreciation of leases (€22.4 million), mainly driven by a decrease in our lease base, including due to closure of the former Tele2 head office and dismantling of former Tele2’s mobile network sites, in each case during the nine months ended September 30, 2021 ----- _Profit from operations (EBIT)_ As a result of the factors described above, profit from operations (EBIT) for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €180.6 million, an increase of €8.2 million, or 4.8%, compared to €172.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. _Net finance costs_ Interest income for nine months ended September 30, 2021 resulted in €2.5 million, a slight decrease of €0.3 million compared to €2.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. Interest expense for nine months ended September 30, 2021 resulted in €73.0 million, a slight increase of €0.5 million, or 0.7%, compared to a loss of €72.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. As a result of the movement in the interest income and interest expense as described above, net finance costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €70.5 million, an increase of €0.8 million, or 1.1%, compared to €69.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020. _Other financial (expense)/income_ Other financial (expense)/income for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 represented an expense of €0.1 million compared to an income of €0.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of €0.3 million due to changes in the measurement of provision for transactions in foreign currencies. _Gain/(loss) from other financial activities_ Gain/(loss) from other financial activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was a loss of €0.1 million, compared to a gain of €0.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of €0.3 million due to certain changes in the measurement of provision for transactions in foreign currencies, which also resulted in an increase in other financial expenses as described above. _Net finance (expense)/income_ Net finance (expense)/income for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was an expense of €70.6 million, compared to an expense of €69.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of €1.1 million, or 1.6%, due to an increase in net finance cost partially offset by an increase in other financial expenses, as described above. _Profit/(loss) before income taxes_ As a result of the factors described above, our profit before income taxes, for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, was €110.0 million, as compared to a profit before income tax of €103.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, representing an increase of €7.0 million, or 6.8%. _Income tax income/(expense)_ Income tax income/(expense) for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was an expense of €27.6 million, compared to an expense of €16.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, an increase of €11.3 million, or 69.3%, primarily due to a tax refund of €7.8 million relating to tax filings for previous periods received from the Dutch tax authority during the nine months ended September 30, 2020, with no corresponding tax income during the nine months ended September 30, 2021. _Profit/(loss) for the period_ As a result of the factors described above, our profit/(loss) for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was €82.3 million, compared to €86.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, a decrease of €4.4 million, or 5.1%. -----

Subsubsection Title: For the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the year ended December 31, 2018
Subsubsection Text: The below table sets forth our consolidated statement of comprehensive income data for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Net revenue_ Net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €1,948.4 million, an increase of €33.5 million, or 1.7%, compared to €1,914.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to higher mobile service revenues and higher fixed services revenues, which was mainly driven by a growth in subscriber base in the B2C and B2B segments during the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition, the acquisition of Simpel, which was completed on December 1, 2020, had a positive impact on our net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 as we consolidated revenue from Simpel for the period from December 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020 (contributing €4.6 million). Net revenue for our B2C segment for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €1,459.3 million, an increase of €33.3 million, or 2.3%, compared to €1,426.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to higher mobile service revenues mainly driven by a growth in subscriber base in the B2C segment and consolidation of the revenue from Simpel for the period from December 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020. Net revenue for our B2B segment for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €354.9 million, a decrease of €49.8 million, or 12.3%, compared to €404.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to certain wholesale carrier revenues (€37.3 million) being recorded in the B2B segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 and which was subsequently recorded in the other segment during the year ended December 31, 2020. Net revenue for our other segment for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €134.3 million, an increase of €50.0 million, or 59.3%, compared to €84.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to certain wholesale carrier revenues (€37.3 million) being recorded in the B2B segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 and which was subsequently recorded in the other segment during the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was partially offset by completion of the Simpel acquisition on December 1, 2020, ----- pursuant to which, during the period from December 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020, revenue from Simpel was recorded in the B2C segment and not in the other segment as network access fees. _Other operating income_ Other operating income for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €29.5 million, an increase of €27.5 million compared to €2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily representing a gain in the fair value of the call options to acquire Simpel, pursuant to the improved outlook for Simpel post acquisition and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, as compared to the nine months ended September 30, 2020. _Own capitalized costs_ Own capitalized costs for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €18.1 million, an increase of €1.2 million, or 7.1%, compared to €16.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to capitalization of workforce costs relating to certain functions at Tele2, which post Tele2 acquisition by the Target Group, were capitalized in accordance with the accounting policies of Tele2. _Goods and services purchased_ Goods and services purchased for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €1,076.2 million, a decrease of €33.2 million, or 3.0%, compared to €1,109.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower cost relating to handset devices and lower cost of services purchased for acquiring and maintaining customers (such as marketing and sales costs and commission). _Personnel costs_ Personnel costs for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €166.8 million, a decrease of €6.4 million, or 3.7%, compared to €173.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to reduction of salaries and wages driven by, in light of the Tele2 acquisition, rationalization and reduction of our employee base during the year ended December 31, 2019. _Net impairment losses on financial assets_ Net impairment losses on financial assets for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €16.8 million, a decrease of €6.5 million, or 27.8%, compared to €23.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to a change in debt collection policy as the Target Group began applying a “no cure, no pay” policy (i.e. prolonging the collection assessment timeframe on potential write-offs), beginning from the year ended December 31, 2020. _Other operating expenses_ Other operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €29.5 million, a decrease of €13.2 million, or 30.9%, compared to €42.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to reduced advisory and consultation costs, which were higher in the year ended December 31, 2019 in light of the Tele2 acquisition and movements in relation to the recognition of provisions relating to “all-in subscriptions” contract claims, partially offset by reduction in costs relating to factoring facilities. _EBITDA_ EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €706.7 million, an increase of €121.4 million, or 20.7%, compared to €585.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the increase in net revenues, driven by higher mobile service revenues and higher fixed services revenues, increase in operating income, driven by gain in the fair value of the call options to acquire Simpel and decrease in in goods and services purchased, driven by lower cost relating to handset devices and certain services purchased. ----- _Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses_ Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses for the year ended December 31, 2020 were €475.3 million, a decrease of €42.8 million, or 8.3%, compared to €518.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower depreciation of fixed assets of Tele2 during the year ended December 31, 2020, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. _Profit from operations (EBIT)_ As a result of the factors described above, our profit from operations (EBIT) for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €231.4 million, an increase of €164.3 million compared to €67.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. _Net finance costs_ Interest income for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the year ended December 31, 2019 was flat at €3.8 million. Interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €99.0 million, an increase of €1.4 million, or 1.4%, compared to a €97.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, due to increase in our debt obligations, primarily driven by the increased borrowing under the Existing Target Group 2020 Facility to finance the Simpel acquisition. As a result of the movement in the interest income and interest expense as described above, net finance costs for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €95.2 million, an increase of €1.4 million, or 1.5%, compared to €93.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. _Other financial (expense)/income_ Other financial (expense)/income for the year ended December 31, 2020 represented an income of €0.2 million, compared to an expense of €0.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, due to changes in the measurement of provision for transactions in foreign currencies. _Gain/(loss) from other financial activities_ Gain/(loss) from other financial activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 was a gain of €0.2 million compared to a loss of €0.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, due to certain changes in the measurement of provision for transactions in foreign currencies, which also resulted in an increase in other financial expenses as described above. _Net finance (expense)/income_ Net finance (expense)/income for the year ended December 31, 2020 was an expense of €95.0 million, compared to an expense of €94.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of €0.9 million, or 1.0%, due to an increase in net finance cost partially offset by a decrease in other financial expenses, as described above. _Gain/(loss)before income taxes_ As a result of the factors described above, gain/(loss)before income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2020, was a gain of €136.4 million, as compared to a loss of €27.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing an increase of €163.4 million. _Income taxes_ Income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2020 were a benefit of €38.4 million, compared to a benefit of €22.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of €16.1 million, due to a lower effective tax rate. Primarily, as a result of losses which previously were not recognized, prior year income tax ----- benefits and the positive tax effect of changes in tax rate during the year ended December 31 2020, we recognized a lower effective tax rate during this period as compared to the year ended December 31, 2019, when the positive tax effect of changes in tax rate was partially offset by certain non-deductible expenses. _Profit/(loss) for the period_ As a result of the above factors, profit/(loss) for the year ended December 31, 2020 was €174.8 million, compared to a loss of €4.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of €179.5 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
