MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Net revenue_ Net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €1,914.9 million, an increase of €594.3 million, or 45.0%, compared to €1,320.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the acquisition of Tele2, which was completed on January 2, 2019. Accordingly, revenue from Tele2 was consolidated with our results for the year ended December 31, 2019 (contributing €597.0 million), whereas our results for the year ended December 31, 2018 did not consolidate revenue from Tele2. In addition, the increase in net revenue for year ended December 31, 2019, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2018, was, among other things, due to the increase in our subscriber base in relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C mobile operations and T-Mobile Thuis brand in our B2C fixed operations, partially offset by a slight decrease in our B2C Mobile postpaid ARPU during the same period (from €17.6 per month during the year ended December 31, 2018 to €17.2 per month during the year ended December 31, 2019, in each case calculated on an historical basis and excluding the impact of the Tele2 B2C Mobile postpaid ARPU). Net revenue for our B2C segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €1,426.0 million, an increase of €477.9 million, or 50.4%, compared to €948.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to our acquisition of Tele2 resulting in a larger customer base (an addition of approximately 1.2 million subscribers, as of January 2, 2019 and a revenue of €336.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019) and the increase in subscriber base in relation to our T-Mobile and Ben brands in our B2C ----- mobile operations and T-Mobile Thuis brand in our B2C fixed operations, partially offset by a slight decrease in our B2C mobile postpaid ARPU during the same period, as described above. Net revenue for our B2B segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €404.7 million, an increase of €151.1 million, or 59.6%, compared to €253.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 primarily due to our acquisition of Tele2 resulting in a larger customer base, partially offset by a decrease in our B2B mobile ARPU during the same period (from €18.4 per month during the year ended December 31, 2018 to €15.1 per month during the year ended December 31, 2019, in each case calculated on an historical basis and excluding the impact of the Tele2 B2B mobile ARPU for the relevant period). Net revenue for our other segment for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €84.3 million, a decrease of €34.7 million, or 29.1%, compared to €118.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 primarily due to the elimination of certain revenue streams from Tele2, such as in relation to handset revenue and interconnection charges, which we gradually eliminated pursuant to the acquisition of Tele2 in January 2, 2019. _Other operating income_ Other operating income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €2.0 million, a decrease of €8.4 million, or 80.7%, compared to €10.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a decrease in miscellaneous other operating income, driven by the demerger of T-Infra, which became effective on January 1, 2019 and resulted in elimination of site income from the other MNOs who previously used the demerged assets, partially offset by our acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019, which resulted in a release of certain provisions relating to network sharing with Tele2. _Own capitalized costs_ Own capitalized costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €16.9 million, an increase of €7.7 million, or 83.7%, compared to €9.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily driven by the Tele2 acquisition and the resulting increase in capitalization of increased workforce costs. _Goods and services purchased_ Goods and services purchased for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €1,109.4 million, an increase of €328.1 million, or 42.0%, compared to €781.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the acquisition of Tele2 and the consequent increase in our subscriber base which increased our goods and services purchased and an increase in our rental and leasing costs pursuant to the demerger of TInfra. _Personnel costs_ Personnel costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €173.2 million, an increase of €69.5 million, or 67.0%, compared to €103.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an increase in salaries and wages (€59.3 million) and an increase in social security contributions (€7.6 million) driven by an increase in our employee base due to the acquisition of Tele2. _Net impairment losses on financial assets_ Net impairment losses on financial assets for the year ended December 31, 2019 remained relatively flat at €23.3 million compared to €23.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. _Other operating expenses_ Other operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €42.7 million, an increase of €30.3 million, compared to €12.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to increase in legal, consulting and audit fees miscellaneous other expenses driven by the Tele2 acquisition. ----- _EBITDA_ EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €585.3 million, an increase of €165.7 million, or 39.5%, as compared to €419.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the increase in net revenues, driven by the acquisition of Tele2 and increase in our subscriber base, which was offset by an increase in goods and services purchased and personnel costs, in each case driven by the acquisition of Tele2. _Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses_ Depreciation, amortization and impairment losses for the year ended December 31, 2019 were €518.1 million, an increase of €307.1 million compared to €211.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an increase in amortization and impairment of intangible assets (€77.2 million) and depreciation and impairment of PPE (€118.3 million), in each case during the year ended December 31, 2019 and driven by the Tele2 acquisition. _Profit from operations (EBIT)_ As a result of the factors described above, profit from operations (EBIT) for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €67.1 million, a decrease of €141.5 million, or 67.8%, compared to €208.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. _Net finance costs_ Interest income for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €3.8 million, an increase of €3.7 million compared to €0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the Tele2 merger and the resulting increase in interest income relating to site sharing receivables. Interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €97.6 million, an increase of €95.6 million compared to €2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the increase in shareholder loan borrowed by us from Deutsche Telekom and the impact of adoption of IFRS 16, beginning from January 1, 2019. As a result of the movement in the interest income and interest expense as described above, net finance costs for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €93.8 million, an increase of €91.9 million compared to €1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. _Other financial expense_ Other financial expense for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €0.3 million, as compared to €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, due to losses from transactions in foreign currency. _Gain/(loss) from other financial activities_ Loss from other financial activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 was €0.3 million, as compared to €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of €0.1 million due to losses from transactions in foreign currency, which also resulted in an increase in other financial expenses as described above. _Results from financial activities_ Results from financial activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 was a loss of €94.1 million, compared to a loss of €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, an increase of €92.0 million, primarily due to an increase in net finance cost, as described above. ----- _Profit/(loss) before income taxes_ As a result of the factors described above, profit/loss before income taxes, for the year ended December 31, 2019, was a loss of €27.0 million, as compared to a profit of €206.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, representing an increase of €233.6 million. _Income taxes_ Income taxes for the year ended December 31, 2019 were a benefit of €22.3 million, compared to an expense of €113.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, a variation of €136.2 million, due to a loss before tax and a positive tax effect of changes in tax rate, partially offset by certain non-deductible expenses, during the year ended December 31, 2019, as compared to a profit before tax and impairment due to the adjustment of future tax rate during the year ended December 31, 2018. _Result for the year_ As a result of the factors described above, result for the year ended December 31, 2019 was a loss of €4.7 million, compared to a profit of €92.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, a decrease of €97.3 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Cash flow from operating activities_ We generated an aggregate amount of €581.6 million of cash from our operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to €429.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in cash generation from operating activities is primarily attributable to an increase in operating profits (€164.3 million), change in working capital (€50.0 million) and increased income tax receipts (€24.6 million), partially offset by certain non-cash adjustments (€85.7 million). _Cash flow used in investing activities_ We used an aggregate amount of €695.2 million of cash in our investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to €481.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in cash used in investing activities is primarily attributable to increased investments in intangible assets (€158.3 million), such as 5G spectrum, and payment of consideration for the acquisition of Simpel, which was fully funded pursuant to a long-term intercompany loan from Deutsche Telekom. _Cash flow from/(used in) financing activities_ We generated an aggregate amount of €138.7 million of cash from our financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to a cash outflow of €97.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in cash generated from financing activities is primarily attributable to proceeds from the long-term intercompany loan from Deutsche Telekom (€270.0 million), dividend payments in year ended 2019 with no corresponding payment in the year ended December 31, 2020 (€57.7 million), partially offset by increased lease payments relating to leased assets during the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2019 (€104.2 million).

MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Cash flow from operating activities_ We generated €429.8 million of cash from our operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to €394.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in cash generation from operating activities is primarily attributable to increase in operating profits as a result of the merger with Tele2 (€362.4 million). _Cash flow used in investing activities_ We used €481.4 million of cash in our investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to a cash outflow of €145.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in cash used in investing activities is primarily attributable to partial payment for the acquisition of Tele2 (€196.7 million) and investments in PPE (€129.3 million), driven by increased capital expenditure in our network. _Cash flow from financing activities_ We used €97.3 million of cash in our financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to a cash outflow of €505.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The decrease in cash used in financing activities is primarily attributable to repayment of long-term intercompany payables, such as repayment of certain financing facilities we previously borrowed from Deutsche Telekom (€500 million) during the year ended December 31, 2018 with no corresponding repayment by us during the year ended December 31, 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Working Capital
Subsubsection Text: We define working capital as current assets less current liabilities. This financial measure represents our operating liquidity. As of September 30, 2021, we had a working capital of €28.7 million, compared to a negative working capital of €85.4 million as of December 31, 2020 and a working capital of €142.5 million as of December 31, 2019 and €444.0 million as of December 31, 2018. The movement in our working capital across the periods under review generally reflects the significant growth of our business in such periods. In particular, negative working capital results from our business model and financial structure, that we believe to be typical for telecommunications service providers and is not a barrier to the normal operation of our business. The following table shows our working capital as of the dates indicated:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our liquidity requirements consist mainly of debt servicing requirements, investments in bolt-on acquisitions, Mobile Capital Expenditure and Fixed Infrastructure Capital Expenditure. Historically, our principal sources of liquidity have been our net cash generated from operating activities, share capital increases, factoring arrangements entered into by us and borrowings under our financing arrangements, including financing facilities from Deutsche Telekom. Going forward, in addition to net cash generated from operating activities, we expect our principal sources of liquidity to include the Notes, drawings under the Senior Facilities Agreement (including the RCF) and the factoring arrangements entered into by us from time to time. RCF1 under the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for an aggregate principal amount of up to €500.0 million in revolving credit, and RCF2 under the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for an aggregate principal amount of up to €200.0 million in revolving credit, both of which were undrawn as of September 30, 2021. Subject to certain exceptions and conditions, each of RCF1 and RCF2 may be borrowed, repaid and reborrowed thereunder at any time in accordance with the Senior Facilities Agreement. For further information, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.” After the completion of the Transactions, we will have €800.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes outstanding, €550.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes outstanding and €2,400.0 million in aggregate principal amount of outstanding loans under the Senior Facilities Agreement (excluding amounts drawn by us from time to time under RCF1 and RCF2), in addition to certain other financial indebtedness as described under “Capitalization.” The Issuers are holding companies with no material operations or assets of their own. As a result, the Issuers will primarily depend on the cash flow generated by the operating subsidiaries of the Group and paid to the Issuers by way of interest payments under, or repayments of, the relevant intercompany loans or otherwise ----- to meet their obligations, including their respective obligations under the Notes and the Senior Facilities Agreement. The relevant Issuer’s ability to pay cash interest on the Notes offered hereby will be determined by its cash available for debt service. As of September 30, 2021, after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, the Issuers and the Guarantors would have had €4,528.4 million in aggregate principal amount of third-party debt, including €760.7 million of lease liabilities under IFRS 16 and €17.7 million in respect of our factoring facilities. While we believe we have sufficient liquidity and capital resources to meet our current operating requirements, our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent on a variety of factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled “Risk Factors.” For further information, see the section titled “Capitalization.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Capital Expenditure
Subsubsection Text: Our business capital expenditure consists of: - Mobile Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure relating to expansion and/or improvement of our mobile network infrastructure and is calculated as the sum of capital expenditure relating to (i) modernization of RAN to ensure full 5G capabilities and the roll-out of low frequency 5G-ready bands and (ii) other expansion or improvement of our mobile network, such as in relation to quality improvement and network evolution projects and capital expenditure to increase capacity. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we incurred Mobile Capital Expenditure of €79.7 million, €143.0 million and €114.7 million, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur Mobile Capital Expenditure of approximately €103 million. Since the year ended December 21, 2018, we have continued with our initiatives to upgrade our mobile network, primarily through the installation of active antennas on the 1800MHz and 2600MHZ time division duplex bands. In particular, during the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, we significantly increased our Mobile Capital Expenditure, primarily in relation to the preparation of the 5G rollout on the low band and adding extra capacity and coverage by preparing for introducing the 800MHz band into use. During the current period, the main focus of our Mobile Capital Expenditure has been in relation to the continuing rollout of the low bands 700/800/900Mhz networks and ramping up the 1800/2100Mhz hardware replacement. - Fixed Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure necessary to maintain and expand our fixed infrastructure, and is primarily related to (i) capacity extension and upgrades of our fixed infrastructure, (ii) investments in active equipment in new roll-out areas, (iii) customer-premise equipment for new customers and (iv) quality improvements and phase out of legacy networks. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we incurred Fixed Capital Expenditure of €22.3 million, €64.5 million and €79.6 million, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur Fixed Capital Expenditure of approximately €106 million, Prior to the year ended December 31, 2019, we had a relatively small fixed network. With the acquisition of Tele2 on January 2, 2019, we expanded our owned base of fixed network infrastructure. Since then, along with the growth of our fixed subscriber base, we have sought to expand our fixed network, and one of the key drivers of increase in our Fixed Capital Expenditure during the periods under discussion, has been in relation to customer-premise equipment for new customers. In addition, our Fixed Capital Expenditure initiatives have also been focused on addition of capacity in respect of our T-Mobile Thuis network so as to accommodate the continued growth of our fixed network subscribers, as well as improving the quality, and where appropriate, phasing-out of legacy fixed networks. - IT Capital Expenditure, which represents capital expenditure relating to the ongoing IT transformation and our cloud-first strategy. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we incurred IT Capital Expenditure of €41.6 million, €44.6 million and €38.7 million, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur IT Capital Expenditure of approximately €44 million. Since the year ended December 31, 2018, our IT Capital Expenditure initiatives have been focused on the implementation of customer relationship management or “CRM”-related upgrades to our IT systems and infrastructure, including digitization initiatives to supports our B2C and B2B segments. In addition, since the year ended December 31, 2019, we have implemented a new vertical sourcing model, so as to move our IT systems to a cloud-based network. - Other Capital Expenditure, which represents certain other heads of capital expenditures incurred by us, such as in relation to the acquisition and post-acquisition integration related capital ----- expenditure as well as certain other miscellaneous heads of capital expenditure such as in relation building facilities and retail outlets. During the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2019, we incurred Other Capital Expenditure of €2.7 million, €38.8 million and €35.9 million, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2021 we expect to incur Other Capital Expenditure of approximately €36 million. The higher Capital Expenditure from 2019 onwards is primarily in relation to the integration of our Tele2 acquisition. In relation to the Tele2 acquisition, which we completed on January 2, 2019, the key focus of capital expenditure was in relation to postacquisition integration initiatives, particularly in relation to increasing our mobile network to accommodate all Tele2 traffic and subscribers and to phase-out the Tele2 mobile network. In relation to the Simpel acquisition, which we completed on December 1, 2020, our capital expenditure was relatively limited. In connection with the Acquisition, we expect to incur capital expenditure under the Transition Services Agreement, particularly in relation to the separation of our management functions from Deutsche Telekom, ring-fencing of our systems and operations, obtaining of new licenses and entering into new contracts, and the migration of some of our operation systems to an independent network. See also “Summary—Summary Financial _Information and Other Data—Capital Expenditure Data.”_ For the year ended December 31, 2021, we expect to incur a total capital expenditure of approximately €289 million. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Working capital as of September 30, 2021 was €28.7 million, an increase of €114.1 million, compared to negative working capital of €85.4 million as of December 31, 2020. The increase of our working capital was primarily due to lower inventory as a result of the global chip shortage and a lower factoring balance. Working capital as of December 31, 2020 was negative €85.4 million, a decrease of €227.9 million compared to a working capital of €142.5 million as of December 31, 2019. The decrease in our working capital was primarily due to the change in trade and other payables following the recognition of an accrual for payment of the acquisition of the 700Mhz spectrum. ----- Working capital as of December 31, 2019 was €142.5 million, a decrease of €301.6 million, or 67.9%, compared to a working capital of €444.0 million as of December 31, 2018. The decrease of our working capital was primarily due to increased trade receivables and the change in trade payables and lease liabilities.

Subsubsection Title: Factoring Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we also enter into factoring arrangements in respect of receivables owed to us. These receivables include both telecom charges already due and receivables from sales of handsets to customers payable over a period of up to two years. The terms of our existing factoring agreements between 2022 and 2023. The factoring arrangements entered into by us typically involve (a) the transfer of substantially all risks and rewards with the involvement of structured entities, (b) the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining with us without the involvement of structured entities or (c) the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining with us and with the involvement of structured entities. As of September 30, 2021, our factoring facilities were of an amount of €240.0 million. See also “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangement—Factoring and Receivables Financing Facilities” and “Capitalization.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2021, we have provided certain bank guarantees to secure the performance of our obligations, among others, under our licenses and supplier contracts. As of September 30, 2021, we have issued bank guarantees in the amount of €3.0 million (December 31, 2020: €3.6 million). Further, as of September 30, 2021, we have also entered into certain purchase commitment contracts, including in relation to inventories (including handsets) and property, plant and equipment resulting in commitments of €182.7 million (December 31, 2020: €214.2 million. Further, we have entered into partnership agreements with Primevest and Open Dutch Fiber to roll-out Fiber-to-the-Home (“FTTH”) throughout The Netherlands. Pursuant to the partnership agreement with Primevest, the first cluster, Segbroek in The Hague, was delivered in November 2019. Under the partnership agreement with Primevest, we have a minimum commitment of 10 years to pay a fixed percentage of the homes passed (amounting to €5.4 million) for the period beyond the exclusivity period (after year three) and until year 10 for this sub-cluster. We entered into a partnership agreement with Open Dutch Fiber on April 1, 2021. This partnership agreement is over an initial 20-year period with a minimum commitment to pay for a fixed percentage of the homes passed for the period beyond the exclusivity (after year one per cluster). For risks associated with our off-balance sheet arrangements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to _Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We are and may in the future, become a party to certain performance bonds, guarantees or other off-balance sheet arrangements that may have a current or future effect on our financial condition, revenue or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest rates or indexation, could affect our income or the value of financial instruments held. The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable parameters. We face a low market risk regarding our financial instruments. Our overall risk management program focuses on minimizing uncertainty in financial markets and the potential adverse effects on our financial performance. For further details on our market risk management, refer to note 32 in our Audited Financial Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 and note 9 in our Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Credit Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to which we are exposed if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations. This risk arises principally from receivables from customers. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to the following risks related to the use of financial instruments: - market risk; - credit risk; - liquidity risk; - foreign currency risk; and ----- - interest rate risk. Our supervisory and management boards of directors have overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of our risk management framework. Our risk management policies are designed to identify and analyze the risks undertaken by us, define appropriate risk limits and controls, and monitor risks and the adherence to limits. Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and in our activities. We, through our management standards and procedures, aim to develop a disciplined and constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and obligations.

Subsubsection Title: Liquidity Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet financial obligations as they fall due. Our approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that we will always have sufficient liquidity to meet our liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation. We apply a prudent policy to cover our liquidity risks, based on maintaining sufficient cash and marketable securities as well as the availability of sufficient financing through credit facilities to settle market positions. Our available cash and equivalents as of September 30, 2021, were €153.9 million, compared to €169.2 million as of December 31, 2020, €143.9 million as of December 31, 2019 and €293.0 million as of December 31, 2018. Net cash generated from operating activities during the nine months ended September 30, 2021 was positive in the amount of €293.7 million, compared to a positive amount of €581.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, a positive amount of €429.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 and a positive amount of €394.0 million during the year ended December 31, 2018. With respect to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is foreseeable that the general situation of the markets where we operate could lead to a general increase in liquidity tensions in the Dutch economy, as well as a potential contraction in the credit market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Balances as of December 31, 2020 take bad debt allowances into account. For a consistent disclosure, trade receivables as of December 31, 2019 were aligned by €59.6 million bad debt allowance for amortized costs (“AC”) and €12.4 million for fair value through other comprehensive income (“FVOCI”). (2) Reclassification of €7.3 million from category “continuing involvement” to AC as of December 31, 2019, in order to provide for more precise presentation and consistency with the balances as of December 31, 2020. We have no significant concentrations of credit risk and maintain policies to ensure that sales are made to customers with an adequate credit history. Our clients primarily consist of consumers and businesses with low average balances which are regularly reviewed. When necessary, these consumers are disconnected from service when no payment is received. Credit risk is taken into account through a combination of specific and general valuation allowances. We have policies to limit exposure to risks assumed in respect to customers and financial institutions, exposure to risk of recovering receivables and loans is managed as part of our ordinary activities. We have policies to ensure that sales of products on a wholesale basis are made to customers, including both B2B and B2C customers, with an adequate credit history. Several debt collection agencies are commissioned to collect ----- outstanding receivables and inform us about the status of doubtful debts. This valuation is done by the agencies based on complex models taking various indications into account. To measure the expected credit losses, trade receivables and contract assets have been grouped based on shared credit risk characteristics and the days past due. The contract assets relate to unbilled work in progress and have substantially the same risk characteristics as the trade receivables for the same types of contracts. We have therefore concluded that the expected loss rates for trade receivables are a reasonable approximation of the loss rates for the contract assets. The expected loss rates are based on the payment profiles of sales over a period of 12 to 45 months, depending on the segment, and the corresponding historical credit losses experienced within this period. The historical loss rates are adjusted to reflect current and forward-looking information on macroeconomic factors affecting the ability of the customers to settle the receivables. Our maximum exposure to credit risk from fair value at profit or loss at December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and September 30, 2021 is equal to the carrying amounts. With respect to the COVID-19 pandemic, we consider that there was no significant impact on our credit risk and financial assets as of September 30, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: INDUSTRY, COMPETITION AND MARKET OVERVIEW Overview
Subsubsection Text: Within the Dutch telecommunications industry, we operate across two markets, providing both mobile and fixed connectivity services to consumers and businesses. While we began as a mobile-only business, we have now established ourselves as a challenger in the fixed connectivity services market, with fixed broadband internet as our core fixed product, in addition to fixed telephony and television services. We are one of three mobile network operators in The Netherlands, each of which holds a strong presence in the mobile and fixed connectivity services markets. Other players in our industry include mobile virtual network operators (“MVNO”) and infrastructure providers, such as independent tower companies. We operate in a dynamic regulatory environment to which we must be continually responsive and innovative. Driven by organic and inorganic growth, we are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: _PresseBox, Five in a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut )._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dutch Real GDP Growth in European context
Subsubsection Text: _Real GDP Growth (actual and forecast) Sources: Eurostat, International Monetary Fund (April 2021)_ Netherlands European France United Germany Italy Union Kingdom 17-19A 21E-26E _Sources: Eurostat, International Monetary Fund (April 2021)_ ----- The Netherlands is the second largest exporter of goods and services within the European Union (source: Eurostat, October 2021)._ Agricultural production represents approximately 16% of total exports, which makes the Dutch economy the second largest agricultural exporter in the world and the largest in Europe (source: Eurostat). Price growth in The Netherlands has remained low and relatively stable, with an annual inflation rate of 1.1% in 2020, compared to 2.6% in 2019 (source: De Nederlandsche Bank (“DNB”), March 2021). The decrease is mainly attributed to reduced consumption in 2020 caused by the containment measures that were taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic (source: OECD). The inflation rate is projected to increase to 1.5% over the course of 2021. This relatively stable increase is a result of higher oil prices on the one hand and substantial adjustments to household expenditures on the other hand, with the impacts effectively cancelling one another. Inflation is expected to rise to 2.2% in 2022 and 1.5% in 2023, in line with developments that would be expected in economic recovery _(source: European Commission, November 2021)._ Dutch unemployment rates have improved, declining from a peak of 7.4% in 2014 to a low of 3.4% in 2019 before increasing to 3.8% in 2020, due to the fast implementation of policy support such as wage subsidies, deferred tax expenses and loan guarantees for firms, but these rates remain low overall compared to other jurisdictions (sources: OECD, World Bank).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dutch unemployment rate
Subsubsection Text: 7.4% 7.2% 6.9% 5.8% 6.0% 5.0% 5.0% 4.8% 4.4% 3.4% 3.7% 3.8% 3.8% 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 _Source: World Bank_ The Netherlands has recovered from challenging macroeconomic conditions in the past, most recently from the 2008 global financial crisis. Following a four-year period of economic growth from 2003 to 2007 _(source: World Bank), in 2008 The Netherlands entered a recession following the global economic slowdown_ at the time. Consequently, The Netherlands’ real GDP declined by 3.7% in 2009, with the unemployment rate not peaking until 2014 at 7.4%. This decline was partially mitigated by a series of stimulus measures taken by the Dutch government in 2008 and 2009 to stabilize the economy. The two stimulus plans, amounting to €6 billion and €13.754 billion respectively, aimed to bolster domestic sectors and improve social and unemployment policies. The efforts translated into positive economic growth over the subsequent years, however growth stagnated with a further recession in 2012, caused by low export growth and a decrease in domestic spending (source: Statistics Netherlands (Central Bureau voor de Statistiek)).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Netherlands is the sixth largest economy in the European Union, with a gross domestic product (“GDP”) of €800 billion in 2020 (source: Eurostat, October 2021), and the 10[th] most populated country in the region, with an estimated population of 17.5 million inhabitants in 2020 (source: Eurostat, October 2021). In 2020, Dutch GDP declined by 3.8%, less than the European Union average of 6.0% (source: Eurostat) as a result of the COVID-19-related lockdowns imposed by Dutch authorities. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Dutch economy consistently grew faster than the European Union average for the past four years. Dutch GDP growth has been driven by a combination of factors, led by private consumption, investment and international trade. The Netherlands has been moderately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, timely fiscal support and existing digital infrastructure reduced the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Eighty percent of the decrease in output caused by the COVID-19 pandemic in the first half of 2020 was recouped towards the end of 2020. This was mainly attributed to the resilience of manufacturing. Export of services in 2020 was 17% lower than in 2019 (source: Bureau for Economic Policy Analysis (“CPB”) (Centraal Planbureau)). Despite a contraction of 3.7% of the Dutch economy during 2020, current economic analyses project a strong recovery. The OECD estimates an annual growth rate of 3.5% in 2021, 3.0% in 2022 and 1.8% in 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: History and regulatory changes
Subsubsection Text: As a result of liberalization initiatives of the telecommunications sector mandated by various European Commission Directives and WTO commitments, the Dutch telecommunications market officially has moved from a closed, restricted, and virtually monopolized sector to an open market structure in 1997. ----- Prior to 1990, the Royal Dutch PTT (now known as KPN) held a monopoly position on the installation of telecommunication networks and the provision of telecommunication services. Liberalization was gradually imposed over the following seven years and after its privatization in 1989 and listing in 1994. In 1995, an additional Global System for Mobile communication (“GSM”) license in the mobile segment was awarded to Libertel (now known as VFZ). In 1996/1997, the liberalization of the fixed segment was initiated by opening up fixed infrastructure. Two national licenses were awarded to Telfort and Enertel along with KPN as the incumbent and about 1,400 regional infrastructure licenses were awarded to approximately 160 other companies. In 1998, digital cellular system licenses at 1,800 MHz were awarded to Telfort, Teledanmark/Proximus, which was launched as Ben and is now part of TMNL, and France Telecommunications, which was launched as Federa and was bought by TMNL in 2007. These market participants all expanded their product offerings, introduced new technologies and enhanced the telecommunications market. The Dutch telecommunications sector has experienced multiple instances of consolidation. In 2008, three of the largest cable operators – Home, Casema and Multikabel – formed Ziggo, which eventually was acquired by Liberty Global. Subsequently, Liberty Global formed in The Netherlands a joint venture with Vodafone, creating the large national converged cable operator VFZ. A condition of the European Commission’s regulatory approval of this joint venture was that Vodafone had to divest its Dutch fixed line broadband business, Thuis, which was acquired by TMNL in December 2016. Deutsche Telekom Group originally entered the Dutch telecommunications market through its acquisition of operator Ben Nederland Holding B.V. in 2002 and Orange Nederland N.V., Orange Nederland Breedband B.V. in 2007, and later acquired the Dutch operations of Swedish MNO Tele2 Sverige AB in January 2019. Today, TMNL, KPN and VFZ are the major operators in the country. Following the global financial crisis of 2009 and the takeover attempt by América Móvil of KPN in 2012, the Dutch government’s view on a fully open market changed slightly. The government made various regulatory commitments to protect Dutch consumers and foster healthy competition. In 2011, The Netherlands became the first European country to pass net neutrality legislation, preventing leading market operators from charging consumers extra for certain data traffic. In 2019, the Dutch industry regulator, Netherlands Authority for Consumers and Markets (“ACM”), through guidance detailed a framework to prevent bottlenecks in FTTHrollout, therein highlighting options such as joint investment and temporary protection at municipal level for first movers. The objectives of consumer and technology protection for the vital telecommunications sector also has resulted in a revised Telecommunication Sector Act, passed on May 19, 2020, with the purpose of further protecting Dutch national security and public order. Under this reform, the Minister of Economic Affairs and Climate must be notified if a party intention to acquire ‘a controlling interest’ in a ‘telecom party’ if such interest results in ‘relevant influence’ in the Dutch telecommunications sector. If an acquisition leads to disproportionate influence over Dutch national security and public order, the Minister can prohibit the transaction. Although wholesale regulation which required operators to sign commercial agreements to gain access to KPN’s fixed network was repealed in 2020, the Dutch telecommunications supervisory board (ACM) is considering whether to reinforce the legislation after reviewing it this year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dutch Telecommunications Infrastructure Mobile infrastructure market
Subsubsection Text: The Dutch mobile telecommunications infrastructure ecosystem comprises three mobile network operators (“MNO”) that own their networks, approximately 30 active mobile virtual network operators (“MVNO”) as well as infrastructure companies. Many telecommunications operators and smaller tower companies across The Netherlands are executing, or considering, tower network sales to other operators and independent telecommunications infrastructure tower companies. The major independent tower company in The Netherlands is Cellnex, which offers network as a service, allowing customers to operate their own networks, without maintaining own passive network infrastructure, by paying a flat fee per site or a variable cost per gigabyte (“GB”) consumed. Cellnex builds and maintains the distributed antenna system (“DAS”), to which the MNOs connect. Cellnex entered the Dutch market in 2016 with its acquisition of Protelindo and Shere Group in 2016, as well as Alticom in 2017. On September 1, 2018, TMNL carved out its tower business by way of a legal demerger (juridische splitsing) to Cignal Infrastructure. As part of a later transaction, Cignal Infrastructure was transferred to Cellnex Netherlands B.V. T-Mobile Netherlands maintains access to Cellnex’s ----- passive infrastructure elements through a master services agreement. Cellnex now operates a total of 4,314 sites, with 180 new sites to be rolled out in the next seven years. VFZ owns its portfolio of towers of approximately 3,000 sites. The three MNOs – TMNL, KPN and VFZ – have been rolling out 4G technology since mid-2012 or early 2013 and are collectively offering 4G coverage in 99% of the country in terms of both geography and population. All three MNOs provide 5G services, following an early launch by VFZ in April 2020 with the help of Ericsson’s dynamic spectrum sharing technology which enables 5G activation with existing frequency bands on the 1,800 MHz band, KPN and TMNL launched their respective 5G services in July 2020, following the first auction of 5G on the 700 MHz band. The auction covered 700 MHz, 1,400 MHz and 2,100 MHz bands and raised a total of €1.23 billion. In terms of allocation of frequency rights between the dominant market players, TMNL secured 70 MHz and KPN and VFZ 75 MHz each. All MNOs have since expanded their 5G networks, with VFZ reporting in July 2020 that it had reached a population coverage of more than 80% on its 5G network. In October 2020, TMNL reported that its 5G mobile network reached 90% of the Dutch population, making it the first MNO to provide nationwide 5G coverage. Finally, in April 2021, KPN estimated that their 5G network reached approximately 72% of the Dutch population. Further 5G services may be offered after the auction in the latter half of 2022 of the 3.5 GHz band, which is currently used by the Dutch government for intelligence communications and by a satellite telecommunications company for safety communications at sea.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Overview of Dutch spectrum allocation
Subsubsection Text: _Note: Based on used frequencies only, excluding guard bands. 10 MHz has been excluded for TMNL and KPN, respectively, on the 2,600 MHz band as this represents unused frequencies. VFZ currently offers 5G on the 1,800 MHz band, using DSS. Based on 2020 mobile SIMs (postpaid, prepaid and B2B), TMNL including Tele2 and Simpel.
