Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Fixed infrastructure market
Subsubsection Text: The Netherlands has one of the highest fixed broadband penetrations in Europe, with 97% of all households having internet in 2020 (source: Eurostat). DSL, hybrid fiber coaxial (“HFC”) and fiber networks compete on a cross-platform basis. Fixed broadband connections have increased by 13.3% between 2013 and 2020 and fiber connections have increased by more than a factor of three over the same period. HFC connections increased by 12.9% and DSL decreased by 19.7% (source: ACM Monitor; Publicly available sources). DSL connections are falling as consumers move to next-generation networks (“NGN”), namely fiber to the home (“FTTH”) or HFC, which are able to deliver higher speed and quality. In 2020, about 49% of the fixed ----- broadband connections provided households with data above 100 Mb/s (source: ACM). This number has continuously increased over the years due to new technologies and infrastructure as well as increased consumer demand, not least during the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns. FTTH and HFC have become the main focus for Dutch operators in recent years, as demonstrated by the extensive rollout of fiber optic network. The Netherlands has taken a collaborative approach with municipalities when building out fiber networks. As a result of operators partaking in the rollout of NGN networks and phasing out copper networks, the number of FTTH networks installed grew from 517,000 to almost 1,600,000 in 2020, representing an increase of 206% (source: ACM Monitor). As of 2020, the number of households passed with FTTH amounted to approximately 3.67 million, representing approximately 46% of all households in The Netherlands (source: ACM Monitor). Approximately 3.33 million of the houses passed are on the KPN and DELTA Fiber Nederland B.V. (“DELTA Fiber”) network. _Evolution of installed fiber (in millions of lines)_ 3.3 4.09 1.76 1.6 2.8 2.6 2.6 2.7 2.5 1.4 1.3 1.1 1.0 0.9 1.9 2.3 0.7 0.5 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 Q2 2021 Homes passed FttH Homes installed FttH _Source: ACM Monitor_ The fixed infrastructure market has followed a similar monetization path as the mobile infrastructure market, and several commercial wholesale agreements over fiber networks have been reached in recent years. Operators have been either divesting their FTTH networks or creating strategic partnerships with companies such as Open Dutch Fiber (“ODF”) or DELTA Fiber Nederland B.V., backed by financial sponsors KKR & Co. Inc. (“KKR”) with Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners Management GmbH (“DTCP”) and EQT Partners (“EQT”), respectively. In April 2021, KKR and DTCP launched a fiber venture with TMNL as the anchor tenant, in which capital expenditure commitments will amount to approximately €700 million (source: publicly _announced by KKR and DTCP). Similarly, one of EQT’s infrastructure funds and Stonepeak recently_ announced their joint acquisition of DELTA Fiber. Another example is KPN and pension fund APG’s joint venture, Glaspoort, a partnership that is aimed to rollout fiber to approximately 750,000 homes and 225,000 businesses in the upcoming five years. The investment is expected to amount to over €1 billion. The fixed broadband sector also has been backed by significant investment in fiber infrastructure, as seen in the FTTH household penetration of approximately 20% in 2020, compared to 7% in 2013. There is, however room for growth, as fiber connections in The Netherlands represented only 21% of total broadband connections in 2020, compared to the OECD average of 31%. The Netherlands ranks 26[th] among all 38 OECD countries in terms of percentage of fiber connections amongst total broadband connections. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dutch telecommunications market
Subsubsection Text: The Dutch telecommunications market is one of the largest in Europe, supported by The Netherlands being the sixth largest economy in the European Union (source: Eurostat, October 2021) and a population of more than 17.5 million (source: Eurostat, January 2021). The market landscape is led by the three MNO players: KPN, TMNL and VFZ. Mobile penetration is 128% as of the fourth quarter of 2020 (source: ACM _Monitor), which is above the European Union average of 122% (source: World Bank). Consistent with global_ consumption trends, demand for data has increased significantly in The Netherlands, translating to a compounded annual growth of approximately 61% since 2013 and until the end of 2020. TMNL currently carries more than 50% of this data (source: ACM Monitor) and a vast majority of this data is based on 4G (LTE), the network for which currently reaches over 99% of the country by both geography and population. Consequently, the Dutch operators are increasingly focusing on services based on 5G. _Evolution of mobile data consumption (in petabytes (PB))_ 952 ### 61 % CAGR 760 ### 2013-2020 574 337 185 115 63 34 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 _Source: ACM Monitor_ In 2020, mobile cellular subscriptions in The Netherlands amounted to 22.3 million subscriptions _(source: ACM Monitor), compared to 19.5 million in 2013, with broadband communications lines increasing_ from 6.7 million in 2013 to 7.5 million in 2020 (source: ACM Monitor). Penetration continues to improve, with mobile telephony and fixed broadband penetration reaching 127.9% (population) and 94.1% (households), respectively, in each case as of the fourth quarter of 2020. ----- _Dutch telecommunications market development (in millions of lines)_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Total mobile lines[(1)] (millions)_** **_Total broadband connections (millions)
Subsubsection Text: _Source: ACM Monitor (1) Includes both B2B and B2C._ There are positive trends that impact the mobile B2C segment. The continued increase of the population, with younger generations having phones at a younger age and the pre-to-post migration impact the number of SIM subscriptions. The current trend towards multi-SIM, meaning the ability for consumers to connect multiple devices to the same mobile number, allows for more flexible voice services and increased customer loyalty. KPN and TMNL offer multi-SIM solutions today. Average revenue per user (“ARPUs”) of the market are according to management’s estimates expected to grow, mainly through the increased access of 5G, “more for more” services and low-end portfolio optimization. Within the fixed market, consumer demand for data at a higher speed is increasing and the willingness to pay more for ultrafast fiber and better quality is becoming increasingly important to consumers. We believe that this growing demand for broadband services is likely to offset the decline of segments such as traditional TV and fixed voice, which are increasingly being replaced by more digital solutions such as over the top (“OTT”) communication services that operate over the internet.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dutch Mobile Market Focus on the Dutch mobile telephony market
Subsubsection Text: The Dutch mobile telephony market is led by the three MNOs – KPN, TMNL and VFZ – which directly provide services to consumers mainly through their group brands, with KPN offering sub-brands such as Simyo, and TMNL offering Tele2, Simpel or Ben as an alternative to the premium brand T-Mobile. MVNOs hosted on MNO’s networks also provide consumers with mobile telephony services. As of December 31, 2020, TMNL was the premier company in the B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the same market. KPN phased out its Telfort brand between 2019 and 2020 in order to focus on value-over-volume strategy in which the company wants to leverage a simplified product portfolio. TMNL’s growth has been driven partly by the completion of the merger with the Dutch operations of Swedish Tele2 Sverige AB in 2019 and the acquisition of Simpel, a Dutch SIM-only MVNO, in 2020. Despite increased competition in the last decade, the market has stabilized and prices have shown moderate growth across the MNOs. ----- _B2C mobile (postpaid) telephony revenues (in € million)_ **CAGR (%) ’18-20** 2,380 2,326 2,339 30 42 52 32.7% 687 631 637 (3.7%) 792 745 714 (5.1%) 79 97 104 3.6% 793 811 831 2018 2019 2020 TMNL Simpel KPN VodafoneZiggo Other PF TMNL (including Tele2) _Note: TMNL data is pro forma adjusted to include Tele2 over the entire period. Note: TMNL data represents ARPU, which is B2C Mobile Service Revenue. KPN, VFZ and Other data represents ARPU in the segment for the year multiplied by the average number of SIMs at the end of the period for the presented and previous year multiplied by 12. Certain competitor data is calculated using reported consumer mobile service revenue minus estimated market share based on industry reports._ Recent trends have shown increasing demand for mobile telephony lines in The Netherlands, with 22.3 million lines in 2020, an increase of 14.4% since 2013 (source: ACM Monitor). The postpaid segment is the main driver of growth, with 5.9 million new lines since 2013, representing 90.4% of the MNO mobile services market in 2020, while prepaid services decreased by 3.1 million over the same period. TMNL is achieving the greatest increase of its postpaid customer base and has the highest share of net new customers compared to its peers. This is mainly attributed to recent merger and acquisition activity, such as the merger with Tele2 in 2019 and the acquisition of Simpel in 2020. _Mobile postpaid net new customers (in millions of lines) Note: Reported TMNL quarterly net adds (including Simpel from December 2020 onwards). KPN and VFZ data represents reported B2C net adds per quarter. Source: Publicly available sources/Management estimates._ The mobile telecommunications market in The Netherlands is relatively sizeable and attractive with three MNOs and the risk of new MNOs and MVNOs entering the market is limited. For MNOs, low prices act as a deterrent as ARPUs are at the low end of European benchmarks and significantly below the level at which Tele2 unsuccessfully entered the market in 2015. Furthermore, there is no upcoming spectrum auction that ----- could facilitate a new entrant – the upcoming auction for the 3.5 GHz spectrum is inappropriate for new entrants due to propagation characteristics – and the market is highly converged, resulting in more lasting customers and limiting the pool of available subscribers. The number of MVNOs has halved in the last six years from approximately 60 to approximately 30 and the remaining MVNOs are small and focused on niche customer groups. _B2C mobile postpaid ARPU ( € p.m.) Notes: (1) ARPU as per peer reporting; KPN & VFZ only report rounded ARPUs, displayed ARPUs are management estimates based on reported quarterly year-over-year growth percentages and (2) TMNL data includes Tele2 but excludes Simpel. Source: Publicly available sources/Management estimates._ The three players in the market have seen relatively stable ARPUs in recent quarters. KPN has delivered stable ARPUs for the B2C mobile postpaid category, with ARPUs ranging between €17.3-18.3 since the first quarter of 2019 (source: Public filings). KPN is devoting resources to its value-over-volume strategy by refocusing on the KPN brand and phasing out its Telfort brand, in 2019, aiming to leverage its market position as a trusted and conventional MNO and offer a simplified product portfolio. Historically, VFZ’s ARPUs declined in a push to grow FMC penetration as a competitive response to TMNL’s lower prices. ARPUs have recently started to stabilize, given the high FMC share reached and the changed competitive environment. In recent reporting periods, all brands have experienced ARPU increases and reduced aggressive promotions. Further growth within the Dutch mobile telephony market is supported by structural drivers such as the increase in number of SIMs due to population growth. The continued pre- to post-migration trend, the growth of Unlimited, 5G, value-added services and overall inflation are other drivers that are expected to support ARPUs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Focus on the Dutch mobile broadband market
Subsubsection Text: Mobile broadband is wireless internet access that is delivered through cellular towers. Although representing a relatively small fraction of mobile connections in The Netherlands, the mobile broadband market has gained traction through mobile network operator investments in high-speed package (“HSPA”) and LTE technologies. An increase in the number of subscribers of mobile broadband is expected with the upcoming auction of 3.5 GHz band in 2022, as 5G will enhance the range and capacity of networks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Dutch Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market
Subsubsection Title: Focus on fixed broadband market
Subsubsection Text: Active fixed network broadband lines reached 7.5 million households in 2020, a modest increase of 0.9% compared to 2019 (source: ACM Monitor). Expansion of fixed broadband is mainly driven by growth of installed fiber networks, which grew by 16.1% between 2019 and 2020 and resulted in a penetration of 42%. This number has been increasing by the month, and as of June 2021 fiber penetrated 51% of Dutch households. ----- _Broadband by technology (in millions of lines) Source: ACM Monitor_ The growing number of broadband lines is partially driven by bundled offerings, the prevalence of which has increased and most notably for 4P bundles (fixed-mobile). In 2020, 4P bundles took up 26% of total broadband connections – compared to 7% in 2014. Bundled offerings accounted for 92% of all retail connections with broadband in 2020 (source: ACM Monitor). Over the course of 2020, average fixed broadband speed increased because of higher network access and greater sales of bundles with higher fixed line connection speeds and larger mobile connection traffic volumes. As of 2020, 99% of broadband lines had a connection speed higher than 10 Mbps. In 2019, lines with a connection speed greater than 30 Mbps but less than 100 Mbps amounted to 46% and decreased to 44% in 2020. However, this decrease was offset by an increase of lines with a connection speed of 100 Mbps or higher, which increased from 46% of retail connections in 2019 to 49% in 2020 (source: ACM Monitor). Collectively, lines with a speed of 30 Mbps or more amounted to 91.7%. While lines with connection speeds greater than 100 Mbps increased in 2020, this was mainly reflected in high-speed data processed via fiber-optic connections, representing a 30.1% increase, whereas DSL and cable connections increased by 0.9% and 1.3% respectively. This demonstrates the proportionate relationship between the number of high data subscribers and upgrades of network infrastructure and technology. Two of the three largest MNOs, VFZ and KPN, hold key positions in the market for fixed broadband retail connections, with a revenue market share of 45% and 41% respectively, with TMNL currently holding a 6% share. ----- _B2C fixed broadband revenue (in € million) Note: (1) TMNL data includes Tele2 historical data and (2) TMNL, KPN, VFZ and Other data represents service revenue in the segment for the year. Source: Publicly available sources/Management estimates._ Fixed-mobile convergence has been one of the key themes in the market over the past years. As such, a viable FMC product, which currently only can be offered by the three large MNOs, is a prerequisite to participate at large scale in both the fixed and mobile markets. _Fixed broadband net new customers (in thousands of lines) Note: Tele2 customer base of 339,000 includes B2C and B2B lines. Source: Publicly available sources._ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Dutch Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market
Subsubsection Title: Focus on fixed telephony
Subsubsection Text: Fixed telephony revenue continued to decline during 2020 and so did both public switched telephone networks (“PSTN”) and voice over broadband (“VOB”) single connections. Although fixed telephony is considered a mature, declining market, the operators benefit from the service by bundling it with other telecommunications services. In 2020, only 17% of fixed telephony retail connections were contracted individually. The remaining 37% was in 4P bundles, 40% in 3P bundles and 6% in 2P bundles. In 2020, the network traffic per fixed line decreased by 30.9% whereas broadband network traffic increased by 14.7%. The majority of consumers have replaced their fixed telephones with mobiles and most digital interactions now take place either online or via mobile networks. As a result of the shift from fixed to mobile telephony, fixed telephony revenues have decreased by 71% since 2013. _Revenue fixed network (in € million) Source: ACM Monitor_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Dutch Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market
Subsubsection Title: Bundling/fixed-mobile convergence
Subsubsection Text: By bundling services together, such as high speed data packages and phone services, rather than offering discounted prices separately, both consumers and operators can potentially achieve better value. FMC can be driven by consumer demand and by operators seizing opportunities and locking in customers, leveraging either a fixed or a mobile asset that competitors may not have. _Product bundles penetration (% of total subscribers)_ ----- _Source: ACM Monitor_ The Dutch telecommunications market has shifted over recent years. The number of fixed-mobile product bundles (4P, 3P and 2P bundles) has increased every year from an aggregate of 5.6 million in 2013 to 7.0 million in 2020, with penetration of fixed-mobile product bundles increasing from 4.9% to 36.6% over this period. There has been a steady increase in the popularity of 4P bundles, growing each year from approximately 0.4 million in 2013 to 2.9 million in 2020. Meanwhile, 3P bundle subscriptions increased from 3.5 million in 2013 to 3.9 million in 2016, before falling back to 2 million in 2020 as 4P bundles grew in popularity. Consumers with 2P bundle subscriptions have increased from 1.7 million in 2013 to 2.1 million in 2020 (source: _ACM Monitor). In 2020, TMNL held a 5-10% retail market share of bundled services. VFZ held a 45-50%_ market share, while KPN and DELTA Fiber held 35-40% and 5-10% market share, respectively. DELTA Fiber does not offer retail bundles containing mobile (source: ACM Monitor). FMC will be further enabled by cross-selling a large mobile base and through the upselling of fixed services to mobile customers, which will spur growth in the consumer market. In 2021, TMNL’s brand Tele2 launched various FMC multi-brand offerings that are aimed to improve loyalty, both by serving the existing customer base and by establishing brands that cater to new customers within the whole household.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Although demand for traditional television is gradually reducing as consumers move to alternative media services, such as OTT services, television via fiber is gaining prominence. Between 2013 and 2020, fiber connections for television in The Netherlands increased by a factor of 1.7x _(source: ACM Monitor). Fiber provides customers with good quality picture while simultaneously allowing operators to reduce operating costs in the long run. _Television subscriptions per connection type (in millions of lines) Source: ACM Monitor_ The rapid growth of OTT streaming services, both advertisement-based video on demand (“AVOD”) and subscription-based video on demand (“SVOD”), has impacted traditional pay-TV operators that use satellite and cable to offer subscription television services. As KPN launched its IPTV package as part of its convergence strategy and eventually launched 4P bundles, competitors had to act accordingly and improve their own convergence service offerings. Despite VFZ’s leading position in the market, the company now offers Netflix on all of its set-top boxes. In 2015, KPN launched KPN Play, which eventually was discontinued in 2018 due to a lack of demand. TMNL subsequently closed its own OTT offering, Knippr, the same year. Nevertheless, in 2020 The Netherlands had the third highest percentage of its national population streaming internet TV or videos compared to 37 other European countries, due to significant growth of companies offering streaming media as a core service. In 2020, 95% of the Dutch population who used the internet within the last three months used it to watch internet-streamed TV or videos, compared to 90% and 84% in 2018 and 2016, respectively (source: Eurostat). ----- _Internet-streamed TV or videos (% of population who use internet)_ 95% 90% 84% 74% 70% 68% 2016 2018 2020 Netherlands EU _Source: Eurostat_ Pay-TV subscriptions in The Netherlands decreased by 8% between 2013 and 2020 (source: ACM _Monitor). Since 2013, the market has experienced a net loss of new subscribers. A trend that is consistent with_ the expansion of OTT platforms which offer consumers alternative choices. _Pay-TV Net adds (thousands of subscriptions) Source: ACM Monitor_ The Dutch government and network operators also have responded to the change in media consumption partially by freeing up spectrum space. KPN upgraded its terrestrial television service, digitenne, to the digital video broadcasting – second generational terrestrial (DVB-T2) standard to free up 700 MHz for mobile traffic. Similarly, in April 2021 VFZ finalized its process of turning off its analogue cable television so that capacity for broadband could be increased. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The B2B mobile market has declined in the last three years, mainly due to changes in what type of telecommunications services businesses require for their operations. One factor contributing to the negative trend in voice is the transition from traditional telephony to integrated solutions (e.g., Cloud PBX solutions that provide telephone server access over a cloud-based internet network). _B2B mobile revenue (in € million) Note: (1) TMNL service revenues include revenues from IT Partners and DeanOne and (2) TMNL, KPN, VFZ and Other data represents ARPU in the segment for the year multiplied by the average number of SIMs at the end of the period for the presented and previous year multiplied by 12. Source: Publicly available sources/Management estimates._ The decline of the fixed market is partially a result of the transformation from legacy (copper, PSTN/ ISDN) to new IP services (fiber-based). Although the B2B fixed market is going through a transformation as voice declines, this is offset by the growth of data and broadband, and management expects stabilization with growing revenues in the market. KPN holds a leading position that it leverages by locking in business customers with unified communications solutions that integrate various communication services, such as instant messaging, voice, and video conferencing. VFZ historically has been focusing on small to mid-size enterprise customers, which is a current growth segment. TMNL plans to expand its B2B services by launching broadband/FMC products and to mirror its success in the B2C market. ----- _B2B fixed revenue (in € million) Note: TMNL data represents management revenue and market estimates. KPN data represents the sum of “Broadband & network services” and “Fixed-voice” line items as presented in annual consolidated financial statements available at http://ir.kpn.com. VFZ data represents the “B2B cable revenue-Subscription revenue” line item as presented in quarterly preliminary unaudited selected financial results available at http://www.vodafoneziggo.nl/resultaten/. Other data represents the difference for the total market size, as estimated by management. Source: Publicly available sources/Management estimates._ Wholesale business fiber connections in The Netherlands amounted to approximately 107,000 connections, growing from 100,000 in 2019 (source: ACM Monitor). The fixed connectivity segment is mainly driven by demand for internet and data networks, which in turn is fueled by the shift from cable to fiber. Pursuant to regulatory refinements, KPN and VFZ are no longer required to maintain a wholesale offer for virtual access to their networks. Since 1997, KPN was obligated to provide wholesale access to its copper and fiber network, and since October 2018 VFZ was obligated to provide wholesale access to its cable network. In a landmark decision in March 2020, the regulator (ACM) found that KPN and VFZ together held significant market power. However, after a national appeal, this decision was annulled by the CBb in March 2020. The court held that there was not sufficient evidence to establish joint dominance on the retail market by KPN and VFZ. As a result, these companies are no longer obligated to provide wholesale access to their networks, although KPN has chosen to continue to offer wholesale access of both copper and fiber to other operators.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The main regulatory bodies in the Dutch telecommunications market include ACM and supervisory authorities: the Radiocommunications Agency Netherlands (Agentschap Telecom) (“AT”), which is part of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy; the Dutch Authority for the Financial Markets (Autoriteit _Financiële Markten) (“AFM”); and the Dutch Data Protection Authority (Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens) (“AP”)._ There are differing views on how deregulation will impact competition and pricing for fixed wholesale access. TMNL relies on access to KPN’s networks but recently submitted two requests to ACM to have KPN regulated again and enforce wholesale access against regulated wholesale tariffs (source: Company _information). Despite wholesale access no longer being regulated at this time, ACM has been granted a new_ regulatory tool (symmetric access) to impose access obligations, in addition to the market analysis route it has had for decades. A draft market analysis decision of the ACM is expected to be published towards the end of 2021, following its press release in July 2021, that it will conduct research and take a decision on the need (and ----- if so, the way) to regulate fixed access. According to this press release, the ACM sees a risk that KPN may restrict its access conditions. In February 2021, the Dutch Minister of Finance sent a letter to the Dutch Parliament reflecting an intention to revise consumer credit regulation in The Netherlands by lowering the threshold for document verification required to obtain a loan for a mobile device. So far, no legislative proposal has been submitted to Parliament to execute this intention and a decision has not been made whether to submit such a proposal. With regards to data roaming, there will potentially be stricter quality of service provisions as EU bodies are in a process of reviewing roaming regulations including a potential reduction of the wholesale and/or retail tariffs in the future. In April 2021, Dutch mobile operators received a decision from the Dutch government on the basis of which Chinese vendors are restricted from supplying specific components to the core mobile network and service platforms of Dutch telecom providers. The Dutch MNOs are granted a transition period to replace the current equipment and the transition period is in line with TMNL’s usual replacement and rotation cycle. The auction of the 3.5 GHz is expected to take place in the latter half of 2022, but this could be delayed to 2023 due to a court case initiated by Inmarsat, a British satellite telecommunications company, which currently uses the spectrum for safety communications at sea. There are not expected to be significant regulatory challenges in connection with spectrum coverage. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands, we are one of the three mobile network operators (“MNOs”) in the Dutch telecommunications market. We offer mobile (both postpaid and prepaid) and fixed telecommunications services to both B2C and B2B customers, and we also sell handsets to our customers. We are the largest mobile telecommunications provider in the Dutch consumer market by mobile service revenue and number of SIMs, we have been ranked as the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and we have also been ranked as the top network in the world (Source: Umlaut, The _2021 Mobile Network Test in The Netherlands; PresseBox, T-Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut)._ As of September 30, 2021, we had 6.9 million mobile subscribers and 0.7 million fixed subscribers, representing an increase of approximately 29% and 24%, respectively, compared to December 31, 2018. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our combined mobile service revenues totaled €1,215.1 million, our combined fixed line services revenue totaled €391 million, and our revenue from the sale of goods and services, and other revenues totaled €443 million. Mobile service revenue combines mobile revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as visitor roaming, and our fixed line services revenue combines fixed line revenue from our B2C and B2B segments as well as fixed line wholesale revenue. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, pro forma for our acquisitions and other adjustments, our revenue for the B2C segment totaled €1,239 million and for the B2B segment was €292 million. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021 was €637.4 million. TMNL traces its origins back to 2002, when Deutsche Telekom entered the Dutch market through the acquisition of Ben, which it subsequently rebranded as T-Mobile in 2003. In 2007, we acquired Orange Netherlands, making us the third largest mobile operator in The Netherlands after Koninklijke KPN N.V. (“KPN”) and VodafoneZiggo Group Holding B.V. (“VFZ”). In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which was subsequently renamed to TMNL Thuis. This transaction marked our entry into the fixed market, adding approximately 150,000 fixed line customers. Through the TMNL Thuis acquisition, we also gained access to a dark fiber footprint on KPN’s fiber network (KPN ODF). In January 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2, strengthening our position in the Dutch market, across all segments. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, an online-only SIM-only MVNO on our network, focusing in particular on the low budget segment of the market. The Simpel acquisition further strengthened our position, making us the leader both in terms of B2C mobile postpaid SIM cards and service revenues. We continue to operate the Simpel brand after its acquisition in 2020. In April 2021, we announced a strategic partnership with Open Dutch Fiber, a company owned by KKR and DTCP that plans to roll-out fiber services to over one million homes passed. We are the anchor tenant on this network which focuses on dense, urban areas in which we currently have a large mobile market share. The Open Dutch Fiber partnership is an example of our asset-light model and lean operational setup, which we believe enables us to streamline our business and optimize our indirect cost base ratio. We provide our B2C customers with a multi-brand portfolio of mobile services, including voice, messaging and broadband aiming to cover all segments of the market from premium to low-budget and operating on our own networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide fixed broadband, TV and fixed voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. In addition, and in line with market trends, we offer B2C customers packages that bundle mobile and fixed telecommunications services at attractive prices, known as FMC packages. Our B2B business segment is dedicated to meeting the connectivity needs of companies of all types and sizes as we offer a broad range of telecommunications solutions, cloud-based and unified communications solutions. The chart below sets forth key events in our growth and transformation to the largest mobile telecommunications provider in The Netherlands’ B2C market and an established mobile-led FMC challenger. ----- We have invested heavily in our offerings and we believe we have successfully repositioned our business through innovation and change, as evidenced by our new offerings and services and by our being the first provider to offer nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band. Going forward, we believe we are uniquely positioned to capitalize on further growth opportunities, enabling us to continue on our historical trajectory and set new industry standards. The chart below highlights some of our key successes between 2015 and 2020. _Source: Telecompaper, competitor reports, Company information. Notes: (1) Magenta FTTH footprint consists of FTTH from KPN wholesale, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest fiber. (2) As of the second quarter of 2021. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group and consists of (i) customer recommendation, (ii) customer likelihood to continue services, (iii) competitive advantage and (iv) performance. (3) As per Telecompaper, fourth quarter of 2015. (4) Base for calculation includes T-Mobile premium brand and Tele2 subscriptions across both B2C (3.4 million subscribers) and SOHO/VSE B2B (0.4 million subscribers)._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Attractive telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: We operate in The Netherlands, which has a sizeable and attractive telecommunications market which consists of three main telecommunications providers. The Netherlands is the 6[th ]largest economy in Europe and has a robust macroeconomic environment, with 2% real GDP growth expected for 2021, moderate population and household growth, and a large demand for high-quality communication services (Source: Telecompaper). We compete in both the mobile and the fixed markets with KPN and VFZ. We are the premier company in the B2C mobile market with a 42% market share as calculated by our number of postpaid SIM subscribers, as compared to a 30% market share for KPN and 25% for VFZ in the same market. The MVNO market is small accounting for approximately 4% market share of postpaid SIMs, with the largest MVNO, Youfone, having an approximately 3% market share based on number of SIM subscribers. In this context, we believe the risk of irrational behaviors by existing competitors is low and that existing MNOs are likely to compete primarily on the quality of their services. Following our acquisition of Tele2, the market players were further consolidated ----- from four to three and a process of revenue and ARPU stabilization started, similar to what has been seen in other markets such as Austria, Germany or Ireland. The Netherlands has one of the lowest ARPU levels in Europe. We also believe that the risk of a new MNO entering the market is low. We believe that this is due to the following factors: (i) the highly converged nature of the market, making it less attractive for new entrants, as they must be able to offer both mobile and fixed offers to be competitive therein and (ii) the lack of any viable spectrum auction that could allow the entrance of a new player, since the upcoming 5G spectrum auction in The Netherlands is planned to offer only a specific band of spectrum and we do not need to renew our existing spectrum licenses until 2030, making the auction more suitable for existing MNOs and unsuitable for new entrants. The most recent possibility for a new entrant to obtain a marketable spectrum allocation would have been the 2020 multi-band spectrum auction. However, only the three main players in the telecommunications market, namely KPN, VFZ and us, participated in the auction. Additionally, we believe that the competitive risk posed by MVNOs is low because MVNOs have limited ability to compete on unlimited subscriptions in light of each MVNO’s lack of owned network and their limited ability to cover FMC packages, as well as such unlimited plans’ impact on costs. Indeed, the number of MVNOs has decreased by half from approximately 60 to approximately 30 in The Netherlands over the last six years. Furthermore, we anticipate that the B2C mobile market will continue to grow as data traffic continues to increase. Indeed, our B2C mobile pro forma service revenues grew by 3.1% in 2020 (after a 4.1% decrease in 2019) despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Key trends include: (i) Growth in postpaid SIMs subscriptions, which is driven both by prepaid to postpaid subscription migration and by population growth, as well as trends of increasing proportions of multi-SIM subscriptions; and (ii) Growth in mobile ARPU as driven by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services, value-added services as well as overall inflation and the telecommunications market’s shift towards larger data bundles. We believe that B2C ARPU will grow in the future due to these factors, even though mobile ARPUs had decreased in The Netherlands in past years because of intense price competition and mobile discounting as part of FMC offers, mainly triggered by KPN and VFZ. The following table sets out historical trends in B2C mobile services ARPU across our brands and our two major competitors, KPN and VFZ, and demonstrates that while ARPU among our competitors has generally decreased in recent years, ARPU among our brands has generally increased or stabilized. ----- _Source: Company information and publicly available information adjusted based on management estimates._ The B2B market has seen similar developments. In particular, ARPU in the SOHO/VSE segment follows consumer market trends, driven as in the B2C market by growth in unlimited subscriptions, 5G services and value-added services, and we believe those drivers will continue to push ARPU growth. In the B2B market generally, we believe that growth in subscribers will be driven by growth in SOHO/VSE businesses, an increased adoption of mobile services in the B2B market and an increasing adoption of converged telecommunications solutions. Additionally, the Dutch fixed telecommunications market has benefitted from infrastructure upgrades in recent years that have contributed to a growing market, in spite of declining telephony and peaking TV, primarily due to a higher demand for broadband services at higher speeds, which is our core product offering within the fixed segment. Historically, the fixed internet market in The Netherlands was dominated by KPN and VFZ, which have a combined market share of approximately 80%. We have positioned ourselves as a challenger in this market, focusing on providing fast broadband services and offering competitive and sustainable pricing. In the future, we believe that growth in the fixed market will be driven by (i) an increase in subscribers associated with household growth and (ii) premium customers’ willingness to pay for ultrafast fiber and better quality, which allows for more-for-more strategies and results in increasing demand for higher fiberbased data bundles. FTTH coverage is expanding in The Netherlands and the B2C and B2B markets are expected to benefit from such expansion. We expect to benefit from this trend through what we call our ‘Magenta’ footprint, which includes several Optical Distribution Framework-type of agreements and partnerships with, among others, Open Dutch Fiber, KPN’s affiliate Reggefiber Operator B.V. and Primevest Capital Partners, where we expect to eventually have access to over three million households at sustainable commercial terms. The remaining households can be reached by Wholesale Broadband Access (“WBA”)-type of access on KPN copper (until its planned phase-out over the next three years) and/or fiber network. Additional infrastructure players of ----- significant size include Delta Fiber, Glaspoort (a joint venture between KPN and APG Groep N.V.) and Eurofiber.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: World-class network and strong commercial execution
Subsubsection Text: We lead our competitors across a number of key attributes, including our world-class mobile network with the largest spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands, our leading brand portfolio and our strong commercial execution. In December 2020, Umlaut ranked us the best mobile network in The Netherlands for the fifth year in a row, and in February 2021, they recognized us as the top network in the world (Sources: PresseBox, Five in _a Row—T-Mobile Wins the Umlaut Connect Mobile Benchmark in The Netherlands Again; PresseBox, T- Mobile Awarded “Best in Test” Worldwide by Umlaut). According to the ACM, our mobile network carries_ approximately 50% of mobile data traffic in The Netherlands. We believe that our leading network position results from our efficiently leveraging three key pillars: (i) technology, such as single radio access network (“RAN”) with future-proof site configurations that are regularly upgraded in anticipation of customer demand; (ii) sites, as we operate an optimal site grid with the highest site density in urban areas and 4,982 base stations in total, providing coverage to more than 99% of the population of The Netherlands; (iii) the largest mobile spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands with interference-free low bands, resulting in high cost efficiency and an indoor capacity advantage. As of December 31, 2020, we held an aggregate of 250 MHz of spectrum, in comparison with 215 MHz for VFZ and 195 MHz for KPN. None of the licenses in our portfolio need to be renewed before 2030. We have distinguished ourselves by our distinctive brand portfolio. In line with other MNOs in The Netherlands, we have been following value-based and more-for-more strategies that target different market segments with separate brands. Each of our four brands has a distinctive positioning with differentiated profiles, as summarized in the following chart.
