Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Well-positioned to benefit from market tailwinds for growth in market share, B2C revenue, customer satisfaction and ARPU
Subsubsection Text: Our status as a leading B2C mobile operator is confirmed by our market share as measured by our volume of subscribers and by our revenue. As of December 31, 2020, we have 42% of the B2C mobile postpaid market share by volume, which corresponds to 5.1 million SIMs. We have managed to reach our leading volume market share of 42% over the past three years, supported in part by the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, while the absolute number of subscribers grew at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2018 and 2020. At the same time, our market share by revenue increased from 33% to 40% over the same period. Our B2C mobile revenue growth in the past three years was mainly driven by stable ARPUs at brand levels and a growing subscriber base, driven by marketing strategies for our brands, our strong positioning in unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2, and an increase in demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel. We have also maintained growth in customer satisfaction, which has helped us retain customers. In the B2C mobile market, TMNL outpaced its competitors in The Netherlands by delivering the fastest-increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade. TRI*M is a customer satisfaction metric widely adopted within the Deutsche Telekom Group which combines customer recommendation, customer likelihood to continue services, competitive advantage and performance. Our TRI*M score increased by over 50% over 12 years. We believe that an increase in customer satisfaction was one of the key factors driving the reduction in our B2C mobile churn to approximately 11% in 2020. We believe that our position as a leading B2C mobile operator with growing customer satisfaction metrics situates us well to take advantage of trends towards converged fixed and mobile offerings and morefor-more strategies, as it allows us a larger base of customers to cross-sell into FMC packages and to upsell into more premium offers. See “—World-class network and strong commercial execution” and “Industry—Dutch _Broadband and Fixed Telephony Market—Focus on fixed broadband market.” Already in the first three quarters_ of 2021, our ARPU has grown across all four of our brands, corresponding to increases of between €0.8 and ----- €1.1 in the third quarter of 2021 in comparison with the first quarter of 2021. We expect to experience moderate growth in the future by building on our success in growing subscriber base and potential further ARPU growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model
Subsubsection Text: We have a successful track record of M&A, synergy realization and cost optimization. This track record, combined with a lean, asset-light fixed business model has given us operating leverage and operational efficiency. In 2016, we acquired Vodafone’s B2C fixed business, Vodafone Thuis, which we shortly thereafter rebranded T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone’s divestiture of Vodafone Thuis was ordered by the European Commission as a remedy to provide competition clearance for VFZ, the joint venture between Vodafone and Ziggo. This acquisition marked the beginning of our present fixed internet business and added about 150,000 fixed-line customers. In January 2019, we completed our acquisition of Tele2. This acquisition has strengthened our position in the Dutch telecommunications market and allowed us to compete more effectively with KPN and VFZ by giving us enhanced scale, combined spectrum resources and significant synergy potential. We are executing a three-year plan to realize synergies from our acquisition of Tele2 in 2019. We have closed Tele2’s standalone stores and we are in the process of implementing significant operations costs savings. Based on our estimates, we anticipate realizing Tele2 cost-saving synergies with a total run-rate synergy potential of €130 million by 2024, of which we have already realized €115 million of synergies run-rate as of September 30, 2021. In December 2020, we completed the acquisition of Simpel, by then the largest MVNO in The Netherlands. By means of this transaction, we acquired one million additional B2C mobile postpaid customers who were already using our network under Simpel’s prior wholesale agreement with us. The acquisition of Simpel provide further synergy and cost savings potential to be realized in the total amount of approximately €9 million by 2024. Synergies related to Tele2 and Simpel entail for example related to reduced interconnect costs, migration of Tele2’s business support system (“BSS”) to our Magenta stack, synergies in respect of bad debt collections (representing improved client acceptance and collection practices implemented upon integration with TMNL), direct and indirect cost savings related to the discontinuance of the Tele2 network and the cancellation of leased telecommunications towers, reduction in marketing expenses as a result of mobile cross-selling, optimization of campaigning periods, reduction in other indirect costs such as personnel related costs as well as legal audit and tax fees. For risks related to our growth through acquisitions, see “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Acquisitions and other strategic transactions present many risks, including the risk that we may not be able to integrate newly acquired operations into our business, which may prevent us from realizing the strategic and financial goals contemplated at the time of any such transaction and thus adversely affect our business.”_ We believe that these strategic acquisitions, coupled with our rapid and successful organic growth initiatives, position us well to capture further market share and grow margins across the business segments in which we operate. Further, our lean and digital business model also allows us to benefit from strong operating leverage. Aside from the lean operating cost base described above, we have also repositioned ourselves to become a digital telecommunications company with an asset-light fixed model. On September 1, 2018, we demerged our tower business into Cignal Infrastructure (at demerger and until June 2021, T-Infra). Subsequently, on January 1, 2019, one day prior to the closing of the Tele2 acquisition, we distributed Cignal Infrastructure as a dividend in kind to Deutsche Telekom, with TMNL continuing to have full access to the contributed infrastructure through a long-term, arms-length service agreement. In June 2021, Deutsche Telekom sold Cignal Infrastructure to Digital Infrastructure Vehicle 1 SCSP, which is a joint venture of Cellnex and DTCP. Currently, we benefit from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price Index. Additionally, we continue to hold our own market-leading mobile spectrum portfolio. In our fixed segment we also have an asset-light model. Our partners, Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, are conducting the roll-out of our FTTH network, and we do not have any direct fixed access network ownership. We expect to have access to the over one million FTTH homes that Open Dutch Fiber is scheduled to roll out to by 2025 in densely-populated areas with strong TMNL mobile customer presence. Under the ----- Primvest partnership, we expect that we will have FTTH access to approximately 130,000 homes passed. By the terms of this partnership, we benefit from an initial period of exclusivity and line prices with base rates of not more than €15 per month, indexed to inflation and subject to certain adjustments. In both of these partnerships, we have agreed to certain utilization commitments. In addition, we have access to approximately two million homes passed on KPN’s Open Distribution Framework footprint which is completed by WBA for a nationwide fixed network footprint. Such a lean business model has allowed us to achieve total capital expenditure savings of over €700 million, estimated as savings as a result of us not having to allocate and devote capital expenditure on building a fiber network and mobile towers for five years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong cash flow profile with demonstrated resilience and strong cash generation
Subsubsection Text: We have historically demonstrated a track record of growth, profitability improvement and strong cash flow generation. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we have been able to maintain growth and increase profitability, as evidenced by a 29.7% Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin in 2020 in comparison to 26.7% in 2019. We believe this demonstrates the resilience of our business and of our company overall. In addition, we generated a 56% Cash Conversion in 2020 in comparison with an average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies. We delivered revenue growth in a challenging market environment between 2018 and 2020 at a 2% CAGR. Such growth was mainly driven by a growing subscriber base and stabilizing ARPU levels in the mobile B2C segment, as well as by strong growth in our B2C fixed business. Historically, our B2C mobile segment has been the major contributor to revenue at a 4% CAGR between 2018 and 2020, having accounted for 47% of total revenue in 2020. Our B2C mobile business delivered significant SIM net adds, particularly in the Simpel and Ben brands, and relatively stable ARPUs among those of our brands that offered the increasingly-popular unlimited data bundles. Positive developments offset a decrease in roaming revenue as a result of COVID-19– induced travelling restrictions. Our B2C fixed segment was our fastest-growing segment, growing at a CAGR of 11% over the past three years. We believe that this strong growth was driven by a successful FMC challenger strategy which resulted in strong growth in subscriber base that amounted to an additional 133,000 customers in the past three years. We also delivered strong performance in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL, both in terms of margin expansion and growth. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin increased from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 and to 31.1% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2021. Our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL exhibited a strong CAGR of 16.1% between 2018 and 2020 due to an improved gross margin, declining indirect costs in absolute terms from cost saving programs and headcount reduction, and realization of Tele2 synergies. Because we delivered strong revenue and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL expansion through challenging market conditions, we believe that we are in a position of strength and greater scale to deliver incremental top line and profitability expansion as market conditions improve. We also benefit from a strong cash generation profile driven by a solid top-line performance that is combined with prudent cost management and moderate capital expenditure needs. Our Underlying Operating Free Cash Flow increased by 53% in 2020 compared to 2019, and is expected to continue on a growth trajectory going forward as we maintain our capital expenditure-light strategy. Our Cash Conversion was 56% in 2020 and it further increased to 58.9% during the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, which is above the average level of 30% for other international telecommunication companies. The below chart shows our resilience and strong cash flow profile by presenting certain business metrics for the periods under review, on a pro forma basis for the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions, the demerger of T-Infra and the application of IFRS 16, as applicable, in each case from January 1, 2018. For further information, see “Summary—Summary Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial Information.” ----- _Source: Company information. Notes: (1) Pro forma service revenues per segment where B2C mobile only incudes postpaid subscriptions and B2B mobile excludes revenues from IT partners and Gamma Communications Nederland (formerly named Dean One), a reseller of our B2B services. (2) Booked capital expenditures excluding spectrum._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Committed and experienced management team
Subsubsection Text: Our experienced management team is led by our CEO, Søren Abildgaard, and our CFO, Gero Niemeyer, each of whom has over 22 years of industry experience. Our management team is seasoned in running, acquiring and staffing telecommunications businesses and in navigating consumer markets both in The Netherlands and abroad, and they leverage the expertise they acquired over decades of combined experience at top-tier telecommunications and consultancy companies such as Telia, Orange, Magenta Telekom, KPN, Deloitte and Booz Allen Hamilton. More importantly, the management team has a strong track record of delivering growth from both organic initiatives and strategic acquisitions, and has won and maintained strong stakeholder support while maintaining a strong debt capital structure. This industry-leading management team is supported by a deep bench of divisional managers, who in turn are supported by a substantial workforce of 1,870 full-time equivalents as of September 30, 2021. Our employees, 48% of whom are customer-facing, are highly diverse, being represented by 45 distinct nationalities. Our management team has reached multiple milestones. Under our management’s leadership, revenue between 2018 and 2020 increased by a CAGR of 2% due to increasing B2C revenues, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA AcL Margin expanded from 22.8% in 2018 to 29.7% in 2020 as driven by an improved cost structure and synergies from the Tele2 acquisition. Furthermore, the team has successfully repositioned our company as a full FMC challenger in addition to having executed the Tele2 and Simpel acquisitions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: range of offerings at the low end _Source: Company Information._ Our strong commercial execution is supported by our multiple sales channels and highly optimized distribution network. We complement our in-store retail sales channel with an indirect sales channel that deploys more than 500 extra partner stores that we regard as vital to boost physical sales. On top of our brickand-mortar network, webshops for T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel serve as efficient and growing online channels that are instrumental for the sales of the whole brand portfolio. Our direct and indirect online channels accounted for more than 60% of our B2C sales in 2020, which we regard as proof of our established and effective digital presence. Furthermore, customer service for Ben and T-Mobile has been voted the best in the ----- Dutch telecommunications industry in 2021 as determined by a customer survey (Source: MarketResponse _customer survey). The quality of our customer service both in our physical locations and through our online_ presence has resulted both in continuous improvement of customer satisfaction and generation of FMC leads. The following chart summarizes key indicators of our status as the leading telecommunications operator in The Netherlands. _Source: Umlaut, Agentschap Telecom, Company information. Notes: (1) According to Umlaut. (2) Spectrum portfolios as of latest 5G auction in July 2020. (3) Average includes mobile operator network test from 2019 in Hungary and Slovakia, 2020 in Austria, Czech Republic, Finland, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Spain and Sweden, 2021 in Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Malta, Portugal and Romania. (4) Based on number of transactions, both gross adds and renewals._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Leverage our leading position in B2C mobile and benefit from market tailwinds on 5G monetization, unlimited offerings, portfolio optimization and increased value-added services
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading B2C mobile operator with a SIM market share of 42% in the B2C mobile postpaid market, corresponding to 5.1 million SIMs as of December 31, 2020. B2C revenue growth resulted from ----- stabilizing ARPUs in 2019 and 2020 as well as a growing subscriber base, further supported by growth in unlimited bundles on T-Mobile and Tele2 as well as an increasing demand for cheaper bundles with Ben and Simpel. We have also seen continued growth in our customer satisfaction. For B2C mobile, we have delivered the fastest increasing customer satisfaction TRI*M score over the last decade, having outpaced our competitors in The Netherlands. Our leading market position provides a strong platform for growth both in terms of volume and value across all brands and segments. In particular, we plan to grow ARPU through (i) 5G monetization, (ii) unlimited growth, (iii) portfolio optimizations, (iv) value-added services and (v) FMC growth. _Drive 5G monetization_ We were the first operator to reach nationwide 5G coverage on the 700 MHz band in 2020, and we believe that we are well positioned to monetize our 5G investments. We offer 5G connectivity per default to our premium offerings, such as T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan,’ or as an add-on to our value offerings, such as a €2 p.c.m. add-on for our Tele2 customers. In the future, we plan to extend our 5G offering and continue our more-for-more portfolio approach on the back of 5G. _Grow unlimited offerings_ We believe that we hold a leading position in unlimited offerings based on our number of subscribers and on our having been the first to have introduced an unlimited plan for mobile in The Netherlands. Our premium offers in the mobile segment are unlimited plans, which we sell for €35 p.c.m. and €25 p.c.m., including value added tax (“VAT”), through the T-Mobile and Tele2 brands respectively. T-Mobile’s ‘Unlimited plan’ also includes 5G connectivity by default. Having introduced these offerings in 2017, our unlimited subscriber base grew from 578,000 subscribers in December 2018 to more than a million subscribers in June 2021. In May 2021, we also introduced an ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ plan including access to Netflix and Videoland, a Dutch streaming service. We intend to continue to grow our unlimited offerings in the future as we believe that unlimited plans are a key value driver in our premium portfolio by increasing customer loyalty and customer satisfaction, and ultimately result in above-average monthly recurring charges (“MRC”). _Portfolio optimizations_ Our multi-brand portfolio is a key value driver that allows us to effectively compete in all market segments. All our brands have a distinctive positioning, minimizing the risk of intra-brand competition. With approximately 100,000 intra-brand migrations in 2020, creating an average incremental MRC of €1, we have proven the ability to upsell to customers within our portfolio, accruing value. _Value-added services_ We believe that by offering value-added services (“VAS”), we distinguish ourselves from our competitors while increasing ARPU, customer loyalty and customer satisfaction. Our new ‘Unlimited & Entertainment’ package, described above, is one such example. In addition, T-Mobile offers security options and add-ons from the music streaming service Deezer. On Tele2, we recently introduced ‘Unlimited for a day’ and ‘Unlimited weekend’ plans which add VAS to a Tele2 portfolio that already includes, among other things, a 5G priced add-on. _FMC growth_ Compared to KPN and VFZ, who have mobile FMC penetrations of 65% and 71% as of December 31, 2020, we believe that our FMC penetration of 8% as of December 31, 2020 provides us with ample opportunity for growth. While KPN and VFZ leverage their large fixed bases, we intend to focus on crossselling our fixed offerings into our leading consumer mobile base. Since FMC customers are more loyal, more satisfied and have higher monthly bill sizes compared to one-product customers, we expect FMC growth to be attractive, both, in terms of volume and value. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus
Subsubsection Text: We are a successful challenger in the B2C fixed market with approximately 9% market share by subscribers in 2020. In the past three years, as our business has grown its subscriber base and revenue at a CAGR of approximately 11%, marking the fastest growth among our competitors, our market share has grown from 7% in 2018 to 9% in 2020 and our share of total subscriber gross adds has grown from 17% in 2018 to 20% in 2020. We believe that we have been able to deliver this rapid, market-leading growth by leveraging our challenger strategy and B2C fixed ARPUs below those of our competition, as our fixed ARPU was approximately €33 for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, compared to the market average of approximately €50. Our price leadership is evidenced by our FMC offer which combines 1 Gbit internet speeds and a T-Mobile Unlimited subscription for a price of €50 p.m. (€25 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile subscription), compared to €90 p.m. at KPN (€65 p.m. internet + €25 p.m. mobile) and €93 p.m. at VFZ (€65.5 p.m. internet + €27.5 p.m. mobile). These consumer bundle prices are excluding promotions. We believe this lower fixed-segment ARPU and challenger strategy represents a strong lever to continue attracting valueseeking customers. As illustrated in the chart below, we are able to offer fixed and mobile services at a significantly lower price than our competitors. We have an FTTH footprint that covers approximately 1.6 million homes passed on KPN’s and Primevest’s networks. FTTH is also achieved through the Magenta footprint. We expect a further increase of approximately 500,000 homes passed by the end of 2021 and the Magenta footprint is expected to significantly increase homes passed by 2025. Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest partnerships are also key pillars of this strategy. We have secured exclusive agreements with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in addition to benefitting from non-exclusive ODF wholesale access to the KPN network, complemented by nationwide wholesale access via KPN bitstream. For more about our partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest, see “—Our _Competitive Strengths—High operational efficiency and an asset-light fixed model.” We believe that our_ partnerships with Open Dutch Fiber and Primevest in particular will allow us to grow our fixed subscriber base and drive margin expansion while maintaining healthy cash profile through our capital expenditure-light strategy. In the future, we plan to increase our revenue share through share gains at competitive ARPUs. First, we plan to tap our mobile subscriber base, which is the largest in The Netherlands, to cross-sell our fixed offerings to our mobile customers. In our T-Mobile brand, FMC penetration rose from 4% in 2018 to 20% in 2020, whereas overall for our company, FMC penetration increased from 2% in 2018 to 8% in 2020. However, our FMC penetration remains well below the FMC penetration of our competitors. We believe our penetration will grow in the future both as a result of a focused sales approach and because we expect more SIMs to become FMC-eligible in 2021-2022. Planned quality improvements will also help grow and maintain our fixed base through increased customer satisfaction and loyalty. Second, we will rely on highly-competitive ARPU levels to further drive market share gains. Going forward, we are considering shifting towards a value-based proposition by focusing on high-end fiber speeds and value-added services. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Exploit untapped B2B value pools and expand in fixed
Subsubsection Text: We have established a presence in the B2B market across all segments, namely SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE, both with our mobile and our fixed offerings which represent 71% and 29%, respectively, of our B2B revenue in 2020. Our presence extends across all B2B customer segments with our largest exposure in the SOHO/VSE and LE/CE segments at 36% of B2B mobile service revenues each, followed by the SMB segment with a 25% revenue share (Source: Company information). We have increased our revenue market share in the mobile B2B market from 17% in 2018 to 20% in 2020. For the past three years, we have the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator as measured by SIM net adds, having earned a 43% SIM net adds share in 2020 in comparison with 31% for the closest competitor. We believe this strategy highlights our success in attracting B2B mobile customers and managing churn well, and we believe it will fuel our growth in the coming years. In the fixed B2B market, we had a modest revenue market share of 4% in 2020, affording us an opportunity to grow our presence in the segment in 2021 and beyond. Among our key priorities, we aim to transform the former Tele2 large enterprise legacy business and expand into SOHO/VSE with fixed offerings. Recognizing the above growth path in B2B mobile and the opportunity in B2B fixed, we have defined a strategy to develop our potential in each of our SOHO/VSE, SMB and LE/CE B2B segments. Our entrepreneurial approach is built on four key growth drivers, namely (i) FMC offerings in the SOHO/VSE segment, (ii) an SMB portfolio that combines FMC offerings (a “converged” portfolio) with cloud-based service enhancements, (iii) a differentiating partner approach and (iv) fixed transformation in the LE/CE segment. _FMC offerings in the attractive SOHO/VSE segment_ The SOHO/VSE segment is a highly attractive market for our services, both because of its higher margins and because we believe we are well-positioned to succeed in this space as a result of its similarities with the B2C segment where we are a leader in mobile. This segment has rarely been tapped by either T-Mobile or Tele2 before and it is growing in line with the B2C market. See “—Our Competitive Strengths—Attractive _telecommunications market structure in The Netherlands.” Given our strength in mobile offerings in particular,_ we intend to target the SOHO/VSE segment by relying on FMC offerings. For example, in September 2021, we launched a VSE internet offering and related FMC bundling proposition in order to provide the best value for money, thus opening an additional market segment for us and a potential source of incremental revenue. _FMC and cloud-enhanced SMB portfolio along with differentiating partnering approach_ We operate in the SMB segment under the T-Mobile and selectively under the Tele2 brand for larger SMB customers. Our SMB offering comprises a product portfolio focused on FMC and cloud-enhanced solutions. In the SOHO/VSE segment, we strive for an increase of our Unlimited attach rate as a key value driver. In addition, we believe that our SMB FMC seats will increase, driven by, among other things, a Microsoft Teams integration that forms a unified communications solution which we were the first to launch in the Dutch market. We have a large mobile customer base and, as in the consumer market, we intend to upsell fixed and unified communications services to our mobile base. In addition to our core connectivity services, we sell a broad range of communications and cloud-based solutions tailored to the customers’ needs through our extensive partner portfolio. See also “—Capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus” above. _Fixed transformation in LE/CE_ In the LE/CE segment, we are conducting a transformation of our fixed services in order to realize the full potential of our extended portfolio. We are in the process of a transition from Tele2 legacy fixed infrastructure to future-proof transactional stacks in order to accommodate changing customer demands that request faster and more reliable connections and thus are switching to future-proof fiber-based technologies which includes a shift from copper to fiber, from VPN to SDWAN and a phase-out of ISDN. We also intend to supplement our stable fixed wholesale business with international carriers and Internet Service Providers by wholeselling active services in ODF areas. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Optimize our indirect cost base ratio
Subsubsection Text: We have an asset-light fixed model and have been focused on creating a lean operational setup since 2016 when we completed a reorganization under the name ‘Lean Telco’ with a headcount reduction of certain full-time equivalents and a savings target of €30 million. We further streamlined our business with a “3F – Fit For Future” initiative in 2018-2019, having achieved our further cost savings target of €100 million during the two year period 2018-2019. The focus in the coming years will be on optimization of our indirect cost base (“IDC”) ratio through: - _Focusing on smart growth by transforming remaining legacy architecture, digitizing processes towards self-service, improving fixed product quality and transforming the OSS while focusing on high-margin segments, thereby increasing our scale; - _Countering inflation with efficiencies by investing in marketing automation, robotic process automation and first-time right focus to deliver efficiency gains as they increase productivity; and - _Continuing to optimize costs by investing in systems and process improvements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Build on our ESG commitments
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several initiatives in order to improve our impact on the environment and society. We intend to build on our past ESG successes with a four-pillar ESG program. Our first pillar is sustainability. In 2020, we already used 100% green electricity and produced 60,000 kWh of renewable energy by using our own solar panels. In 2021, we introduced eco-plastic, E-SIMs and lighter packaging. Additionally, we have targeted a reduction to carbon neutral emission level by 2026. Furthermore, we will reduce new plastic packaging to zero by 2026. We continue to be involved in our community in other ways, such as our establishment of two partnerships to accelerate “Innovation for Society” projects in 2020. For 2021 and 2022, we aim to set up three impactful “Innovation for Society” partnerships to invest in e-health, education and smart cities. Going forward, we intend to continue setting up three partnerships a year. We also focus on digital inclusion, as our goal is to enable more people to be part of the digital society. In 2020, more than 2,500 people gained access to the digital society with our social SIM program and we reached more than 15,000 people through our debt prevention program. Our target is to reach more than 25,000 disadvantaged individuals every year. Lastly, our management aims to foster an environment in which everyone feels included. We have set up a dedicated work stream in the diversity and inclusion program focused on activities and awareness within the company, sharpened our policy on social return and set up a “Back to work” fund. For 2021 and 2022, our focus is on diversity and inclusion, such as through setting up gender-neutral communication and starting the dialogue on safety and belonging. Our goal is to be a 100% inclusive organization by 2025. ----- _Notes: (1) Sustainable Development Goals of United Nations, of which there are 17 in total_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have detailed commercial plans to support our further growth, both in terms of volume and of value, for all brands and segments. In particular, we have identified a number of key drivers leading to growth in our business which we believe will preserve our leadership position in the future, namely (i) leverage our leading position in the B2C mobile market, (ii) capital-efficient fixed strategy with fiber focus, (iii) exploitation of untapped B2B value pools and expansion in fixed and (iv) optimization of our indirect cost base ratio, with (v) a commitment to ESG initiatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: TMNL’s primary subsidiaries consist of (i) T-Mobile Netherlands and its subsidiaries, including TMobile Netherlands Retail B.V. (“T-Mobile Netherlands Retail”) and, indirectly through Complex Bidco B.V., Simpel.nl B.V. (“Simpel”), (ii) T-Mobile Thuis B.V. (“T-Mobile Thuis”) and (iii) T-Mobile Netherlands Finance B.V. (“T-Mobile Netherlands Finance”). T-Mobile Netherlands Finance holds the financial markets license for consumer credit issued by AFM and is the contracting party for consumers obtaining credit for products provided by us. Our origins can be traced back to two acquisitions in The Netherlands by the group headed by Deutsche Telekom AG (the “Deutsche Telekom Group”). In September 2002, the Deutsche Telekom Group acquired the Dutch mobile operator Ben Nederland Holding B.V., whose name was then changed to T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. in February 2003. The Deutsche Telekom Group also rebranded Ben to T-Mobile in February 2003, marking the introduction of the T-Mobile brand in The Netherlands. In September 2007, we acquired Orange Nederland N.V. and Orange Nederland Breedband B.V. from the France Télécom S.A. group. The fixed line component of this business, acquired under Orange Nederland Breedband B.V., was eventually rebranded and sold in January 2014 under the Online.nl brand. In 2008, we relaunched Ben as a budget brand. In April 2010, we acquired the customer base and the ‘Simpel’ brand of the mobile service provider Simpel Consumenten B.V from its founder Jasper de Rooij. We transferred the customer base and brand back to de Rooij and investors in August 2014 by concluding an asset purchase agreement, and we also then signed an MVNO agreement with Simpel, the successor company of the business, under which Simpel continued to use our network. In December 2016, we acquired from Vodafone Libertel B.V. the B2C fixed line internet business of Vodafone Thuis in The Netherlands, which we renamed T-Mobile Thuis. Vodafone divested this business as the result of an antitrust remedy ordered by the European Commission to provide clearance for the VFZ joint venture. This acquisition added approximately 160,000 customers. On September 1, 2018, we carved out our tower business by way of a legal demerger (juridische _splitsing) from TMNL to Cignal Infrastructure (until June 2021, named T-Mobile Infra B.V.). As part of the_ demerger, Cignal Infrastructure was incorporated as a 100% subsidiary of T-Mobile Netherlands. On December 17, 2018, T-Mobile Netherlands and Cignal Infrastructure entered into a master services agreement governing the relationship between us and Cignal Infrastructure and the terms and conditions of our access to these passive infrastructure elements. Ultimately, Cignal Infrastructure was distributed as a dividend in kind to Deutsche Telekom on January 1, 2019. As part of a later transfer of Cignal Infrastructure to Cellnex Netherlands B.V., on May 27, 2021 T-Mobile Netherlands and Cignal Infrastructure entered into an amended and restated master lease agreement which replaced the master services agreement dated December 17, 2018. ----- On January 2, 2019, we completed the acquisition of Tele2. The seller, Tele2 Sweden, received approximately €190 million in cash and 25% of the issued and outstanding shares of TMNL. This transaction was subject to the approval of European antitrust authorities, and final and unconditional approval was obtained from the European Commission on November 27, 2018. This acquisition better enabled us to become an integrated telecommunications provider by deepening our capacity to offer fixed and mobile subscriptions. On December 1, 2020, we acquired Simpel pursuant to the exercise of a call option we had signed in July 2019 for the acquisition of 100% of Complex Bidco B.V. and its 100% subsidiary, Simpel. This transaction gained the unconditional approval of the ACM on November 16, 2020. Simpel had previously exclusively marketed SIM-only subscriptions through its own website, using SIM cards that operated on the T‑Mobile Netherlands network. This acquisition was effectuated in order to secure mobile market shares, create synergies, and make us more competitive in the SIM-only consumer market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our business operates entirely in The Netherlands and all of our revenue is generated from The Netherlands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We offer a complete portfolio of telecommunications services and products to customers and operate in two main customer segments: B2C and B2B. In addition, we also present in our results, an “other” segment which consist of other revenues such as wholesale revenues and costs related to the Target Group’s headquarters. Set forth below is a breakdown of our net revenue by customer type for the periods indicated:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Year** **Nine months ended December 31** **ended September 30, 2018** **2019** **2020** **2020** **2021 (audited)** **(audited)** **(audited)** **(unaudited)** **(unaudited) Net Revenue breakdown (€ in thousands)

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _B2C segment_ The B2C segment represents our largest customer segment, constituting 74.9% and 79.0% of our net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021, respectively. Customers in this segment are offered landline, mobile phone, broadband and bundled services mainly marketed under the T-Mobile, Tele2, Ben and Simpel brands. Specifically, we provide our B2C customers with the following multi-brand portfolio of services, aiming to cover all segments of the market: - Mobile services: we provide voice services, SMS/MMS and mobile broadband through our own networks of 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G spectra, with 2G scheduled to be phased out shortly. We offer consumers mobile flexible bundled and unbundled service packages through our key brands: - T-Mobile: T-Mobile is our premium B2C mobile brand, focusing on premium-seekers and households. It offers 24-month and 12-month subscriptions and combines premium handset sales. This brand offers limited and unlimited data, text, and talk packages on both 4G and 5G spectra. Through T-Mobile Thuis, it also offers a fixed internet package with an option to purchase voice and TV add-ons, as well as FMC packages. We market our TMobile brand through an omni-channel approach, leveraging retail stores, online sales, telesales and indirect sales. T-Mobile’s key competitors include KPN and VFZ. ----- - Tele2: Tele2 is our value brand, aimed at value-seekers and digital natives. It also offers limited and unlimited bundles with 5G as an add-on, and it also offers handsets. We intend Tele2 to operate within its own value segment. - Ben: Ben is our budget-conscious brand. It offers SIM-only subscriptions in the 4G spectrum along with a basic portfolio of handsets. Key competitors include Simyo and Hollandsnieuwe, which are KPN’s and VFZ’s budget brands, respectively. - Simpel: Simpel is our low-budget mobile brand. It offers SIM-only subscriptions on the 4G spectrum exclusively through its website. Simpel’s key competitor is Youfone, which is an MVNO on the KPN network. - Fixed services: Through T-Mobile Thuis, we offer nationwide fixed broadband, TV and fixed voice services with FTTH and xDSL (copper) technologies. FTTH is offered via Primevest, Open Dutch Fiber and KPN networks based on unbundled access through an ODF access as well as VULA and WBA access with KPN. We also use KPN’s copper network based on unbundled access through MDF, VULA and WBA. We also offer to combine T-Mobile Thuis’s fixed service with T-Mobile or Tele2 subscriptions, as these FMC packages offer discounts and other benefits for the customer in comparison to standalone service purchase. _B2B segment_ Our B2B segment is dedicated to meeting the telecommunications needs of companies of all types and sizes as we aim to offer telecommunications solutions and cloud based services to businesses to accompany them in their growth. The B2B segment constituted 18.2% and 17.5% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021, respectively. For both our SOHO/VSE customers and our SMB customers, we offer FMC bundles that combine fixed telephony landline, mobile phone, SMS/MMS, broadband and data services, as well as other value-added services such as data centers, Unified Communications, security, cloud, storage, virtual PBX, email and videoconferencing. These bundled services allow clients access to broadband internet and fixed and mobile telephony services which are invoiced jointly at competitive prices. Contracts from our LE/CE customers, by contrast, are typically awarded by customized, separate mobile and fixed services tenders, and may also include data network services. We additionally offer standalone B2B mobile services, notably through our ‘@Work’ plans which allow subscribers to adjust monthly their data limits and which include unlimited data plan choices. B2B mobile revenues accounted for approximately 10% of our total revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020 and for the past three years we have been the fastest-growing B2B mobile operator in the Dutch telecommunications market as measured by net adds. For SMB and LE/CE customers, fixed internet services are currently offered under the Tele2 brand while SOHO/VSE customers are currently offered fixed internet services under the T-Mobile brand. _Other_ We have also entered into several wholesale agreements for the sale of certain services, such as Ethernet connections or access to our mobile radio networks, to other providers of mobile and fixed telecommunications services. These services are consolidated in the Other segment, which constituted 6.9% and 3.6% of our total company revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2021, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Mobile networks and spectrum
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2021, our national access network comprised 4,956 macro outdoor sites. For an overview of the frequency bands on which these nodes are used to broadcast our network, see “—Licenses” below. Currently, our 4G mobile network reaches approximately 99.98% of the Dutch population and our 5G network reaches 92.31% of the Dutch population.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Fixed networks
Subsubsection Text: Our fixed internet service is generally offered under the T-Mobile Thuis brand. The Magenta footprint of our fixed internet service offers fiber internet through an ODF access as a result of several agreements and partnerships. We have agreements with Reggefiber Operator B.V., a member of the KPN group, to provide ODF access to their fiber network, which currently extends to 2 million homes passed as of September 30, 2021. Either party under certain conditions may terminate these agreements, including the condition that they may be terminated by Reggefiber Operator B.V. with two years’ notice if Reggefiber Operator B.V. is no longer required by law or regulation to provide access to its fiber grid. We also have an exclusive agreement to be the anchor tenant of Open Dutch Fiber, a joint venture between KKR and Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners, which aims to deploy to one million homes passed by 2025, mainly in dense urban areas with no targeted overbuild of existing FTTH. Finally, we have an agreement with Primevest Capital Partners according to which we will serve as an anchor tenant on a FTTH, very high speed internet network that Primevest Capital Partners and their construction partner, VolkerWessels, will build. Following the pilot in The Hague’s Segbroek area, this joint venture will build or has already built fiber networks in The Hague’s Loosduinen area as well as Eindhoven and Rotterdam. This network is expected to extend to over 130,000 homes passed by mid-2022. Under the terms of both of these agreements we are obligated to maintain certain utilization rates which we expect to be able to maintain. Most of the remainder of our nationwide fixed internet footprint currently relies upon KPN providing us with WBA, MDF, ODF and VULA, whether through agreements that we have made with KPN and its affiliates or through legacy contracts that we have inherited upon acquiring Tele2. This involves wholesale broadband access by means of virtual unbundled local access under an open wholesale model. For more information about our wholesale agreements with KPN, see “—Material Contracts—KPN Wholesale _Agreements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our network is distributed throughout The Netherlands and provides both fixed line and mobile services to customers, routing calls and data, including circuit switching services, packages switching, authentication, data bridge with other networks, upload to the internet, value added services and interconnection ----- to other networks. Although we own our mobile network, we do not generally own the passive infrastructure of either our mobile or fixed networks but lease them or contract for access to them from other companies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _B2C segment_ We use different sales channels to market our products and services with an aim to optimize customer reach and reduce costs. Our main sales channels are the following: - Exclusive retail stores: we currently operate 124 retail stores across The Netherlands, with a slightly higher concentration in the _Randstad, the metropolitan area comprising Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Utrecht and The Hague. As of March 31, 2021, we operated these shops with an average of 3.9 FTE per shop. In addition to providing for sales of traditional mobile offerings, the stores represent an opportunity to market fixed broadband and bundled packages. We rent all shop buildings from third parties and have incorporated our retail business in a separate legal entity, TMobile Netherlands Retail. - Indirect sales: we leverage relationships with key telecommunications partners to sell T-Mobile-, Tele2- and Ben-branded products both online and through several offline resellers with presence in more than 500 stores nationwide. Additionally, in fiber roll-out areas, we engage door-to-door partners to sell T-Mobile Thuis-branded fixed internet. ----- - Online sales: we have prioritized the growth of our online sales channel, which benefits from lower costs than brick-and-mortar storefront. We reached a high benchmark in online sales, with approximately 46% of overall sales implemented through digital channels in 2020, excluding our indirect online sales. Each brand has its own brand-specific website and a dedicated digital marketing strategy supported by big data platforms to optimize media investment, traffic and conversion rates. Simpel’s online sales channel represents its only platform for customer interaction. - Telesales: we sell our products and services by telephone through our own and third-party call centers, using both active direct to consumer telephone marketing and passive advertising in print, online and television media. Our telesales channel not only focuses on customer retention but also serves as important up-selling and cross-selling routes, as into fixed or FMC packages. _B2B segment_ In our B2B segment, we take a differentiated approach to sales with a focus on maximizing growth while optimizing cost to sell. At the SOHO/VSE level, we employ multiple distribution channels, including telesales, our retail shops, online sales through our B2B web shop and sales through retail partners. At the SMB level we rely mainly on dedicated retail partners, with some direct business channels. Finally, at the LE/CE level, we employ key account management for all our clients, deploying both retention and acquisition teams.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our Magenta business support system (“BSS”) stack forms the foundation for consolidating our brands and customer segments into a suite of systems. The Magenta stack deploys industry-leading BSS systems, such as Salesforce, Tibco, BSCS, Netcracker and SAP, and features a high degree of consolidation with no duplicate systems. Services under the Ben brand are mostly based on the Magenta BSS systems but with independent sales systems and customer relationship management provided by SugarCRM. The Simpel brand features a fully outsourced, standalone BSS environment, while a legacy Tele2 BSS is maintained by Cognizant and services a small number of LE/CE customers. We rely on Atos, Wipro and Netcracker for application development and maintenance services as well as, in the case of Atos and Wipro, infrastructure delivery and management on Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services, as well as other related services. Wipro also provides our external 24x7 IT service desk. Salesforce provides us its customer relationship management system. Our IT infrastructure is based on a hybrid architecture deployed in private and public clouds and houses a large number of applications for our business units and customers. We operate on a “cloud first” principle such that new workloads are deployed to the public cloud by default, and more than 90% of the Magenta BSS has been migrated to the cloud. However, in recognizing that not all IT workloads are cloud-ready, we migrate our applications to the public or private cloud based on the requirements of our business technology, taking into account our security-by-design framework, which aims to guarantee the security of our applications and our compliance with relevant regulations. All personnel involved in software development activities are required to follow an obligatory security awareness and security-by-design e-learning. We have implemented polices and systems for GDPR compliance that consist of, among other things, a data processing register, privacy statements for customers and employees, a group security policy, a data retention policy, a data breach and notification policy and internal instructions on how to deal with data subjects’ rights and requests. Our designated, full-time Data Privacy Officer (“DPO”) is registered with AP and is supported by (i) a Privacy and Complaints team, (ii) a Privacy and Compliance Specialist, (iii) risk officers, who are a part of our Governance, Risk Management and Compliance Department and (iv) by the legal department. In addition to providing our employees with our data protection policy along with instructions regarding the secure handling of data, we require our employees to complete a GDPR e-learning that is repeated every two years. We are closely monitoring developments regarding the European Commission’s proposal for an ePrivacy Regulation. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We rely on infrastructure agreements with Koning & Hartman, Spie and VolkerWessels for the construction and/or operation of our mobile networks. We also have agreements (i) with Nokia, Cisco, Ericsson and Huawei for mobile access, core infrastructure equipment and transmission equipment, (ii) with Cignal Infrastructure for mobile towers, (iii) with Open Dutch Fiber, Primevest and KPN for our access to the FTTH our partners are deploying, (iv) with Amazon Web Services, Azure, Atos and Wipro for IT equipment, development and cloud services, (v) with Zyxel for our modems and customer premises equipment and Guidion for home installations and (vi) with Soluno and Eurofiber for our B2B solutions. We had also previously engaged Huawei to supply certain network-related hardware, software and services. Since the United States’ decision in May 2019 to impose restrictions on business dealings with Huawei, we have been in close contact with the Dutch authorities with regards to the security of our network. Following the Telecommunications Security and Integrity Decree of November 2019 (Regeling veiligheid en _integriteit telecommunicaite, since supplemented by the additional rules of October 2021), in April of 2021, we_ received an individual decision from the Dutch government in which requires us to replace certain specificallyidentified equipment during over a 5-year transition period. This transition period is in line with our usual replacement cycle, and we have identified and have implemented or are implementing a transition to nonrestricted suppliers for the affected network elements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
