Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The increase in employees in the period is related to acquisitions of new subsidiaries, together with organic growth and business expansion. In addition to the work performed by employees, we outsource certain services to third parties, such as call-center services, and make use of independent contractors and agency workers through T-Mobile Netherlands and T-Mobile Netherlands Retail for individuals working in stores. All retail employees are subject to the collective labor agreement for the electro-technical retail trade (CAO voor de Elektrotechnische _Detailhandel)._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe the sum insured, the limits of liability, the deductibles and scope of cover in our policies are satisfactory and suitable for companies acting in the telecommunications sector (subject to the wording of the policies, conditions and exclusions). However, we cannot guarantee that no losses will be incurred or that no claims will be filed against us which go beyond the type and scope of the existing insurance coverage, and we do not insure against war, terrorism and epidemic or pandemic risks. Following the Acquisition, some of our insurance policies will need to be arranged on a standalone basis. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have the largest spectrum portfolio in The Netherlands with advantageous positioning in the interference-free lower bands, which is both cost-efficient and gives us an indoor capacity advantage relative to our competitors. In the low frequency bands, we have 10 MHz of paired spectrum in the 700 MHz band, 10 MHz of paired spectrum in the 800 MHz band and 15 MHz of paired spectrum in the 900 MHz band, with license renewal dates in December 2040, January 2030 and February 2030, respectively. In the mid frequency bands, we have 10 MHz of spectrum in the 1,400 MHz band, 30 MHz of paired spectrum in the 1,800 MHz band and 20 MHz of paired spectrum in the 2,100 MHz band, with license renewal dates in December 2040, December 2029 and February 2030, and December 2040, respectively. In the high frequency bands, we have 25 MHz of paired spectrum in the 2,600 MHz band and 20 MHz of spectrum in the 2,600 MHz band, with license renewal dates in May 2030 and January 2030, respectively. For a visual summary of these licenses in comparison with our competitors’ spectrum portfolios, see the chart below. _Note: Based on used frequencies only, excluding guard bands. 10 MHz has been excluded for TMNL and KPN, respectively, on the 2,600 MHz band as this represents unused frequencies. VFZ currently offers 5G on the 1,800 MHz band, using DSS. Based on 2020 mobile SIMs (postpaid, prepaid and B2B), TMNL including Tele2 and Simpel. Source: Publicly available sources/management estimates_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our real estate consists of leased stores and leased office locations as well as network infrastructure, the latter pursuant to a combination of lease and other agreements. Our headquarters are subject to a guarantee provided by Deutsche Telekom that will be withdrawn following the Acquisition and will need to be replaced and agreed upon with the lessor. Our entitlement to the network infrastructure required for conducting our business is based on (i) rights of superficies related to antenna locations, (ii) lease agreements for PoP or MSC locations, which are distribution stations which support the operations of a fixed or mobile network, (iii) site rental agreements for installing mobile equipment and (iv) a commercial agreement with Cignal Infrastructure. See also “Material ContractsOther Agreements.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Following the Acquisition, we will have to deal on a standalone basis with certain procedures that until now had been dealt with through Deutsche Telekom AG and its affiliates, or through frameworks arranged by ----- Deutsche Telekom AG and its affiliates, such as (i) our license to the T-Mobile brand, which automatically renewed while we were a member of the Deutsche Telekom Group but which we will need to agree or negotiate to extend with Deutsche Telekom AG once the term of the license which we will acquire in connection with the Acquisition expires, (ii) services that the Deutsche Telekom Group provided to us relating to IT, network, marketing, personnel and procurement, (iii) cash pooling and cash management arrangements for financing and treasury solutions, (iv) existing parent guarantees to third parties for our benefit and (v) insurance policies. In this regard, as a condition of completing of the Acquisition, we will enter into a transitional services agreement with Deutsche Telekom AG pursuant to which the Deutsche Telekom AG and/or its affiliates would agree to provide us the relevant transitional support and services for certain agreed fees. We expect to avail of transitional services from Deutsche Telekom and/or its affiliates for up to five years after the Acquisition. See also “Risk _FactorsRisks Relating to Our Separation from Deutsche Telekom.”_ In addition to altering the terms of our license of the T-Mobile brand in connection with the Acquisition (see “—Material Contracts—T-Mobile License Agreement”), under the transitional services agreement that will come into effect upon completion of the Acquisition, we expect that Deutsche Telekom AG and its affiliates will continue to provide many of the network and IT resources it currently provides to us on similar pricing, including IoT, wholesale and interconnect billing, handset and SIM card management, subscriber data management and messaging platforms, RAN and mobile core, and cloud services. We may incur significant one-time costs in transitioning away from other Deutsche Telekom Group network and IT services, among other agreements, and we may face reduced buying power for other services, such as cloud services. See “Risk _FactorsWe may experience increased costs resulting from a decrease in the purchasing power that we may have had during the period when we were owned by Deutsche Telekom.” Additionally, and among other_ changes, we will enter into a roaming broker arrangement on commercial terms with Deutsche Telekom and/or its affiliates, whereas previously we had a roaming broker arrangement with Deutsche Telekom on preferential rates, and we will need to manage our own cash pooling and factoring arrangements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are involved in legal, regulatory, tax and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of our business. The proceedings initiated against us may include, among others, the following categories of claims: claims by or on behalf of customers on grounds such as alleged misrepresentation, breach of service or license terms, breach of telecommunications, consumer, health, privacy and unauthorized access and safety regulations, or intellectual property claims primarily relating to alleged copyright infringement brought by copyright collection entities; claims by suppliers and other telecommunications providers, including telecommunications providers who use our network pursuant to wholesale services arrangements; claims by employees; claims by tax authorities with respect to tax matters such as VAT, transfer taxes and property tax; and claims by other administrative bodies or agencies such as claims for breach of data protection or consumer protection regulations. In line with an agreement we made with Dutch tax authorities in the past, we currently do not charge VAT over disconnection fees. The Dutch tax authorities are having an internal discussion to determine their view in this matter. The Dutch tax authorities may challenge our view that the disconnection fees are not subject to VAT. Any such action may have material adverse effect on our reputation, financial condition or results of operations. Additionally, we are currently being investigated by the AT, in joint cooperation with the AP, regarding alleged breaches of data protection and telecommunications laws in connection with our sharing certain aggregated and anonymized customer location data with CBS under a partnership with CBS that has since terminated. If it finds against us, the AT could impose a fine of up to €900,000. For more information about the AT investigation, see “Risk Factors—We face risks arising from the outcome of various criminal, _civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.”_ Prior to changing our debt collection processes and agencies in the first quarter of 2020, we sold customer invoice receivables to Direct Pay, who, as of September 30, 2021, continues to owe us €4.3 million under our agreement with them, which we have currently provisioned as bad debt. However, Direct Pay has submitted claims to us in the aggregate amount of €7.5 million, first, that we have not provided sufficient documentation regarding customer contracts and invoices, and second, that it lost profits due to unforeseen ----- changes in the regulatory environment that diminished its ability to collect on the debts, and that we should share the burden of such alleged lost profits. We discussed the matter with Direct Pay in the course of the third quarter of 2021 but have been unable to resolve the dispute amicably thus far. We or Direct Pay may initiate legal proceedings if we are not able to resolve this matter. Further, we have been involved in litigation involving our prior and discontinued offer of ‘free handsets’ to consumers along with mobile subscriptions, referred to as ‘all-in subscriptions.’ In 2014 and 2016, the Supreme Court of The Netherlands gave interlocutory decisions in which it concluded that such offerings were not compliant with statutory provisions on installment purchases, credit transactions and credit agreements. We had voluntarily stopped offering such all-in subscriptions on September 9, 2014 for direct sales and January 18, 2015 for indirect sales. Tele2, which we subsequently acquired, also offered all-in subscriptions and stopped offering them on September 1, 2014. Subsequently, multiple claims vehicles and foundations have solicited individuals to initiate mass claims against telecommunications providers who offered all-in subscriptions. We have been in contact with several vehicles and foundations in order to reach a settlement and have reached a settlement with Consumentenbond and ConsumentenClaim in October 2020 in particular regarding the period and type of mobile subscription eligible for compensation as well as the calculation method for the amount of compensation per customer. We have finalized processing claims under this settlement. However, this settlement does not cover claims submitted by other claims vehicles and foundations. For instance, we are in settlement discussions with MobiClaim in particular regarding potential claims on the same matter from claimants who are not party to any settlements thus far, and ConTel approached us in mid-2021 to express a willingness to pursue certain claims that have been pending since 2016. Such negotiations may fail and it is possible that MobiClaim or ConTel will initiate legal proceedings. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not aware of any other legal, administrative, judicial, regulatory, tax or arbitral proceedings or investigations (including any pending or threatened proceedings or investigations) that are likely to have, or have had, individually or in the aggregate, a material adverse effect on our reputation, financial condition or results of operations. The outcome of legal proceedings and investigations, however, can be extremely difficult to predict with certainty, and we can offer no assurances in this regard. See also “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Legislative and Regulatory Matters—We face risks _arising from the outcome of various criminal, civil, administrative and regulatory proceedings.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations relating to land use, environmental protection and health and safety in connection with our ownership of real property and other operations. While we could incur costs, such as clean-up costs, fines and third-party claims for property damage or personal injury as a result of violations of or liabilities under such laws or regulations, we believe we substantially comply with the applicable requirements of such laws and regulations and follow standardized procedures to manage environmental risks. Given the scope of our activities and the property, plant and equipment we own or operate, we believe that there are no environmental factors likely to have a significant impact on the use of our current property, plant and equipment other than as disclosed in “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our _business may be adversely affected by actual or perceived health risks and other environmental requirements relating to mobile telecommunications transmission equipment and devices, including the location of antennas.” We have recognized no material liabilities, expenses, assets or contingencies, and have made no_ provisions, relating to environmental matters. With regards to our mobile network, we comply with regulations setting out rules governing the public radio domain, restrictions on radio-electric emissions and health protection measures. Radiocommunications Agency Netherlands (“AT”) (Agentschap Telecom) performs regular checks on us to verify our compliance with our license obligations. We carry out all of our activities in strict compliance with applicable regulations, and in accordance with Dutch recommendations, to safeguard public health. We are committed to ESG initiatives and have made it a priority to focus on several commitments in order to improve our impact on the environment and society. For a description of some of our ESG initiatives, see “—Our Strategy— Build on our ESG commitments” above. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: KPN Wholesale Agreements
Subsubsection Text: Between 1998 and 2018, we or our legal predecessors executed a series of non-exclusive framework agreements with KPN and affiliated companies that provide us access to their copper and fiber fixed internet networks. These agreements are generally effectively of indefinite length and provide various termination rights to both T-Mobile Netherlands or its subsidiaries and to KPN and its affiliates. In particular, under these framework agreements, KPN or its affiliates may terminate the agreements or services under the agreements with between two months’ and two years’ notice. These agreements provide us with MDF access services, WBA on the OWM and through VULA, and usage rights to fiber networks. We are largely dependent on wholesale access to KPN’s fixed network for both bitstream access and (virtual) unbundled wholesale access products. Wholesale access to KPN’s fixed network was previously regulated by the ACM based on “significant market power” (“SMP”) provisions in the Dutch Telecommunications Act. As a result of a March 2020 decision by the CBb, no such SMP provisions apply and KPN is no longer required to provide access to its copper and fiber networks. As we can no longer rely on the former regulatory framework, KPN and its affiliates could potentially charge prices for access without regulatory restriction or deny us access. At the moment we are largely protected against price increases for the wholesale access services we purchase from KPN and their affiliates by the terms of the contracts that we have concluded with them, with the exception of our contracts for MDF access, where we lack such price protection. At our request, the ACM is reviewing ways of restoring regulation to KPN’s fiber network through SMP or through competent authorities’ ability to impose symmetric regulation as provided for in the European Electronic Communications Code.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Cignal Infrastructure Master Services Agreement
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the carve-out of our passive telecommunications tower infrastructure to a separate legal entity in 2018 (see “—History of the Target Group”), in December 2018 we signed a master services agreement with Cignal Infrastructure, then known as T-Mobile Infra B.V., which governed the relationship between us and the demerged tower business. Our current relationship is governed by an amended and restated master lease agreement which we signed with Cignal Infrastructure on May 27, 2021. Under the agreement, we benefit from access to 3,150 towers owned by Cignal Infrastructure with nationwide coverage under a long term contract for an initial term of 15 years, with the option for T-Mobile Netherlands to renew for two additional periods of 10 years each, and at favorable terms consisting of a capped yearly cost increase in line with the Consumer Price Index.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Primevest Partners Partnership
Subsubsection Text: On April 9, 2019 we signed an agreement with PCIF NL I S.A.R.L., a subsidiary of Primevest Partners, according to which we will serve as an anchor tenant on a FTTH, very high speed internet network that Primevest Capital Partners and VolkerWessels will build. Following the pilot in The Hague’s Segbroek area, this joint venture will build or has already built fiber networks in The Hague’s Loosduinen area as well as Eindhoven and Rotterdam. This network is expected to extend to over 130,000 homes passed by mid-2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Open Dutch Fiber Partnership
Subsubsection Text: RootsOpCo B.V. (“Open Dutch Fiber”) is a joint venture between KKR as majority shareholder (80%) and Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners as minority shareholder (20%) which has committed to rolling ----- out a fiber network to at least one million households in The Netherlands over a five-year period. The project involves total investments into Open Dutch Fiber of at least €700 million. On April 1, 2021, we signed an agreement to become Open Dutch Fiber’s anchor tenant under a 20year contract in which the base wholesale tariff we will be charged ranges from €13 to €15 per month, per line, subject to certain adjustments, including an index to the Consumer Price Index with a cap of 3% p.a. We were not involved in, and are not a party to, agreements that relate to the debt or equity financing of the Open Dutch Fiber project.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: T-Mobile License Agreement
Subsubsection Text: We license the T-Mobile brand and various Deutsche Telekom AG trademarks and domain names under a December 22, 2004 sublicense agreement between T-Mobile Netherlands and T-Mobile Global Holding GmbH, then a member of the Deutsche Telekom Group who as licensor eventually merged into Deutsche Telekom AG. This sub-license incorporates by reference the terms of a December 22, 2004 license agreement between Deutsche Telekom AG and T-Mobile International AG & Co. KG. According to the terms of these agreements, as amended, we license the T-Mobile brand for a fixed percentage of the revenue we derive from the use of the T-Mobile brand. Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, upon completion of the Acquisition we will sign a non-exclusive agreement with Deutsche Telekom AG on agreed terms under which we will license the T-Mobile brand from them for a fixed percentage of the revenue we derive from the use of the T-Mobile brand for an initial term of five years, extendable by mutual consent.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Tele2 License Agreement
Subsubsection Text: We use the Tele2 brand under an eight-year license agreement with Tele2 Sweden dated February 11, 2019, according to which we make quarterly payments to Tele2 Sweden out of the revenues from sales under the Tele2 brand. Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, upon completion of the Acquisition we will sign a non-exclusive agreement with Tele2 Sweden under which we license the T-Mobile brand for them for a certain percentage of our Tele2-branded revenue for an initial term of ten years, with such percentage varying over that term according to a schedule.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other Agreements
Subsubsection Text: Other key agreements include, among others, agreements with resellers and dealers, producers of television content, and agreements for the distribution of TV channels. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to _Our Business and Industry—We depend on third parties to market, sell and provide a portion of our mobile and fixed line products and services. If we fail to maintain or further develop our distribution and customer care channels, our ability to sustain and further grow our subscriber base could be materially adversely affected._ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our key supplier agreements relate to, among other, interconnection and transit interworking and roaming, network technology, information technology, logistics, outsourcing, advertising and handsets. Furthermore as explained below, KPN is a material supplier for the fixed business of the T-Mobile Thuis and Tele2 brands. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We depend on certain key _partners and other third parties for the provision of hardware, software and other providers of outsourced services, who may discontinue their services or products, seek to charge us prices that are not competitive or choose not to renew contracts with us.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our business is subject to various regulatory requirements and obligations including communications and broadcasting laws, general antitrust law, environmental, health and safety laws, planning and construction laws, consumer protection laws as well as technical and other regulations in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate. Such laws and regulations are promulgated and enforced to varying degrees by supranational regulators such as the European Commission (“Commission”) and national, state, regional and local authorities. The regulatory environment can have a material effect on our activities. Certain key provisions of the regulations governing our activities in The Netherlands as of the date of this Offering Memorandum are set forth below. This description is not intended to be an exhaustive description of all regulation in this area nor a review of specific obligations which have been imposed on us.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Summary of European regulation
Subsubsection Text: In the last eighteen (18) years, the telecommunications market in the European Union has been gradually deregulated. In March 2002, the European Union approved a new regulatory framework for electronic communications (the “RF” or “regulatory framework”), in order to adopt a harmonized regulatory framework among the Member States. The RF was originally composed of five directives (the “Directives”): - _Framework directive: a common regulatory framework for electronic communication networks and services that establishes the general principles of the RF, as well as the procedure that should be followed by national regulating authorities to impose _ex ante obligations on operators with significant market power (“SMP”). - _Universal service directive: this regulates the universal service and the rights of users of communication networks and services. - _Access directive: this regulates access to electronic communication networks and their interconnection. - _Authorization directive: this regulates the authorization of communication networks and services; and - _Directive on privacy and electronic communications: this regulates the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in electronic communications. This regulatory framework also includes three key elements: - a recommendation from the European Commission on important markets subject to _ex ante regulation (the “Market Recommendation”); - guidelines on market analysis and the assessment of SMP (the “Guidelines”); and - the decision on a regulatory framework for the radio-electric spectrum. In November 2009, the regulatory package on electronic communications was revised in a process that took two years, with the involvement of the European Commission, Parliament and Council. The main change consisted of the increase in the powers of the Commission to coordinate the use of the radio-electric spectrum, and the Commission was also granted greater powers regarding the obligations that national regulatory ----- authorities could impose on operators with significant market power, specifically when these could create barriers to the single market or violate EU legislation. The revised directives also contain a set of provisions relating to new generation networks, consumer rights and (as an exceptional measure) the functional separation of vertically-integrated companies. This measure is adopted when the regulatory authority concludes that the obligations imposed by national regulatory authorities on operators with significant market power in accordance with applicable legislation have not produced effective competition and there are major, persistent competition problems and/or market risks related to the wholesale provision of certain access markets. In 2007, a new market recommendation was adopted by the Commission, repealing and replacing the previous 2003 Market Recommendation, by virtue of which the markets potentially subject to ex ante regulation were reduced from eighteen to seven . This reduction included most retail markets, mobile network access markets and the broadcast market. In November 2009, the European Parliament and the Regulation of the European Council created the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (the “BEREC”), a European body of national regulatory authorities that acts as a consultative committee of the European Commission. The BEREC began its activities in January 2010. The regulatory framework applicable to this body was changed by European Regulations on December 11, 2018. Since then, the European Commission has updated its recommendation for markets in the 2014 Market Recommendation, removing the fixed access retail markets and wholesale rented lines with the markets subject to ex ante regulation being reduced to four. Specifically, termination markets on fixed and mobile networks (markets 1 and 2, respectively) and the access market to broadband in its residential and business sectors (markets 3a, 3b and 4) were retained. Subsequently in 2020 the European Commission adopted a new Recommendation (2020/2245) on relevant markets, reducing its remaining defined markets to a market for wholesale local access provided at a fixed location (now market 1) and wholesale dedicated capacity (now market 2). The recommendation became effective on December 21, 2020. It has also adopted measures aimed at promoting the development of broadband, through the adoption of: (i) recommendations in 2010 and 2013 promoting greater harmonization and effectiveness of corrective measures for NRAs (national regulatory authorities) concerning operators with significant market power with access to NGNs (new generation networks); (ii) a European Directive to facilitate the roll-out of networks, and (iii) a new commission decision on the spectrum of the following frequencies: 790-862 MHz, 880-915 MHz, 925-960 MHz, 1,710-1,785 MHz, 1,805-1,880 MHz, 1,900 -1,980 MHz, 2,010 – 2,025 MHz, 2,110– 2,170 MHz, 2.5 -2.69 GHz, and 3.4-3.8 GHz. On July 1, 2012 Regulation (EU) No. 531/2012 on public communications networks in the EU entered into force, with the ultimate aim of removing the differences between international roaming tariffs (the “Regulation 531/2012”) by establishing an internal market for communication services. This regulation makes it possible for: - mobile operators to use the networks of other operators in Member States at regulated wholesale prices; and - clients to use voice, SMS and data services from an alternative service provider without changing their telephone, telephone number or SIM card. The application of regulation 531/2012 started on July 1, 2014. On June 30, 2015, the Commission announced that it had reached a commitment with the European Parliament and the Council to eliminate excess costs for users starting on June 15, 2017 (“RLAH”—roam like at home) and establish the principle of net neutrality on April 30, 2016. In November 2015, Regulation 2015/2120 entered into force, which establishes the measures to safeguard open internet access and among other regulations, modifies Regulation 531/2012 regarding roaming. The principle of net neutrality must ensure that all traffic that circulates through networks receives the same treatment, irrespective of its content, source or destination. Therefore, it prohibits commercial practices that ----- consist of blocking traffic, slowing down speed and discriminating against services. The BEREC guidelines were published on August 30, 2016, detailing the terms of the European Regulation in order to ensure universal internet access with a minimum quality, known as the “best effort.” The 2015/2120 European Regulation foresaw the removal of roaming surcharges from June 2017 and established a maximum price calendar applicable until April 2016 and for the period from April 2016 to June 2017. It also introduced specific restrictions to ensure fair use of the roaming service by users to prevent abuses of such permanent roaming. On December 15, 2016, the European Commission approved the Regulation that details the fair use policy and the methodology to ensure the sustainability of the removal of the roaming surcharge for roaming providers. The BEREC Guidelines concerning the retail roaming market were published on March 27, 2017, updating the 2016 guidelines to include and specify all the provisions introduced by the 2015 Regulations and the European Commission’s 2016 Implementing Regulations. In May 2017, Regulations were approved changing the 2012 roaming Regulations regarding wholesale roaming markets. In February 2021, the European Commission proposed a new Regulation governing roaming, which seeks to extend the RLAH rules and inter alia improve service levels when roaming. The new Regulation is still subject to the European Union legislative process and may therefore be modified before entering into force. For example, a European Parliament Committee has voted to reduce wholesale roaming fees charged between operators. Until a final Regulation enters into force, the exact implications will remain uncertain. In 2013, the EU announced its cyber security strategy, which included a series of measures, among them a newly proposed Directive on network and information systems security. This regulatory proposal would guarantee a reliable information society throughout the EU, where internet providers are also subject to security requirements. This Directive ((EU) no. – 2016/1148)) was definitively adopted in August 2016. In January 2012, the European Commission announced the proposed replacement for Data Protection Directive 95/46/CE with the new General Data Protection Regulation, which is applicable to providers that process personal data in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not. The Regulation was published on May 4, 2016 and became application from May 25, 2018. One of the ten strategic priorities of the European Commission for coming years is the strategy of a digital single market adopted on May 6, 2015 and which approved several initiatives organized into three pillars were approved: (i) better access for consumers and businesses to digital goods and services across Europe; (ii) maximizing the growth potential of the digital economy, and (iii) creating the right conditions and a level playing field for digital networks and innovative services to flourish. This pillar provided for the review of the new telecommunications regulatory framework. Said review led to Directive (EU) No. 2018/1972 of the European Parliament and the Council of December 11, 2018 that established the European Electronic Communications Code. This is a harmonized framework to regulate electronic communication networks, electronic communication services, associated resources and services and some aspects of terminal equipment. The objective of the aforementioned code is to promote competition, encourage investment and strengthen the internal market and consumer rights. In 2016, the Commission also presented an action plan for the roll-out of 5G which provided a common calendar in the EU for its coordinated commercial commissioning in 2020, as well as cooperation between Member States and interested parties in the sector to determine and allocate spectrum bands to 5G, organize 5G pan-European trials starting in 2018, promote worldwide common 5G regulations and encourage the adoption of national plans for the roll-out of 5G in all Member States.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Competition Regulation
Subsubsection Text: EU competition legislation applies to all its Member States. In particular, Article 101 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (the “TFEU”) prohibits all agreements between companies, decisions by associations of undertakings and concerted practices, which may affect trade between Member States and which have as their object or effect the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition within the European Union. Article 102 of the TFEU prohibits the abuse by one or more companies of a dominant position within the internal market or a substantial part of it. Article 107 of the TFEU prohibits all aid provided by a Member State or through state resources that falsifies or ----- threatens to falsify competition, by favoring specific companies or the production of specific products that affect trade between Member States. Finally, EU Regulations on merger control demand that all mergers and acquisitions that exceed specific turnover thresholds are notified to the European Commission for their review, and not to the national competition authorities. The regulations prohibit mergers if they affect real competition within the internal market or a substantial part of it, particularly as a consequence of the creation of strengthening of a dominant position in the market. Both the European Commission and the national competition authorities and courts have to apply European legislation on competition (although only the European Commission has the authority to apply the law relating to state aid). In addition, there are similar competition regulations in the national legislation of each state, and national and regional competition authorities and courts have the authority to oversee compliance with these regulations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: National regulatory authorities in The Netherlands
Subsubsection Text: _Overview_ The video distribution, broadband internet, fixed-line telephony and mobile businesses are regulated at the EU level. In The Netherlands, these regulations are implemented through the Telecommunicatiewet (the Dutch Telecommunications Act, “DTA”), the Mediawet (the Dutch Media Act, “DMA”), the Wet beveiliging _network en informatiesystemen (the Network and Information Systems Security Act, “NNIS”) and related_ legislation and regulations. The ACM in which the former Independent Post and Telecommunications Authority (“OPTA,” _Onafhankelijke Post en Telecommunicatie Autoriteit) as well as the former Dutch Competition Authority (“NMa,” _Nederlandse Mededingings autoriteit) have been integrated, and the Dutch Radiocommunications Agency (“AT,” _Agentschap Telecom) supervise and enforce compliance with certain parts of the DTA. Pursuant to the DTA, the ACM is designated as a National Regulatory Authority (NRA). The Dutch Media Authority (“CvdM,” Commissariaat voor de Media) is authorized to enforce compliance with the DMA. The AT is authorized to enforce the NISS with regard to network and information system providers and any mandatory notifications of cybersecurity incidents have to be made to The Netherlands National Cyber Security Center (“NCSC,” _Nationaal Cyber Security Centrum). The Privacy Authority (“AP”) (Autoriteit _Persoonsgegevens) supervises and enforces compliance with privacy legislation._ In addition to complying with industry specific regimes, we must comply with both specific and general legislation concerning, among other areas, competition, data protection, data retention, cyber security, internet service provider liability, consumer protection, and e-commerce. The DTA comprises a wide variety of rights and obligations relevant to the provision of public electronic communications networks and services. Certain key provisions included in the DTA are described below, but this description is not intended to be a comprehensive description of all regulations in this area. _Licensing_ The DTA contains a system of general authorizations and provides a possibility to charge supervision costs, generally based on a percentage of the generated revenues or in case of certain specific activities a fixed fee applied for the activity conducted by ACM. A provider of a public electronic communications network or service needs to notify the ACM of its network or service, who will register the notification. The purpose of the notification is to increase transparency and to ensure effective regulation and does not constitute a formal condition for market entry. With regard to scarce resources such as telephone numbers and frequencies, a system of (individual) licensing or allocation by the ACM applies. The ACM, on request, administers telephone number allocation in line with the national phone number plan. The Ministry of Economic Affairs, including through AT, administers the frequency spectrum (including auction processes and supervision) and grants licenses with regard to the use of frequencies. Licenses for frequencies are issued upon application, either on a first-come-first-serve basis, beauty contest or auction. A frequency license confers the right to use a specific set of frequencies in a specific band for a specific period of time and under specific conditions, such as coverage obligations. Frequency licenses are transferable with permission from the Minister of Economic Affairs. In addition to one-off license fees, holders of licenses have to pay annual supervision costs, based on the amount of spectrum held. We hold licenses in the 700, 800, 900, 1,400, 1,800, 2,100, and 2,600 MHz bands to provide 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G communications in The Netherlands. In 2020, we acquired new licenses in the 700 MHz, 1,400 MHz band and ----- were able to re-acquire licenses in the 2,100 MHz bands, all for a period of 20 years. The other licenses will expire in 2030. The Dutch Government is planning to auction 300 MHz in the 3.5 GHz band, which due to delays is presently expected to occur in the second half of 2022, but could be delayed even further. As of December 31, 2020, we hold approximately 38% of the total mobile spectrum licenses in The Netherlands, which are used to deliver mobile services. _Access, Interoperability and Interconnection_ All providers of public electronic communications networks or services who control access to endusers are obliged to enter into good-faith negotiations upon the request of a competitor to conclude an interoperability agreement. Interoperability refers to all measures, including network interconnection, which should be implemented to ensure end-to-end connections. Although there is no obligation to reach any specific outcome, if a provider does not comply with its obligation to enter into good-faith negotiations, the ACM, at the other party’s request, can impose proportionate obligations on the provider in order to ensure end-to-end connectivity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Financial Services Regulation
Subsubsection Text: We provide consumer credit to customers for payment installments for mobile devices when obtaining a post-paid subscription. Our entity providing these services, T-Mobile Netherlands Finance B.V. is subject to the Dutch Financial Supervision Act (Wet op het financieel toezicht).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Significant Market Power
Subsubsection Text: To ensure that the telecommunications markets become genuinely competitive, the ACM can, in the event of a possibility of consumer harm at retail level, impose ex ante regulation at wholesale level by means of market analysis decisions on operators or service providers that have significant market power in a relevant market. Ex ante regulation means that the ACM sets behavioral rules beforehand with which providers who the ACM determines have significant market power must comply. A company will be deemed to have significant market power if, either individually or jointly with others, it enjoys a market position equivalent to dominance, _i.e., a position of economic strength affording it the power to behave to an appreciable extent independently of_ competitors, customers, and ultimately consumers. Before it can be established whether an operator or service provider has significant market power, the ACM needs to determine, in accordance with the principles of general European competition law, in which relevant electronic communications market(s) the operator or service provider competes. The ACM must do this while taking into account the European Commission’s “Recommendation on relevant product and service markets within the electronic communications sector,” the latest version of which was published by the European Commission on December 21, 2020. The ACM may also define additional relevant markets provided that any such market meets the cumulative criteria defined by the European Commission in its so called threecriteria test for determining whether a market is susceptible to ex ante regulation. If the ACM determines that a company has significant market power, the ACM must, subject to appropriateness and proportionality principles, impose one or more obligations. These obligations relate to, among other things, access and use of specific network facilities, non-discrimination, transparency, and price regulation at both the wholesale and retail level, though the framework seeks for obligations to be imposed as much as possible at an upstream (wholesale) level. To ensure a proper functioning of the market, these obligations may not be disproportionate. The investigation of a relevant market, the designation of parties with significant market power and the imposition of _ex ante obligations culminate in so-called market analysis decisions of the ACM. These decisions normally apply for a period of three years, after which the market concerned needs to be re-investigated. Under the EECC this term is extended to five years. The ACM has completed various rounds of market analyses. The Company was designated as a party with significant market power for both the fixed terminating and mobile terminating access markets. The analysis in respect of these markets are discussed below. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: ACM Call Termination Market Analysis Decisions
Subsubsection Text: In respect of the call termination market, the ACM has taken the view that all providers of call termination on fixed-line and mobile networks in The Netherlands have significant market power because all such providers exclusively control access to end-users connected to their respective public telephone networks. As a result, Former Ziggo (in relation to fixed call termination services) and Vodafone NL (in relation to both fixed and mobile call termination services), have been subject to specific _ex ante obligations, including in particular tariff regulation (maximum termination charges), since the ACM’s third market analysis decision of July 7, 2010. On August 5, 2013, the ACM published its fourth market analysis decision on call termination, which combined both the fixed termination market and the mobile termination market. The new tariffs became effective September 1, 2013, and applied for a three-year period that ended September 1, 2016. The decision was appealed by various operators, including us, and on August 27, 2013, the Dutch Supreme Administrative Court decided in a preliminary decision that the price cap on mobile termination charges should be higher than the ACM had initially determined. The court ruled that the ACM should apply a so-called Bottom-up Long Run Incremental Cost (“BULRIC”) plus cost calculation method (taking into account common overhead costs relating also to other services than mobile call termination, (“BULRIC plus”)) rather than a pure BULRIC method (in which such common overhead costs are to be disregarded, “pure BULRIC”). These revised tariffs applied until the Dutch Supreme Administrative Court arrived at a final decision in the appeal proceedings on the merits (see below). Because the pure BULRIC method used by the ACM is in fact a method recommended by the European Commission in its 2009 Recommendation on the Regulatory Treatment of Termination Rates, the Supreme Administrative Court posed prejudicial questions to the European Court of Justice. After an Advocate General opinion, the European Court of Justice ruled on September 15, 2016, that deviation from the European Commission’s 2009 Recommendation on Termination Rates is only possible if justified by national circumstances. The ACM started a new (the fifth) market analysis and published a draft decision on November 18, 2016, in which they again regulate using a pure BULRIC calculation. The hearing at the Dutch Supreme Administrative Court was held on January 11, 2017, and ruling given on July 10, 2017, upheld the ACM’s use of pure BULRIC, though not requesting retroactive adjustment. In April 2017, the ACM provided their plan to impose tariff ceilings of €0.00139 per minute for fixed and €0.005819 per minute for mobile calls from July 1, 2017, to the European Commission. The European Commission approved these in May, 2017. The new tariff implementation was delayed by the court decision, until July 12, 2017. VFZ appealed ACM’s market decision. In September 2018, the appeal court delivered its decision on VFZ’s appeal against the ACM’s Mobile Termination/Fixed-line Termination Rate (“MTR” and “FTR”) regulations market decision. The verdict provides the relevant guidance sought by VFZ about the interpretation and setting of interconnection tariffs among operators. Further to the entry into force of the EECC, the European Commission has adopted a delegated act on December 18, 2020, that will set maximum, EU-wide voice termination rates, both fixed and mobile. These rates will be applicable to any operator providing voice call termination services in the EU. Approval of the delegated act by the European Council and the European Parliament is expected in the course of 2021 and then, after two months, the new rates will apply. The delegated act includes a transition period for the fixed rate that ends on December 31, 2021, and a glide path for the mobile rates that ends on December 31, 2023. On July 21, 2020, ACM has extended the applicability of the rates that the delegated act did not regulate until the new European rates apply.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: ACM Wholesale Fixed Access Decision
Subsubsection Text: On February 27, 2018, the ACM published a draft decision of its analysis of the LLU market, concluding that there is a single market for local and central access. ACM referred to this market as the Wholesale Fixed Access (WFA) market and concluded for the first time that KPN and VFZ had joint Significant Market Power. As a result, ACM imposed an obligation on VFZ to offer wholesale cable access and continued wholesale access regulation of KPN. Following a market consultation, ACM submitted the draft decision to the European Commission. After comments by the European Commission, ACM published the final decision on September 28, 2018, which became effective on October 1, 2018. VFZ published a draft Reference Offer on December 31, 2018, and published tariffs on March 31, 2019. In parallel, KPN and VFZ appealed ACM’s decision before the national court seeking annulment, while T-Mobile and Tele2 appealed with the intent to ----- secure more stringent regulation. VFZ also initiated an action before the European General Court related to the European Commission’s response to the consultation. The national appeal turned out successful: on March 17, 2020, the Court annulled ACM’s decision. With Court’s verdict being final, VFZ is no longer obligated to offer cable access and has since withdrawn its reference offer. Also, KPN is no longer obligated to offer regulated access. On July 9, 2021, the ACM indicated in a press release that it is again investigating fixed access, because KPN’s access conditions may make it more difficult for competitors to compete, which may in the future lead to higher prices for consumers and companies, and lower uptake of high-speed internet. In its press release the ACM indicated that it intends to publish a new draft market analysis decision in the fall of 2021, which has not yet been done.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Symmetrical access
Subsubsection Text: The DTA is undergoing revision to fully implement the European Electronic Communications Code and has already been revised to contain provisions enabling the ACM to impose obligations inter alia to grant access to infrastructure within buildings or up to the first concentration or distribution point of the network. For this to occur it is necessary that replication is economically inefficient or physically impracticable. Moreover, should this kind of access be insufficient to overcome high and non-transitory barriers to replication within the context of a market situation significantly limiting competitive outcomes for end users, the ACM will be able to impose obligations beyond the first concentration or distribution point of the network. The ACM has not yet made use of these new powers, and it remains to be seen if and how exactly they will be applied, however it is likely that the ACM in doing so will take into account BEREC’s December 2020 Guidelines on the Criteria for a Consistent Application of Article 61 (3) EECC. Nevertheless, they could become an alternative or addition to its powers under the significant market power regime described below. A key difference is that for these symmetrical access provisions to be applied, the ACM will not need to demonstrate the existence of such significant market power (but rather replicability issues and, for access beyond the first concentration or distribution point, a market situation significantly limiting competition outcomes for consumers). We have requested the ACM to make use of its new powers and impose symmetrical access ACM is currently prioritizing its market analysis decision process to impose access regulation on the basis of market dominance. The timing of a decision based on the new powers granted to ACM under the symmetric access regulation is therefore unclear.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Network and services security and continuity
Subsubsection Text: As a provider of public electronic communication networks and services, we are subject to specific obligations to safeguard the security and integrity of our networks and services, and to ensure the continuity of electronic communications services in the event of disturbances or outages of the electricity grid. We are required to notify the AT in case of disturbances, which materially threaten the continuity of our networks and services, and the National Cyber Security Center (“NCSC”) in case of security and integrity breaches caused by cyberattacks, which could lead to disturbance of the continuity. To mitigate the risks to continuity of mobile services, T-Mobile, Vodafone NL, and KPN voluntarily entered into national roaming arrangements in 2014, allowing for their respective subscribers to roam (voice and SMS) on the other parties’ networks in the event of local outages of mobile networks where the outage is foreseen to last for more than three days and affect over 500,000 customers. Acquisitions of control in telecommunications companies (such as ourselves, or companies we may wish to acquire) may be subject to a notification requirement and investigation from the perspective whether the acquisition poses a threat to the public interest, with the worst possible outcome being a prohibition of the acquisition. In October 2021, additional rules (Regeling veiligheid en integriteit telecommunicatie) were published aiming to protect critical network elements, adjacent elements, security elements and control environments. The rules include specifications for implementation, and are categorized as follows: (i) safe configuration of technical equipment, (ii) safe configuration of networks, (iii) guarding of technical infrastructure, (iv) security assurance for software and control services, and (v) human resource security. We will have to comply with these rules ultimately by October 1, 2022. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: End-user Protection
Subsubsection Text: As a provider of public electronic communication networks and services, we are subject to specific regulations aiming to protect end-users, including regulations concerning information obligations toward consumers, the enactment of amendments to end-user contracts, the term of end user contracts, termination rights of consumers, quality reporting, access to emergency numbers and subscriber information, and compensation of subscriber fees in the event of outages. Access to emergency numbers has to be provided without limitation and free of charge. Access to subscriber information includes the provision of access to the names, addresses and telephone numbers of our subscribers who have consented to be included in directory enquiry services.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Data Protection
Subsubsection Text: For providers of public electronic communications networks or services and further to the GDPR and the ePrivacy Directive, a strict data protection regime applies in The Netherlands. On May 25, 2018, the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which replaced the European Data Protection Directive, came into force. The GDPR has direct effect in The Netherlands with additional data protection obligations relevant to our operations that include: (i) clear explanation and transparency of personal data usage to customers and employees, and maintaining an internal data processing register, (ii) affirmative consent from users for profiling by automated means, (iii) stronger privacy rights for users and (iv) application of privacy by design/default to data processes. In addition to the general data protection framework of the GDPR, the DTA sets out specific regulations for providers of public electronic communications networks and services. These regulations include an obligation to offer certain technical facilities, such as specification of invoices, telephone number identification and transfer of calls, rules regarding the use and processing of location data and traffic data (i.e., call detail records), an obligation to provide access to subscriber lists for directory services, obligations to implement security measures to protect personal data and rules regarding unsolicited commercial communications (“spam”). The DTA also obliges providers of public electronic communications networks to notify the AT in case of a security breach or major outage. If this includes the leakage of personal data processed by the provider, the AP needs to be informed as well. On January 10, 2017, a draft ePrivacy Regulation (“ePR”) was proposed by the European Commission to replace the ePrivacy Directive. On February 10, 2021, the Council reached an agreement on their position on the ePR and negotiations are ongoing. It is unclear when the ePR will be agreed on by all Member States and enter into force.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Lawful Interception
Subsubsection Text: Providers of public telecommunication networks and services can only make their networks and services available to the public if they have arranged their networks and services in such a manner that they can be lawfully intercepted promptly. Providers of public telecommunication networks and services are obligated to cooperate fully in the execution of a lawfully given special tapping order or permission, in accordance with the technical and procedural requirements set forth on the basis of the DTA, and to provide relevant Dutch law enforcement agencies information on subscribers and telecommunications traffic.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Net Neutrality
Subsubsection Text: On January 1, 2013, certain provisions in the DTA with respect to net neutrality entered into force. These provisions regulate net neutrality by, among other things, prohibiting operators of public telecommunication networks through which internet access is provided as well as internet service providers from blocking or restricting services or applications which are accessed via the internet other than in circumstances set forth in the DTA. In October 2015, the European Parliament adopted a new Regulation including the first EU-wide net neutrality regime. Following a lengthy legislative procedure, the regulation (directly applicable in all Member States from April 30, 2016) reflects a light-handed approach to net neutrality permitting the provision of specialized services optimized for specific content and approving reasonable traffic management. In October 2016, a bill to change the DTA pursuant to the EU net neutrality Regulation was adopted by the Dutch Senate. In the law, a specific obligation prohibiting tariff differentiation for data was maintained, which however did not follow from the Regulation. The Court in Rotterdam ruled on April 20, ----- 2017, that the Dutch ban on zero rating for data is not valid as the EU net neutrality Regulation does not allow further national regulation on this issue. Also the net neutrality regulation did not contain a prohibition of any form of zero-rating. Therefore, the Dutch law was conflicting with the EU net neutrality regulation and had to be set aside. As a result, the DTA was amended to properly reflect the EU regulation. The special interest group Bits of Freedom has brought a series of legal challenges aimed at prohibiting zero rating, all of which were unsuccessful. BEREC is currently reviewing zero rating as a result of a decision of the European Court of Justice from September 2, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Radio and Television Transmission
Subsubsection Text: The distribution of must-carry television services to the public is regulated by the DMA, entailing obligations regarding the transmission of specified radio and television broadcast channels. On January 1, 2014, the revised must-carry obligations became effective. The revised must carry obligations do not only apply to cable operators, as was previously the case, but also apply to all providers of analogue and digital program packages based on the principle of technology neutrality. Providers of digital program packages with 100,000 or more subscribers are subject to the obligation to provide at least 30 television channels, including six public television broadcasting channels as a must carry obligation, a limited amount of regional and local television broadcasting channels and a number of digital radio broadcasting channels. In addition, all providers of analogue program packages with 100,000 or more subscribers must include at least 15 television channels, including five public broadcasting channels as a must carry obligation, a limited amount of regional and local television broadcasting channels and some analogue radio broadcasting channels. The DMA can grant a (conditional) exemption from the obligation if the must carry obligations listed above give rise to disproportionate costs for the network operator, an impediment to innovation or other unreasonable outcomes. There is no regulated financing mechanism in place between network operators and broadcasters. Commercial and public program providers must negotiate with network operators regarding transmission fees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Property Rules regarding the Network
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with the Dutch Civil Code, all public fixed-line electronic communication networks are the legal property of the rightful constructer of the network or its legal successor, and not (by accession) of the owner of the ground in which the network resides. Registration at the Land Registry (het Kadaster) is required for the transfer of legal ownership and/or to encumber public networks, for example by a right of mortgage. Registration is also required to enjoy statutory protection against title claims of third parties. We have currently registered a substantial majority of our network at the Land Registry.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Roaming
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the European Roaming Regulation, which has direct effect in The Netherlands, as of June 15, 2017, roaming retail surcharges are no longer permitted, subject to a fair use policy. On June 15, 2017, revised maximum wholesale roaming rates (exclusive of VAT) became effective as follows (i) outgoing calls at €0.032 per minute, (ii) incoming calls at €0.0114 per minute, (iii) €0.01 per SMS sent, and (iv) rates for data at €7.7 per GB decreasing annually ultimately to €2.5 per GB effective January 1, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: International calls
Subsubsection Text: New rules regarding intra EU communications impose regulated maximum retail prices charged to consumers of €0.19 per minute for calls and €0.06 per SMS messages (exclusive of VAT). The rates apply to fixed and mobile communications, effective from May 15, 2019 for a period of five years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Regulatory framework—Regulation of electronic communication services
Subsubsection Title: Consumer Credit
Subsubsection Text: In June 2014, and February 2016, the Dutch (Civil) Supreme Court ruled that certain combined propositions of mobile services and a mobile handset could, under circumstances, be qualified as, inter alia, consumer credit and installment sales, which qualification could have consequences on the validity of certain customer contracts and the applicability of financial laws including the supervision of the Autoriteit Financiële _Markten (the Dutch financial market supervisory body, “AFM”). The Company was not party to the above-_ ----- mentioned proceedings. Since January 1, 2017 mobile operators are subject to the Financial Supervision Act (“WFT” Wet Financieel Toezicht) and are required to have a license for the AFM to provide consumer credit services when allowing customers purchasing a mobile device to pay in installments for such device. TMNL was granted a consumer credit license by the end of 2016 and is subject to the supervision of the AFM. In February 2021, the Dutch Minister of Finance sent a letter to the Dutch Parliament reflecting an intention to revise consumer credit regulation in The Netherlands by lowering the threshold for document verification required to obtain a loan for a mobile device. The proposal is to lower the threshold from €1,000 to €250. So far, no legislative proposal has been submitted to the Dutch Parliament to execute this intention and also no decision is taken if such proposal will be submitted. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis provide information that we believe is relevant to an assessment and understanding of our financial condition and results of operations for the periods under review and should be read together with our Historical Consolidated Financial Statements. This discussion contains forward- looking statements that are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated in forward-looking statements for many reasons. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a discussion of important factors to be evaluated in connection with an investment in the Notes. The following discussion and analysis presents the historical consolidated financial information of the Target Group as of and for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019, 2020 and the nine months ended September 30, 2020 and 2021. Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, references to “IFRS” herein are to International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union._

Subsubsection Title: Board of Directors—Senior Secured Notes Issuer
Subsubsection Text: The following table sets forth certain information regarding the members of the board of directors of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as of the date of the Offering Memorandum:

The Target is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte _aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of The Netherlands. The Target has its registered office at_ Waldorpstraat 60, 2521 CC The Hague, The Netherlands, and is registered under the Dutch Trade Register number 33301092. Currently, the Target applies the mitigated large company regime (gemitigeerd or _verzwakt _structuurregime) and therefore has a two-tier governance model in place with a separate supervisory board_ (raad van commissarissen) and management board (bestuur). The supervisory board is responsible for supervising the policy pursued by, and also advises, the management board. The management board in turn forms the management of the Target Group and is responsible for the strategy of the Target Group. Following the completion of the Transaction, we expect to migrate to a full large company regime (structuurregime), the two-tier board will remain in place, with the management board being appointed by the supervisory board, as a result of the Target applying the large company regime.

Subsubsection Title: Senior Management
Subsubsection Text: The Target Group’s management team is composed of industry professionals and has unique and extensive experience in both the mobile and fixed line telecommunications sectors in Europe, including significant experience developed within our organization itself. We believe that our senior management team is well prepared and has the relevant experience and track-record required to successfully implement our strategy. The day-to-day business of the Target Group is run by the management board along with three other executives who together comprise the Executive Committee, as listed below. The business address for each of these members of the Executive Committee is Waldorpstraat 60, 2521 CC Den Haag, The Netherlands. The following table sets forth certain information regarding the member of the senior management of TMNL, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Following the completion of the Acquisition, these members of the senior management are expected to remain with TMNL:

Subsubsection Title: Petrus Adrianus Johannes de Klein is the Target Group’s Chief Strategy Officer. De Klein has had
Subsubsection Text: over ten years’ experience in integration, strategic consulting and marketing work with T-Mobile Netherlands, having been responsible for the integration of Tele2 and of Vodafone’s fixed line business, Vodafone Thuis, into T-Mobile Netherlands. Previously, de Klein served as a director at Ben in The Netherlands and as head of mobile internet at T-Mobile (UK) Limited (from 2010 known as EE Limited). He holds a M.Sc. in Business Management from Eindhoven University of Technology, The Netherlands.

Subsubsection Title: Margreet Hoekstra is the Target Group’s Chief Legal Officer. She has over 19 years’ experience at
Subsubsection Text: T-Mobile Netherlands, having served there in several different roles, including as Compliance Officer, Manager of Regulatory Affairs & Compliance and as Senior Legal Counsel. She has also served for almost 6 years as a Legal Consultant at Doornheim de Vries Telecommunications Consultancy, later renamed to Logica Consulting. Hoekstra holds a bachelor’s degree in Law from Utrecht University, The Netherlands.

Subsubsection Title: Saskia Adriana Petrus Bekkers-Verbraak is the Target Group’s Chief Human Resources Officer.
Subsubsection Text: Bekkers came to T-Mobile Netherlands from Tele2 Nederland, where she was the Director of Human Resources for over two years prior to its acquisition by T-Mobile. Prior to her work with Tele2, she served for over ten years in various human resources roles at Wolters Kluwer in The Netherlands, including as Human Resources Director of Corporate, Global Shared Services, where she was responsible for all people-based activity within the organization from both operational and strategic perspectives. She holds a bachelor’s degree in Organizational Psychology from Utrecht University, The Netherlands.
