Subsection Title: FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS MEASURED AT FAIR VALUE 31 December 2019** **31 December 2018 Fair** **Book Level** **Value** **Value** **Level** **Level 3** **Total

Subsubsection Text: When determining the fair value, it is important to maximize the use of current inputs observable in liquid markets for the financial instrument in question and minimize the use of other inputs (e.g. historical prices, prices for similar instruments, prices on illiquid markets). A three-level measurement hierarchy is defined for these purposes. If prices quoted in liquid markets are available at the reporting date for the respective financial instrument, these will be used unadjusted for the measurement (Level 1 measurement). Other input parameters are then irrelevant for the measurement. If quoted prices on liquid markets are not available at the reporting date for the respective financial instrument, but the instrument can be measured using other inputs that are observable on the market at the reporting date, a Level 2 measurement will be applied. The conditions for this are that no major adjustments have been made to the observable inputs and no unobservable inputs are used. If the conditions for a Level 1 or Level 2 measurement are not met, a Level 3 measurement is applied. In such cases, major adjustments must be made to the observable inputs or unobservable inputs must be used. When determining the fair value, it is important to maximize the use of current inputs observable in liquid markets for the financial instrument in question and minimize the use of other inputs (e.g., historical prices, prices for similar instruments, prices on illiquid markets). A three-level measurement hierarchy is defined for these purposes. If prices quoted in liquid markets are available at the reporting date for the respective financial instrument, these will be used unadjusted for the measurement (Level 1 measurement). Other input parameters are then irrelevant for the measurement. If quoted prices on liquid markets are not available at the reporting date for the respective financial instrument, but the instrument can be measured using other inputs that are observable on the market at the reporting date, a Level 2 measurement will be applied. The conditions for this are that no major adjustments have been made to the observable inputs and no unobservable inputs are used. F-156 ----- If the conditions for a Level 1 or Level 2 measurement are not met, a Level 3 measurement is applied. In such cases, major adjustments must be made to the observable inputs or unobservable inputs must be used.

Subsection Title: (a) Factoring transactions with substantially all risks and rewards being transferred with the involvement of structured entities.
Subsubsection Text: A factoring agreement is in place with a maximum program volume of EUR 95 million. If the buyer agrees to purchase receivables beyond this amount, the purchase price payment shall be deferred until the maximum program volume decreases again by the corresponding amount. With this structure, there is no structured entity consolidated by T-Mobile. Rather, the receivables are sold directly to a structured entity that is not consolidated by T-Mobile due to the lack of ability to direct the entity’s relevant activities. This structured entity holds the receivables and allocates the risks and rewards resulting from these to T-Mobile and a bank on the basis of contractual arrangements. The structured entity is financed through the issue of commercial paper to third parties outside T-Mobile or, alternatively, through a credit facility provided by a bank. The structured entity has the freedom to decide whether and which receivables will be purchased, though purchase of the agreed minimum volume is imperative. T-Mobile is obligated to buy back aged receivables and receivables for which a write-down is imminent at nominal value. The cash flows resulting from the buybacks would occur in the month following the buyback. Such buybacks of receivables would not affect the allocation of the credit risk-related losses in any way, as the latter would be passed back to the buyers in line with the agreed risk allocation. The nominal volume of the receivables sold by T-Mobile and not yet settled by the debtors was EUR 69.7 million (2019: EUR 72,1) as of the reporting date. The structured entity has no other business activities than the purchase or sale of trade receivables or other investments. The risks relevant for the risk assessment with respect to the sold receivables are based on the credit risk and the risk of late payments (late-payment risk). As of reporting date the credit risk represents substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the receivables and is transferred in full to the buyer. The maximum credit risk to be borne by T-Mobile in a worst-case scenario amounts to EUR 3.5 million (2019: EUR 4.0 million) as of the reporting date. The other credit risk-related losses would be borne by the buyer. The late-payment risk continues to be borne in full by T-Mobile. The maximum exposure to loss for T-Mobile resulting from credit risk and late-payment risk relating to the receivables sold at the reporting date is EUR 3.5 million (2019: EUR 4.0 million). According to the risk assessment substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the receivables were transferred to the buyer as of reporting date. The expected loss resulting from the late-payment risk recognized under financial liabilities represents T-Mobile’s entire continuing involvement; the carrying amount and fair value each amounted to less than EUR 100 thousand. In 2019 the agreement was reported as a factoring transaction involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards, according to the then risk assessment, with control remaining at T-Mobile. The accounting treatment changed in 2020 due to an increase of credit risk transferred. T-Mobile continues to perform servicing for the receivables sold. Under the factoring agreement the buyer (structured entity) has the right to transfer the servicing to third parties for no specific reason. Although T-Mobile is not authorized to use the receivables sold other than in its capacity as servicer, it retains control over the receivables sold because the buyers and the structured entities do not have the practical ability to resell the purchased receivables. At the time the receivables are sold, the fair value of the expected losses is expensed. In the transaction with a structured entity, certain portions of the F-82 ----- purchase price are initially held back and, depending on the amount of the actual defaults, are only paid to T-Mobile at a later date. To the extent that such portions of the purchase price are expected to be received in the future, they are recognized at fair value. T-Mobile presents the purchase price payments received from the buyers under cash generated from operations where these relate to the derecognized portion of the receivables, and under net cash from/used in financing activities where they relate to the portion of the receivables that is still recognized. The volume of receivables sold was not subject to major fluctuations since the beginning of the respective transaction. In 2020 T-Mobile expensed EUR 0.7 million, including credit-risk discounts to cover monthly credit risks and including program fees (interest and bank margin), and has expensed a total amount of EUR 6.5 million since the beginning of the transaction.

Subsection Title: (b) Factoring transactions involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile without the involvement of structured entities.
Subsubsection Text: A factoring transaction is in place under which a bank is required to purchase trade receivables. The receivables sold entail charges from sales of handsets payable over a period of up to two years. The factoring agreement has a maximum funding amount of EUR 90 million. The purchase price will be paid out immediately upon sale. On 5 December 2019, the term of this factoring transaction has been extended for another two (2) years to 30 June 2021. In 2019 the transaction was reported as a factoring agreement involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control transferred to the buyers resulting in a full derecognition of receivables sold. In a regular review process of the derecognition requirements in 2020 T-Mobile assessed that bank does not have the practical ability to resell the receivables anymore and consequently T-Mobile remains control over the receivables. The risks relevant for the risk assessment with respect to the receivables sold are the credit risk and the risk of late payments (late-payment risk). The purchase price corresponds to the nominal amount. The maximum credit risk from the various tranches to be borne by T-Mobile amounts to EUR 14.3 million as of the reporting date (2019: EUR 14.4 million). The other credit risk-related losses are borne by the buyer. The late-payment risk continues to be borne in full by T-Mobile. Substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the receivables were neither transferred nor retained (allocation of the material risks and rewards between T-Mobile and the buyers) as of reporting date. T-Mobile continues to perform servicing for the receivables sold. Although T-Mobile is not authorized to use the receivables sold other than in its capacity as servicer, it retains control over the receivables sold because the buyer does not have the practical ability to resell the purchased receivables. At the time the receivables are sold, the fair value of the expected losses is expensed. Expected future payments are presented as a component of the associated liability. T-Mobile continues to recognize the trade receivables sold to the extent of its continuing involvement, i.e. in the maximum amount with which it is still liable for the credit risk and late-payment risk inherent in the receivables sold, and recognizes a corresponding associated liability presented in liabilities to banks. The receivables and the associated liability are then derecognized in the extent to which T-Mobile’s continuing involvement is reduced (particularly when payment is made by the customer). The carrying amount of the receivables is subsequently reduced by the extent to which the actual losses to be borne by T-Mobile resulting from the credit risk and the late-payment risk exceed the losses initially expected. This amount is recognized as an expense. T-Mobile’s continuing involvement as of 31 December 2020 amounted to EUR 14.4 million (2019: n/a), and the carrying amount of the associated liability was EUR 14.4 million (2019: n/a). The outstanding amount of receivables as per 31 December 2020 for this particular factoring transaction amounted to EUR 60.7 million (2019: EUR 42.1 million). In 2020 T-Mobile expensed EUR 0.5 million, including credit-risk discounts and loss allocations to cover monthly credit risks, in the financial year from its continuing involvement including program fees (interest and bank margin), and has expensed a total amount of EUR 5.6 million since the beginning of the transaction. T-Mobile presents the purchase price payments received from the buyers under cash generated from operations where these relate to the derecognized portion of the receivables, and under net cash F-83 ----- from/used in financing activities where they relate to the portion of the receivables that is still recognized. The volume of receivables sold was not subject to major fluctuations since the beginning of the respective transaction.

Subsection Title: (c) Factoring transactions involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile with the involvement of structured entities.
Subsubsection Text: The factoring agreement has a maximum program volume of EUR 55 million. If the buyer agrees to purchase receivables beyond this amount, the purchase price payment shall be deferred until the maximum program volume decreases again by the corresponding amount. With this structure, there is no structured entity consolidated by T-Mobile. Rather, the receivables are sold directly to a structured entity that is not consolidated by T-Mobile due to the lack of ability to direct the entity’s relevant activities. This structured entity holds the receivables and allocates the risks and rewards resulting from these to T-Mobile and a bank on the basis of contractual arrangements. The structured entity is financed through the issue of commercial paper to third parties outside T-Mobile or, alternatively, through a credit facility provided by a bank. The receivables are purchased in an automated process based on the purchase criteria set out in the receivables purchase agreement. T-Mobile is obligated to buy back aged receivables and receivables for which a write-down is imminent at nominal value. The cash flows resulting from the buybacks would occur in the month following the buy-back. Such buybacks of receivables would not affect the allocation of the credit risk-related losses in any way, as the latter would be passed back to the buyers in line with the agreed risk allocation. The nominal volume of the receivables sold by T-Mobile and not yet settled by the debtors was EUR 46.0 million (2019: EUR 47.9 million) as of the reporting date. The structured entity has no other business activities than the purchase or sale of trade receivables or other investments. The risks relevant for the risk assessment with respect to the sold receivables are based on the credit risk and the risk of late payments (late-payment risk). The maximum credit risk to be borne by T-Mobile amounts to EUR 2.6 million (2019: EUR 2.7 million) as of the reporting date. The other credit riskrelated losses are borne by the buyers. The late-payment risk continues to be borne in full by T-Mobile. The maximum exposure to loss for T-Mobile resulting from credit risk and late-payment risk relating to the receivables sold at the reporting date is EUR 2.6 million (2019: EUR 2.7 million). Substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the receivables were neither transferred nor retained (allocation of the material risks and rewards between T-Mobile and the buyers). T-Mobile continues to perform servicing for the receivables sold. Under the factoring agreement the buyer (structured entity)has the right to transfer the servicing to third parties for no specific reason. Although T-Mobile is not authorized to use the receivables sold other than in its capacity as servicer, it retains control over the receivables sold because the buyers and the structured entities do not have the practical ability to resell the purchased receivables. At the time the receivables are sold, the fair value of the expected losses is expensed. Expected future payments are presented as a component of the associated liability. In transactions with structured entities, certain portions of the purchase price are initially held back and, depending on the amount of the actual defaults, are only paid to T-Mobile at a later date. To the extent that such portions of the purchase price are expected to be received in the future, they are recognized at fair value. T-Mobile continues to recognize the trade receivables sold to the extent of its continuing involvement, i.e. in the maximum amount with which it is still liable for the credit risk and late-payment risk inherent in the receivables sold, and recognizes a corresponding associated liability presented in liabilities to banks. The receivables and the associated liability are then derecognized in the extent to which T-Mobile’s continuing involvement is reduced (particularly when payment is made by the customer). The carrying amount of the receivables is subsequently reduced by the extent to which the actual losses to be borne by T-Mobile resulting from the credit risk and the late-payment risk exceed the losses initially expected. This amount is recognized as an expense. T-Mobile’s continuing involvement as of 31 December 2020 amounted to EUR 2.6 million (2019: EUR 2.6 million), and the carrying amount of the associated liability was EUR 2.6 million (2019: EUR 2.7 million). T-Mobile presents the purchase price payments received from the buyers under cash F-84 ----- generated from operations where these relate to the derecognized portion of the receivables, and under net cash from/used in financing activities where they relate to the portion of the receivables that is still recognized. The volume of receivables sold was not subject to major fluctuations since the beginning of the respective transaction. In 2020 T-Mobile expensed EUR 0.7 million, including credit-risk discounts and loss allocations to cover monthly credit risks, in the financial year from its continuing involvement including program fees (interest and bank margin), and has expensed a total amount of EUR 7.8 million since the beginning of the transaction. A factoring transaction that was reported in 2019 as involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile with the involvement of structured entities is now reported as a factoring transaction with substantially all risks and rewards being transferred with the involvement of structured entities. The accounting treatment changed in 2020 due to an increase of credit risk transferred.

T-Mobile is party to factoring agreements under which it sells trade receivables on a revolving basis. The receivables are sold on a daily basis or quarterly basis and settled on a monthly basis. The receivables sold entail both telecom charges already due and charges from sales of handsets payable over a period of up to two years. The debtors are consumers as well as business customers. In none of the transactions is T-Mobile exposed to risks other than the credit risk and late-payment risk resulting from the sold receivables agreed in the respective agreement. The terms of the agreements end between 2021 and 2023. The factoring transactions involve (a) the transfer of substantially all risks and rewards with the involvement of structured entities, (b) the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile without the involvement of structured entities and (c) the factoring agreements involve the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile with the involvement of structured entities. T-Mobile is party to factoring agreements under which it sells trade receivables on a revolving basis. The receivables are sold on a daily basis or quarterly basis and settled on a monthly basis. The receivables sold entail both telecom charges already due and charges from sales of handsets payable over a period of up to two years. The debtors are consumers as well as business customers. In none of the transactions is T-Mobile exposed to risks other than the credit risk and late-payment risk resulting from the sold receivables agreed in the respective agreement. The term of the agreements ends between 2020 and 2021. The factoring transactions involve the splitting of significant risks and rewards F-157 ----- with control remaining at T-Mobile without the involvement of structured entities (I) and the factoring agreements involve the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile with the involvement of structured entities (II). (I) Factoring transactions involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile without the involvement of structured entities. A factoring transaction is in place under which banks are required to purchase trade receivables. The receivables sold entail charges from sales of handsets payable over a period of up to two years. The factoring agreement has a maximum funding amount of EUR 90 million. The purchase price will be paid out immediately upon sale. On 5 December 2019 the term of this factoring transaction has been extended for another two (2) years to 30 June 2021. The risks relevant for the risk assessment with respect to the receivables sold are the credit risk and the risk of late payments (late-payment risk). The purchase price corresponds to the nominal amount. The maximum credit risk from the various tranches to be borne by T-Mobile amounts to EUR 14.4 million (2018: EUR 14.6 million). The other credit risk-related losses are borne by the banks. The late-payment risk continues to be borne by T-Mobile. T-Mobile’s continuing involvement as of 31 December 2019 amounted to EUR 14.4 million (2018: EUR 14.6 million), and the carrying amount of the associated liability was EUR 14.4 million (2018: EUR 14.6 million). The outstanding amount of receivables as per 31 December 2018 for this particular factoring transaction amounted to EUR 47.9 million (2018: EUR 78.5 million). In 2019 T-Mobile expensed EUR 0.6 million, including credit-risk discounts and loss allocations to cover monthly credit risks, in the financial year from its continuing involvement including program fees (interest and bank margin), and has expensed a total amount of EUR 5.1 million since the beginning of the transaction. (II) Factoring transactions involving the splitting of significant risks and rewards with control remaining at T-Mobile with the involvement of structured entities. The factoring agreements have a maximum program volume of EUR 150 million. If the buyer agrees to purchase receivables beyond this amount, the purchase price payment shall be deferred until the maximum program volume decreases again by the corresponding amount. With this structure, there is no structured entity consolidated by T-Mobile. Rather, the receivables are sold directly to a structured entity that is not consolidated by T-Mobile due to the lack of ability to direct the entity’s relevant activities. This structured entity holds the receivables and allocates the risks and rewards resulting from these to T-Mobile and a bank on the basis of contractual arrangements. The structured entity is financed through the issue of commercial paper to third parties outside T-Mobile or, alternatively, through a credit facility provided by a bank. In one receivables portfolio, the receivables are purchased in an automated process based on the purchase criteria set out in the receivables purchase agreement. In another receivables portfolio, the structured entity has the freedom to decide whether and which receivables will be purchased, though purchase of the agreed minimum volume is imperative. T-Mobile is obligated to buy back aged receivables and receivables for which a write-down is imminent at nominal value. The cash flows resulting from the buybacks would occur in the month following the buy-back. Such buybacks of receivables would not affect the allocation of the credit risk-related losses in any way, as the latter would be passed back to the buyers in line with the agreed risk allocation. The nominal volume of the receivables sold by T-Mobile and not yet settled by the debtors was EUR 127.8 million (2018: EUR 134 million) as of the reporting date. None of the structured entities has business activities other than the purchase or sale of trade receivables or other investments. The risks relevant for the risk assessment with respect to the sold receivables are based on the credit risk and the risk of late payments (late-payment risk). The maximum credit risk to be borne by T-Mobile amounts to EUR 6.6 million (2018: EUR 7.4 million) as of the reporting date when translated into euros and is largely attributable to transactions involving structured entities. The other credit risk-related losses are borne by the buyers. The late-payment risk continues to be borne in full by T-Mobile. The maximum exposure to loss for T-Mobile resulting from credit risk and late-payment risk relating to the receivables sold at the reporting date is EUR 6.8 million (2018: EUR 7.6 million) and is largely F-158 ----- attributable to transactions involving structured entities. Substantially all the risks and rewards of ownership of the receivables were neither transferred nor retained (allocation of the material risks and rewards between T-Mobile and the buyers). T-Mobile continues to perform servicing for the receivables sold. Under the factoring agreements in which structured entities are engaged, buyers have the right to transfer the servicing to third parties for no specific reason. Although T-Mobile is not authorized to use the receivables sold other than in its capacity as servicer, it retains control over the receivables sold because the buyers and the structured entities do not have the practical ability to resell the purchased receivables. At the time the receivables are sold, the fair value of the expected losses is expensed. Expected future payments are presented as a component of the associated liability. In transactions with structured entities, certain portions of the purchase price are initially held back and, depending on the amount of the actual defaults, are only paid to T-Mobile at a later date. To the extent that such portions of the purchase price are expected to be received in the future, they are recognized at fair value. T-Mobile continues to recognize the trade receivables sold to the extent of its continuing involvement, i.e., in the maximum amount with which it is still liable for the credit risk and late-payment risk inherent in the receivables sold, and recognizes a corresponding associated liability presented in liabilities to banks. The receivables and the associated liability are then derecognized in the extent to which T-Mobile’s continuing involvement is reduced (particularly when payment is made by the customer). The carrying amount of the receivables is subsequently reduced by the extent to which the actual losses to be borne by T-Mobile resulting from the credit risk and the late-payment risk exceed the losses initially expected. This amount is recognized as an expense. T-Mobile’s continuing involvement as of 31 December 2019 amounted to EUR 6.6 million (2018: EUR 7.4 million), and the carrying amount of the associated liability was EUR 6.8 million (2018: EUR 7.6 million). T-Mobile presents the purchase price payments received from the buyers under cash generated from operations where these relate to the derecognized portion of the receivables, and under net cash from/used in financing activities where they relate to the portion of the receivables that is still recognized. The volume of receivables sold was not subject to major fluctuations since the beginning of the respective transaction.

Subsubsection Text: Parent of the Company . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . — — Other related parties . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 41,000 41,000 **41,000** **41,000 34.** **INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S FEE** The following fees were charged by PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. EUR’1000 EUR’1000 EUR’1000 Audit of the financial statements . . . . . 1,350 — 1.350 Audit related procedures . . . . . . . . . . . — — — Tax services . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . — — — Other non-audit services . . . . . . . . . . . — — — **1,350** **—** **1,350** The fees listed above relate to the procedures applied to the company and its consolidated group entities by accounting firms and external auditors as referred to in art. 1.1 WTA (Dutch Accounting Firms Oversight Act) as well as by Dutch and foreign-based accounting firms, including their tax services and advisory groups. These fees relate to the audit of the 2020 financial statements, regardless of whether the work was performed during the financial year.

The Company’s factoring agreements are subject to financial covenants. For two factoring agreements the financial covenant consist of the tangible net worth ratio based on the audited annual consolidated financial statements. The tangible net worth ratio shall be equal to or greater than 0.18 with the tangible net worth being equal or greater than EUR 500 million. The tangible net worth ratio is calculated as follows (A) divided by (B) whereas (A) is tangible net worth and (B) is balance sheet total. Tangible net worth means share capital plus reserves (including retained earnings) plus minority interests minus (plus (if a negative figure)) cash flow hedge reserve minus intangible assets (excluding licenses). The balance sheet total means balance sheet total minus (plus (if a negative figure)) cash flow hedge reserve) minus intangible assets (excluding licenses). Based on the audited annual consolidated financial statements the tangible net worth ratio amounted to 0.16 in 2020 (2019: 0.21). The tangible net worth amounted to EUR 591 million (2019: EUR 841 million). The financial covenant (tangible net worth ratio) is not met at balance sheet date, but as according to the clauses of the factoring agreement, since the ratio improved within 5 working days after balance sheet date, there is no breach of the financial covenant. On 1 January 2021, the result of the year (EUR 175 million) is transferred to the retained earnings, resulting into a ratio of 0.21 and a tangible net worth of EUR 766 million. Consequently, the financial covenant for the respective factoring agreements have been met for 2020 and 2019. For another factoring agreement a different set of financial covenant applies. The financial covenant of this factoring agreement is based on the Company’s unaudited quarterly financial statements for DT group reporting purposes. The financial covenant is reported to the respective bank on a quarterly basis. The financial covenant for this factoring agreement consists of: The intra-group funding is at least EUR 300 million, The equity ratio may not fall below 20%, and The leverage factor may not exceed 4.0. The Company has met the financial covenant for all quarters during 2020 and 2019. In this respect, The Group depreciated the right-of-use asset resulting from the accounting of the lease agreement under IFRS 16 during the financial year to the amount of EUR 31,088 million (2019: EUR 29,627 million). The unwinding of the lease liability is recognized as interest expense and is shown within the net finance costs to the amount of EUR 35,502 million (2019: EUR 35,954 million). **2020** **2019** EUR’1000 EUR’1000 The Company’s factoring agreements are subject to financial covenants. For two factoring agreements the financial covenant consist of the tangible net worth ratio based on the audited annual consolidated financial statements. The tangible net worth ratio shall be equal to or greater than 0.18 with the tangible net worth being equal or greater than EUR 500 million. The tangible net worth ratio is calculated as follows (A) divided by (B) whereas (A) is tangible net worth and (B) is balance sheet total. Tangible net worth means share capital plus reserves (including retained earnings) plus minority interests minus (plus (if a negative figure)) cash flow hedge reserve minus intangible assets (excluding licenses). The balance sheet total means balance sheet total minus (plus (if a negative figure)) cash flow hedge reserve) minus intangible assets (excluding licenses). Based on the audited annual consolidated financial statements the tangible net worth ratio amounted to 0.21 in 2019 (2018: 0.23). The tangible net worth amounted to EUR 841 million (2018: EUR 521 million). Consequently, the financial covenant for the respective factoring agreements have been met for 2019 and 2018. For another factoring agreement a different set of financial covenant applies. The financial covenant of this factoring agreement is based on the Company’s unaudited quarterly financial statements for DT group reporting purposes. The financial covenant is reported to the respective bank on a quarterly basis. The financial covenant for this factoring agreement consists of: The intra-group funding is at least EUR 300 million, The equity ratio may not fall below 20%, and F-159 ----- The leverage factor may not exceed 4.0. The Company has met the financial covenant for all quarters during 2019 and 2018. **35.** **RELATED-PARTY DISCLOSURES 35.1** **TRANSACTIONS WITH RELATED PARTIES** There are various transactions between the Group, parent company and other related parties during the ordinary course of business. On 6 September 2021, Funds advised by Warburg Pincus LLC (“Warburg Pincus”) and Funds advised by Apax Partners LLP (“Apax”), have agreed to acquire T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V from Deutsche Telekom AG and Tele2 AB. The transaction values the company at an enterprise value of EUR 5.1bn. The deal is subject to approval from regulatory bodies and finalization of the consultation process with the Works Council. F-87 ----- On 6 September 2021, DT Europe B.V., Tele2 Sverige AB and T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. have signed a settlement agreement to terminate the rights and obligations for each of the parties under the SPA concluded in February 2018. This includes, but is not limited to, indemnities for certain claims that existed on the signing date. Some of the indemnities will be continued under the SPA concluded on 6 September 2021 with the contemplated new owners of T-Mobile Netherlands Holdings B.V. On 1 April 2021, the Group signed a long-term agreement to become an anchor tenant on the fiber network to be rolled out by Open Dutch Fiber, a newly established company owner by investment funds KKR and DTCP.(hereafter ‘MSA’). As per this agreement, the Group commits to a long-term agreement to utilize the fiber Infrastructure and warrant a minimum set of payments to the lessor. The MSA only provides a framework / general terms for the Cluster Agreements (CA) that T-Mobile will conclude with the lessor. The CAs set out the details per cluster (area) such as object, commencement date, cluster specifics, charges and payments. Pursuant to the provisions of the MSA/CA, the initial lease term begins on the date on which the relevant cluster is ready for service. Hence, the Group commits to lease the fiber Infrastructure within a cluster and commit to a minimum usage to the lessor as per the date that the subcluster is ready for service. As per the date when the financial statements are authorized for issue, no subclusters are ready for service, which entails that the Group does not yet have a financial commitment, however subclusters will be delivered during the course of 2021 and beyond, which will have a material impact on the financial statements. The Group expects the first subcluster to be ready for service by the end of September 2021. In 2018, a Dutch governmental Taskforce started a risk assessment on 5G security. November 2019 ”Besluit veiligheid en integriteit telecommunicatie”—AMVB is established. In April 2021 T-Mobile received an individual classified decision stating which components should be of a trusted vendor. A transition period is granted. The Group will use this transition period to replace the concerning components. The estimated investment required to replace the concerning components and is included in business plans. Since the beginning of 2019 US regulation has impacted the supply chain for spare parts and execution of services. Actions have been established to ensure continuity both on a spare part level and to bring the execution of services in line with the US regulation. F-88 -----

Subsection Title: Notes to the consolidated financial statements 1** **General information and principal activities 1.1** **Corporate information
Subsubsection Text: T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V., is a limited liability company incorporated and domiciled in the Netherlands with its registered office in The Hague, the Netherlands. The registration number at the Dutch Chamber of Commerce is 33301092. T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. The ultimate parent company of the group is Deutsche Telekom AG in Bonn, Germany. These consolidated financial statements represent the financial statements of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. (T-Mobile or the ‘Company’) and its subsidiaries (together the ‘Group’). The consolidated financial statements of the Group for the year ended 31 December 2018 were authorised for issue in accordance with a resolution of the Board of Management on 31 December 2019. The principal activities of the Group are to participate in, to finance, to collaborate with and to conduct the management of companies and enterprises active in the area of telecommunications and to provide advice and other services. Furthermore, the Group’s objective is to exploit, to apply for and to hold all licenses required for establishing a full-scale mobile and fixed telecommunications business in the Netherlands and to maintain and operate a mobile and fixed telecommunications infrastructure in the Netherlands.
The consolidated financial statements of the Group include:

T-Mobile Netherlands B.V. . . . . . . . . . . . . The Hague 100 100 T-Mobile Klantenservice B.V. . . . . . . . . . . The Hague 100 100 T-Mobile Infra B.V.* . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Hague 100 — T-Mobile Netherlands Retail B.V. . . . . . . The Hague 100 100 T-Mobile Netherlands Finance B.V. . . . . . The Hague 100 100 T-Mobile Thuis B.V. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Hague 100 100 - The Group has decided to demerge part of its passive equipment and part of its rented sites to a separate legal entity, T-Mobile Infra B.V. Active network equipment is not part of the demerger.T-Mobile Infra B.V. has been established on 1 September 2018 via legal demerger as a subsidiary of T-Mobile Netherlands B.V.

The consolidated financial statements of the Group have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as adopted by the European Union (EU), as well as with the statutory provisions of Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. The term IFRS is consistently used in the following. The consolidated financial statements are prepared in thousands of euro. The financial statements of the Group and its subsidiaries included in the consolidated financial statements were prepared using uniform group accounting policies. With reference to the company income statement, use has been made of the exemption pursuant to Section 402 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. F-175 -----

Subsection Title: 2.2** **Changes in accounting policies and disclosures 2.2.1** **Comparative figures
Subsubsection Text: The following restatements were made to the comparative numbers for comparative purposes. The Company has restated the classification of other operating expenses to goods and services purchased for the amount of EUR 24,081. The goods and services purchased decreased from EUR 874,046 to EUR 849,965 and the other operating epenses increased from EUR 18,002 to EUR 42,083. For the continuous involvement in factoring arrangements the Company restated the classification of the related liability from other payables to financial liabilities. The financial liabilities to bank increased with EUR 21,146 to EUR 21,146 and the other amounts payable decreased with EUR 21,146. The above restatements do not have any impact on the reported profit for the year or reported equity and an immaterial impact on the cash flow statement. In the 2018 financial year, T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. applied the following IASB pronouncements and/or amendments to such pronouncements for the first time:
IFRS 9 Financial Instruments IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers IFRIC 22 Foreign Currency Transactions and Advance Consideration

Subsection Title: To be applied by T-Mobile from** **Change
Subsubsection Text: 1 January 2018 IFRS 9 introduces new classification and measurement requirements for financial instruments and replaces, in particular, IAS 39. The new regulations cover the classification of financial assets on the basis of the underlying business models and the cash flow characteristics of the instruments. Under the new provisions on the accounting of impairment losses, expected losses have to be recognized on initial recognition. In addition, the requirements apply not only to debt instruments, but also to contract assets pursuant to IFRS 15. Among other things, the new rules for reporting hedge relationships provide the option of recognizing hedging costs separately in other comprehensive income (OCI). 1 January 2018 This standard provides a single, principles-based five-step model for the determination and recognition of revenue to be applied to all contracts with customers. It replaces in particular IAS 18 and IAS 11. When applying IFRS 15 for the first time, an entity shall apply the standard in full for the current period. In respect of prior periods, the transition guidance grants entities an option to either apply IFRS 15 in full to prior periods (with certain limited practical expedients being available) or to retain priorperiod figures as reported under the F-176 previous standards, recognizing the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 15 to all contracts that had not yet been completed at the beginning of the reporting period as an adjustment to the opening balance of equity at the date of first-time adoption (beginning of current reporting period). 1 January 2018 Mandatory adoption of IFRS 15 for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. 1 January 2018 The clarifications address the following topics relating to IFRS 15: – Identification of performance obligations (when a promised good or service is distinct from other promises in the contract). – Differentiation of principalagent relationships, application guidance on the concept of the transfer of control in the case of services provided by third parties. – Clarification of the conditions for the timing of recognition of revenue arising from the licensing of intellectual property. Further exemption options for the transition to IFRS 15 were also added. 1 January 2018 Clarification of transfers into or out No material impact. of investment property Classification 1 January 2018 Clarifications of classification and and measurement of share-based Measurement payment transactions. of Sharebased Payment Transactions No material impact. No material impact. 1 January 2018 Entities falling within the scope of IFRS 4 and whose predominant activity is issuing insurance contracts may, by way of temporary exemption, defer application of IFRS 9 until such time as the new standard for insurance contracts has come into force. In the interim, such entities are thus subject to the provisions of IAS 39. In the case of F-177 ----- designated financial assets, other entities falling within the scope of IFRS 4 may incur differences in values depending on whether these assets are to be accounted for in accordance with IFRS 9 or IAS 39; these differences must be presented in other comprehensive income instead of in profit or loss. 1 January 2018 IFRIC 22 clarifies what exchange rate is to be applied on initial recognition of a foreign-currency transaction in an entity’s functional currency in cases where the entity receives or pays advance consideration before the related asset, expense or income is recognized. The exchange rate for the underlying asset, expense or income is taken as that prevailing on the date of initial recognition of the non-monetary prepayment asset or deferred income liability

In July 2014, the IASB issued IFRS 9 “Financial Instruments”. Application of this standard is mandatory for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. The standard introduces new classification and measurement requirements for financial instruments and replaces, in particular, IAS 39. The Group applies IFRS 9 prospectively, with an initial application date of 1 January 2018. The cumulative effect arising from the transition is recognized as an adjustment to the opening balance of equity in the year of initial application. TMNL has not restated the comparative information, which continues to be reported under IAS 39. Under IFRS 9, financial assets that are debt instruments are subsequently measured at fair value through profit or loss, amortized cost, or fair value through other comprehensive income. The classification is based on two criteria: the Group’s business model for managing the assets; and whether the instruments’ contractual cash flows represent ‘solely payments of principal and interest’ on the principal amount outstanding. F-178 ----- The assessment of the company’s business model was made as of the date of initial application, 1 January 2018. The assessment of whether contractual cash flows on debt instruments are solely comprised of principal and interest was made based on the facts and circumstances as at the initial recognition of the assets. As described in Note 32.9, the Group is party to factoring agreements under which it sells portfolios its trade receivables on a revolving basis. In accordance with IFRS 9, the Group designated these receivables as either at fair value through other comprehensive income or at fair value through profit or loss. The measurement of debt instruments – especially trade receivables held for potential sale – at fair value had minor effects at the transition date. Effects may arise in ongoing application, particularly from changes in the volumes of receivables held for potential sale in the future. The Group has not designated any financial liabilities as at fair value through profit or loss. There are no changes in classification and measurement for the company’s financial liabilities. The following table shows the effect of adopting IFRS 9 as at 1 January 2018 for each individual line item.

F-89 ----- # Independent auditor’s report To: the general meeting and the supervisory board of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. ## Report on the financial statements 2020 ### Our opinion In our opinion: - the consolidated financial statements of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. together with its subsidiaries (‘the Group’) give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Group as at 31 December 2020 and of its result and cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union (‘EU-IFRS’) and with Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code; - the company financial statements of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. (‘the Company’) give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Company as at 31 December 2020 and of its result for the year then ended in accordance with Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code. ### What we have audited We have audited the accompanying financial statements 2020 of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V., The Hague. The financial statements include the consolidated financial statements of the Group and the company financial statements. The consolidated financial statements comprise: - the consolidated statement of financial position as at 31 December 2020; - the following statements for the year ended 31 December 2020: the consolidated income statement and statement of comprehensive income, the consolidated statement of changes in equity and the consolidated statement of cash flows; and - the notes, comprising significant accounting policies and other explanatory information. As part of the preparation of the financial statements, the board of management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. Based on the financial reporting frameworks mentioned, the board of management should prepare the financial statements using the going concern basis of accounting unless the board of management either intends to liquidate the Company or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so. The board of management should disclose events and circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern in the financial statements. The supervisory board is responsible for overseeing the Company’s financial reporting process. ### Our responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements Our responsibility is to plan and perform an audit engagement in a manner that allows us to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to provide a basis for our opinion. Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error and to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high but not absolute level of assurance, which makes it possible that we may not detect all material misstatements. Misstatements may arise due to fraud or error. They are considered to be material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of the financial statements. Materiality affects the nature, timing and extent of our audit procedures and the evaluation of the effect of identified misstatements on our opinion. A more detailed description of our responsibilities is set out in the appendix to our report. Amsterdam, 24 November 2021 PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. W.A. In addition to what is included in our auditor’s report, we have further set out in this appendix our responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements and explained what an audit involves. ### The auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements We have exercised professional judgement and have maintained professional scepticism throughout the audit in accordance with Dutch Standards on Auditing, ethical requirements and independence requirements. Our audit consisted, among other things of the following: - Identifying and assessing the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, designing and performing audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtaining audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the intentional override of internal control. - Obtaining an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company’s internal control. - Evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the board of management. - Concluding on the appropriateness of the board of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting, and based on the audit evidence obtained, concluding whether a material uncertainty exists related to events and/or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report and are made in the context of our opinion on the financial statements as a whole. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. - Evaluating the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures, and evaluating whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. Considering our ultimate responsibility for the opinion on the consolidated financial statements, we are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the group audit. In this context, we have determined the nature and extent of the audit procedures for components of the Group to ensure that we performed enough work to be able to give an opinion on the financial statements as a whole. Determining factors are the geographic structure of the Group, the significance and/or risk profile of group entities or activities, the accounting processes and controls, and the industry in which the Group operates. On this basis, we selected group entities for which an audit or review of financial information or specific balances was considered necessary. We communicate with the supervisory board regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that we identify during our audit. _T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. - DWNCNXMPWEQQ-1010849602-138_ Page 4 of 4 F-93 ----- The independent auditor’s report of PricewaterhouseCoopers Accountants N.V. is presented on the next pages. The registration number at the Dutch Chamber of Commerce is 33301092. T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. The ultimate parent company of the group is Deutsche Telekom AG in Bonn, Germany. The consolidated financial statements represent the financial statements of T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. and its subsidiaries (together the ‘Group’). The consolidated financial statements of the Group for the year ended 31 December 2019 were authorized for issue in accordance with a resolution of the Board of Management on 31 December 2020. The core activities of the Group are providing mobile and fixed line communications services including internet, television and fixed telephony for the consumer and business market in the Netherlands; the Consumer segment offers fixed and mobile services to the consumer, the Business segment offers fixed and mobile services for entrepreneurs and enterprises. The segment Other consist of other revenue and costs related to the Headquarter.

Section Title: ACQUISITION OF TELE2 NETHERLANDS HOLDING N.V.
Subsubsection Text: The goodwill reflects the value of expected synergies arising from the acquisition, expected new customer gains, and the value of the assembled workforce. The spectrum licenses were measured using the guideline transaction method, with the fair value being derived based on the price analyses used in spectrum auctions carried out in the European telecommunications industry. The spectrum licenses are amortized over the expected useful life of 10 to 11 years. The customer base was measured using the multi-period excess earnings method. Under this method, the fair value of the customer base is determined by calculating the present value of profit/ loss after taxes that can be assigned to the existing customers. The customer base is amortized over the remaining useful life of 5 to 15 years. The carrying amounts of the acquired receivables are based on the fair values. The gross amounts of the receivables amount to EUR 279 million. No material contingent liabilities have been identified. The deferred tax assets relate to Tele2 Netherlands’ loss carryforwards. The deferred tax liabilities comprise the tax effect on the temporary differences between the fair value of the different assets and liabilities on the one hand, and the respective carrying amount for tax purposes on the other. No material transaction-based costs were incurred by December 31, 2019. F-104 -----

Section Title: ACQUISITION OF TELE2 NETHERLANDS HOLDING N.V.
Subsubsection Text: On December 15, 2017, Deutsche Telekom signed an agreement with the Tele2 Group on the acquisition of 100 percent of the shares in the telecommunications provider Tele2 Netherlands Holding N.V. (hereafter: ‘Tele2 Netherlands’) by T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. (hereafter: ‘T-Mobile Netherlands’). After the European Commission issued its approval without conditions on November 27, 2018, the transaction was consummated on January 2, 2019. Tele2 Netherlands has been included in T-Mobile Netherlands’s consolidated financial statements as a fully consolidated subsidiary since the acquisition date. The enlarged company continues to operate as T- Mobile Netherlands and will also use the Tele2 brand name in the Dutch telecom market. This transaction will establish a stronger, more sustainable provider of convergent fixed network and mobile services on the Dutch market. The revenue and profit and loss of the acquiree are since the acquisition date included in the consolidated financial statement of comprehensive income in the reporting period. As the technical merger is realized within the ERP system under the same company code together with T-Mobile Netherlands it is technically impracticable to separate these data. Tele2 Sverige AB received a purchase price in the form of a 25 percent stake in T-Mobile Netherlands and a cash component of EUR 199 million. Deutsche Telekom maintains 75% of the shares in T-Mobile Netherlands. The purchase price allocation and the measurement of Tele2 Netherlands’ assets and liabilities at the acquisition date were finalized as of December 31, 2019. The cash consideration transferred amounts to EUR 199 million plus the stake of Tele2 Sverige AB of 25% in T-Mobile Netherlands Holding B.V. valued at EUR 759 million (in total EUR 958 million). The purchase consideration for the acquisition of the Tele2 business was calculated based on the business plan of the enlarged company, applying the discounted cash flow (DCF) method, and taking synergies into account. Synergies in the business plan included direct costs synergies attributable to the fixed part of the business, market invest synergies attributable to the mobile part of the business, and operating expenditures synergies include synergies related to all categories, i.e. workforce, network, marketing, and other costs. All synergies were assumed to be available to an average market participant. Acquisition related costs amounting to EUR 1.6M were expensed as incurred in the financial year 2019 (2018: EUR 0.6M) and disclosed in the consolidated income statement within the other operating expenses. The fair values of Tele2 Netherlands’ acquired assets and liabilities recognized at the acquisition date are presented in the following table: **2019** Fair value at the acquisition date EUR’1000

Section Title: 1.2.2 DISTRIBUTION OF T-MOBILE INFRA B.V. TO OWNERS BY DIVIDEND IN KIND
Subsubsection Text: T-Mobile decided to demerge part of its passive equipment and part of its rented sites to a separate legal entity. T-Infra B.V. has been established on 1 September 2018 via legal demerger as a subsidiary of T-Mobile Netherlands B.V. Active network equipment was not part of the demerger. As per 1 January 2019, Deutsche Telekom Europe B.V. acquired 100% of the shares of T-Infra B.V. through a dividend in kind. Consequently, T-Mobile derecognized the assets and liabilities of the former subsidiary from the consolidated statement of financial position. The Group will continue to purchase services from T-Infra B.V. **2.** **BASIS OF PREPARATION 2.1** **GENERAL** The consolidated financial statements of the Group comply, in all material respects, with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as adopted by the European Union (EU): IFRS -EU, as well as with the statutory provisions of Part 9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, and give a true and fair view of the assets, liabilities, financial position, and financial performance of the Group. The consolidated financial statements are prepared in thousands of euro. The financial year corresponds to the calendar year. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost basis unless otherwise stated. With reference to the company’s income statement, use has been made of the exemption pursuant to Section 402 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code.

Section Title: 2.4** **NEW STANDARDS, AMENDMENTS AND INTERPRETATIONS ADOPTED BY THE GROUP
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 16 Leases 1 January IFRS 16 principally requires 2019 lessees to recognize assets and liabilities for all leases and the rights and obligations associated with these leases in the statement of financial position. Going forward, lessees will therefore no longer be required to make the distinction between finance and operating leases that was required in the past in accordance with IAS 17. For all leases, the lessee will recognize a lease liability in its statement of financial position for the obligation to make future lease payments. At the same time, the lessee will capitalize a right of use to the underlying asset which is equivalent to the present value of the future lease payments plus initial direct costs, directly attributable expenditure, advance payments and restoration costs, as well as less incentive payments received. Similar to the guidance on finance leases in IAS 17, the lease liability will be adjusted over the lease term for any remeasurement, while the right-of-use asset will be depreciated, which in contrast to the current lease expense normally leads to higher expenses at the inception date of a lease. For the lessor, on the other hand, the provisions of the new standard are similar to the existing guidance in IAS 17. IFRS 16 also includes new provisions on the definition of a lease and its presentation, on disclosures in the notes, and on sale and leaseback transactions. F-106

Section Title: 2.4** **NEW STANDARDS, AMENDMENTS AND INTERPRETATIONS ADOPTED BY THE GROUP
Subsubsection Text: 1 January The amendment sets out 2019 that, if certain conditions are met, financial assets can be measured at amortized cost or fair value through other comprehensive income if, in the case of an early termination, compensation is required to be paid to the party that triggers the early termination of the contract. 1 January The amendments clarify that 2019 an entity applies IFRS 9 including its impairment requirements to long-term interests in an associate or joint venture that form part of the net investment in the associate or joint venture but are not accounted for using the equity method. 1 January The guidance on the 2019 amendment, curtailment, or settlement of a defined benefit pension plan has been changed as follows: Clarification that an entity is required to determine current service cost and the net interest for the remainder of the reporting period after a plan amendment, curtailment, or settlement using updated actuarial assumptions and the net liability (or net asset) at the time of the intervention. Any changes in a surplus must be recognized as profit or loss as part of past service cost, or a gain or loss on settlement, even if this surplus had not been previously disclosed due to the effect of the asset ceiling. The effects of changes in the asset ceiling are recognized in other comprehensive income. F-107 ----- 1 January The interpretation explains 2019 how to recognize and measure deferred and current income tax assets and liabilities where there is uncertainty over a tax treatment. Annual Improvements Project Annual Improvements to IFRSs 2015-2017 Cycle 1 January Clarification of many No material impact. 2019 published standards. The Group applied for the first time the new IFRS 16 ‘Leases’ accounting standard as well as certain amendments to the standards, which are effective on 1 January 2019. The Group has not early adopted any standards, interpretations or amendments that have been issued but are not yet effective. The nature and the impact of the amendments that have a material impact on the presentation of the Group’s result of operations and financial positions are disclosed in this section below. The IFRS 16 standard is mandatory for reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 has a material effect on T-Mobile’s consolidated financial statements, particularly on total assets, the results of operations, cash generated from operations, net cash from/used for financing activities, and the presentation of the financial position. The new regulations affect T-Mobile as a lessee especially in relation to leases of cell sites (land, space in cell towers, or rooftop surface areas), network infrastructure, and buildings used for administrative or technical purposes. T-Mobile has not applied the new lease standard retrospectively in the transition to IFRS 16 and therefore applied the modified retrospective method. The new standard requires payment obligations from existing operating leases to be discounted and recognized as lease liabilities; as financial liabilities, they increase net debt. At the same time, the lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset. Operating expenses previously recognized in connection with operating leases are now recognized in depreciation charges on right-of-use assets and in interest expenses for discounted obligations from operating leases, as appropriate. This significantly increases EBITDA without any attendant change in the economic circumstances. In the statement of cash flows, the principal repayment portion of the lease payments from existing operating leases reduces net cash from/used in financing activities and no longer affects net cash from operating activities. The interest portion of the payments remains in net cash from operating activities and thus also in free cash flow. The Group has not applied the new lease standard retrospectively in full, but makes use of the exemption provisions for lessees, also known as the modified retrospective method. On the transition to IFRS 16, remaining payment obligations from existing operating leases are discounted using the relevant incremental borrowing rate and recognized as a lease liability and the right-of-use assets were carried as of January 1, 2019 in the amount of the lease liability, adjusted by the amount of the prepaid or accrued lease payments. The lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease. If that rate cannot be readily determined, which is generally the case for leases in the Group, the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate is used, being the rate that the individual lessee would have to pay to borrow the funds necessary to obtain an asset of similar value to the right-of-use asset in a similar economic environment with similar terms, security and conditions. The incremental borrowing rate of interest is determined by deriving benchmark interest rates for a period of up to 30 years from maturityrelated risk-free interest rates which are increased by a credit-risk premium and adjusted for a liquidity and country-risk premium and also adjusted for the security related premium. Weighted average incremental borrowing rates of 1.1 to 3.5 percent were applied to lease liabilities recognized in the statement of financial position as of 1 January 2019. For the lease liabilities related to the master lease agreement with T-Mobile Infra B.V., the rate implicit in the lease is 8.5 percent. F-108 ----- In the statement of cash flows, the repayment portion of the lease payments from existing operating leases will reduce net cash from/used in financing activities and no longer affect net cash from operating activities. Only the interest payments will remain in net cash from operating activities, By applying the modified retrospective approach practical expedients are exercised as follows: - The recognition, measurement, and disclosure requirements of IFRS 16 also applied to shortterm leases and leases of low value assets; - Existing contracts will not be grandfathered. On January 1, 2019, IFRS 16 was therefore applied to all existing leases falling within its scope. It applies to contracts in which T-Mobile is a lessee; - A single discount rate is applied to a portfolio of leases with reasonably similar characteristics; - Non-lease components are generally not separated from lease components; instead, each lease component and any associated non-lease components is accounted for as a single lease component. This principle does not include contracts relating to data centers, which due to their special requirements in terms of equipment and premises form their own separate class of underlying asset. For this class of underlying assets, the non-lease payments are recognized as an expense; - IAS 37 is applied immediately before the date of initial application for onerous leases; - Initial direct costs are excluded from the measurement of the right of use asset at the date of initial application; - Provisions for onerous contracts recognized in connection with leases were adjusted against the right-of-use asset as of January 1, 2019; - In determining the lease term, hindsight may be used where economic considerations and penalties indicate that it is reasonably certain that options to extend or terminate the lease will be exercised. In addition, on the date of first-time adoption of IFRS 16 use was made of the main policy elections as follows: - Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities are presented separately in the statement of financial position; - IAS 38 is applied for leases of intangible assets rather than IFRS 16. The Group is not required to make any adjustments on transition to IFRS 16 for leases in which it acts as a lessor, except for a sub-lease. T-Mobile assessed the classification of the sub-lease contracts with reference to the right-of-use asset and concluded that they are finance leases under IFRS 16. The finance leases relate to the sublease of sites. T-Mobile is a party to framework site sharing agreements. The framework site sharing agreements are reciprocal and set for an indefinite time period. Parties to the framework site sharing agreements need the space on the other parties’ sites whereby the reciprocity ascertains that parties will make their sites available to the other party. As per 1 September 2018, the sites subject to the framework site sharing agreements were demerged to T-Mobile Infra B.V. As per 1 September 2018, T-Mobile and T-Mobile Infra concluded a master lease agreement for a minimum period of 15 years whereby T-Mobile leases the passive infrastructure and space on T-Mobile Infra sites. T-Mobile remained principal to the framework site sharing agreements. As at 1 January 2019, T-Mobile recognizes a receivable in the amount of the net investment in the lease for a period of 15 years resulting from subleases related to above mentioned site sharing agreements. The lease payments made by the lessees are split into an interest component and a principal component. The rate implicit in these leases is 8.5%. As at 1 January 2019, a net gain of EUR 21.8 million was recognized in equity as the difference between the net investment in the lease of the amount of EUR 47.1 million and the carrying amount of EUR 18.0 million of the relevant portion of the underlying assets net of deferred tax in the amount of EUR 7.3 million. F-109 ----- The adjustments made to the consolidated statement of financial position as of 1 January 2019 and attributable to the first-time application of IFRS 16 are as follows: - The increase in right-of-use assets amounts to EUR 510.2 million. - Increase in the net investment of the lease amounting to EUR 47.1 million. - With relation to prepayments and accruals, right-of-use assets decreased by EUR 8.5 million (Total right-of-use assets 501.7 million). - The increase in lease liabilities amounts to EUR 510.2 million. - The increase in lease liabilities leads to a corresponding increase in net debt. - The decrease in property, plant and equipment due to reclassification from finance leases amounts to EUR 0.1 million.
